31.26: if I have gazed at the sun when it was shining or at the moon moving in splendor,
31.27: so that my heart was secretly enticed and I threw them a kiss,
31.28: this would also be a crime deserving punishment, for I would have denied God above.
31.29: Have I rejoiced over my enemy’s distress, or become excited when trouble came his way?
31.30: I have not allowed my mouth to sin by asking for his life with a curse.
31.31: Haven’t the members of my household said, “Who is there who has not had enough to eat at Job’s table?”
31.32: No stranger had to spend the night on the street, for I opened my door to the traveler.
31.33: Have I covered my transgressions as others do by hiding my guilt in my heart,
31.34: because I greatly feared the crowds, and the contempt of the clans terrified me, so I grew silent and would not go outside?
31.35: If only I had someone to hear my case! Here is my signature; let the Almighty answer me. Let my Opponent compose His indictment.
31.36: I would surely carry it on my shoulder and wear it like a crown.
31.37: I would give Him an account of all my steps; I would approach Him like a prince.
31.38: If my land cries out against me and its furrows join in weeping,
31.39: if I have consumed its produce without payment or shown contempt for its tenants,
31.40: then let thorns grow instead of wheat and stinkweed instead of barley. The words of Job are concluded.

32.1: So these three men quit answering Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes.
32.2: Then Elihu son of Barachel the Buzite from the family of Ram became angry. He was angry at Job because he had justified himself rather than God.
32.3: He was also angry at Job’s three friends because they had failed to refute him and yet had condemned him.
32.4: Now Elihu had waited to speak to Job because they were all older than he.
32.5: But when he saw that the three men could not answer Job, he became angry.
32.6: So Elihu son of Barachel the Buzite replied: I am young in years, while you are old; therefore I was timid and afraid to tell you what I know.
32.7: I thought that age should speak and maturity should teach wisdom.
32.8: But it is a spirit in man and the breath of the Almighty that give him understanding.
32.9: It is not only the old who are wise or the elderly who understand how to judge.
32.10: Therefore I say, “Listen to me. I too will declare what I know.”
32.11: Look, I waited for your conclusions; I listened to your insights as you sought for words.
32.12: I paid close attention to you. Yet no one proved Job wrong; not one of you refuted his arguments.
32.13: So do not claim, “We have found wisdom; let God deal with him, not man.”
32.14: But Job has not directed his argument to me, and I will not respond to him with your arguments.
32.15: Job’s friends are dismayed and can no longer answer; words have left them.
32.16: Should I continue to wait now that they are silent, now that they stand there and no longer answer?
32.17: I too will answer; yes, I will tell what I know.
32.18: For I am full of words, and my spirit compels me to speak.
32.19: My heart is like unvented wine; it is about to burst like new wineskins.
32.20: I must speak so that I can find relief; I must open my lips and respond.
32.21: I will be partial to no one, and I will not give anyone an undeserved title.
32.22: For I do not know how to give such titles; otherwise, my Maker would remove me in an instant.

33.1: But now, Job, pay attention to my speech, and listen to all my words.
33.2: I am going to open my mouth; my tongue will form words on my palate.
33.3: My words come from my upright heart, and my lips speak with sincerity what they know.
33.4: The Spirit of God has made me, and the breath of the Almighty gives me life.
33.5: Refute me if you can. Prepare your case against me; take your stand.
33.6: I am just like you before God; I was also pinched off from a piece of clay.
33.7: Fear of me should not terrify you; the pressure I exert against you will be light.
33.8: Surely you have spoken in my hearing, and I have heard these very words:
33.9: “I am pure, without transgression; I am clean and have no guilt.
33.10: But He finds reasons to oppose me; He regards me as His enemy.
33.11: He puts my feet in the stocks; He stands watch over all my paths.”
33.12: But I tell you that you are wrong in this matter, since God is greater than man.
33.13: Why do you take Him to court for not answering anything a person asks?
33.14: For God speaks time and again, but a person may not notice it.
33.15: In a dream, a vision in the night, when deep sleep falls on people as they slumber on their beds,
33.16: He uncovers their ears at that time and terrifies them with warnings,
33.17: in order to turn a person from his actions and suppress his pride.
33.18: God spares his soul from the Pit, his life from crossing the river of death.
33.19: A person may be disciplined on his bed with pain and constant distress in his bones,
33.20: so that he detests bread, and his soul despises his favorite food.
33.21: His flesh wastes away to nothing, and his unseen bones stick out.
33.22: He draws near to the Pit, and his life to the executioners.
33.23: If there is an angel on his side, one mediator out of a thousand, to tell a person what is right for him
33.24: and to be gracious to him and say, “Spare him from going down to the Pit; I have found a ransom,”
33.25: then his flesh will be healthier than in his youth, and he will return to the days of his youthful vigor.
33.26: He will pray to God, and God will delight in him. That man will see His face with a shout of joy, and God will restore his righteousness to him.
33.27: He will look at men and say, “I have sinned and perverted what was right; yet I did not get what I deserved.
33.28: He redeemed my soul from going down to the Pit, and I will continue to see the light.”
33.29: God certainly does all these things two or three times to a man
33.30: in order to turn him back from the Pit, so he may shine with the light of life.
33.31: Pay attention, Job, and listen to me. Be quiet, and I will speak.
33.32: But if you have something to say, answer me; speak, for I would like to justify you.
33.33: If not, then listen to me; be quiet, and I will teach you wisdom.

34.2: Hear my words, you wise men, and listen to me, you knowledgeable ones.
34.3: Doesn’t the ear test words as the palate tastes food?
34.4: Let us judge for ourselves what is right; let us decide together what is good.
34.5: For Job has declared, “I am righteous, yet God has deprived me of justice.
34.6: Would I lie about my case? My wound is incurable, though I am without transgression.”
34.7: What man is like Job? He drinks derision like water.
34.8: He keeps company with evildoers and walks with wicked men.
34.9: For he has said, “A man gains nothing when he becomes God’s friend.”
34.10: Therefore listen to me, you men of understanding. It is impossible for God to do wrong, and for the Almighty to act unjustly.
34.11: For He repays a person according to his deeds, and He brings his ways on him.
34.12: Indeed, it is true that God does not act wickedly and the Almighty does not pervert justice.
34.13: Who gave Him authority over the earth? Who put Him in charge of the entire world?
34.14: If He put His mind to it and withdrew the spirit and breath He gave,
34.15: every living thing would perish together and mankind would return to the dust.
34.16: If you have understanding, hear this; listen to what I have to say.
34.17: Could one who hates justice govern the world? Will you condemn the mighty Righteous One,
34.18: who says to a king, “Worthless man!” and to nobles, “Wicked men!"?
34.19: God is not partial to princes and does not favor the rich over the poor, for they are all the work of His hands.
34.20: They die suddenly in the middle of the night; people shudder, then pass away. Even the mighty are removed without effort.
34.21: For His eyes watch over a man’s ways, and He observes all his steps.
34.22: There is no darkness, no deep darkness, where evildoers can hide themselves.
34.23: God does not need to examine a person further, that one should approach Him in court.
34.24: He shatters the mighty without an investigation and sets others in their place.
34.25: Therefore, He recognizes their deeds and overthrows them by night, and they are crushed.
34.26: In full view of the public, He strikes them for their wickedness,
34.27: because they turned aside from following Him and did not understand any of His ways
34.28: but caused the poor to cry out to Him, and He heard the outcry of the afflicted.
34.29: But when God is silent, who can declare Him guilty? When He hides His face, who can see Him? Yet He watches over both individuals and nations,
34.30: so that godless men should not rule or ensnare the people.
34.31: Suppose someone says to God, “I have endured my punishment; I will no longer act wickedly.
34.32: Teach me what I cannot see; if I have done wrong, I won’t do it again.”
34.33: Should God repay you on your terms when you have rejected His? You must choose, not I! So declare what you know.
34.34: Reasonable men will say to me, along with the wise men who hear me,
34.35: “Job speaks without knowledge; his words are without insight.”
34.36: If only Job were tested to the limit, because his answers are like those of wicked men.
34.37: For he adds rebellion to his sin; he scornfully claps in our presence, while multiplying his words against God.

35.2: Do you think it is just when you say, “I am righteous before God"?
35.3: For you ask, “What does it profit You, and what benefit comes to me, if I do not sin?”
35.4: I will answer you and your friends with you.
35.5: Look at the heavens and see; gaze at the clouds high above you.
35.6: If you sin, how does it affect God? If you multiply your transgressions, what does it do to Him?
35.7: If you are righteous, what do you give Him, or what does He receive from your hand?
35.8: Your wickedness affects a person like yourself, and your righteousness another human being.
35.9: People cry out because of severe oppression; they shout for help because of the arm of the mighty.
35.10: But no one asks, “Where is God my Maker, who provides us with songs in the night,
35.11: who gives us more understanding than the animals of the earth and makes us wiser than the birds of the sky?”
35.12: There they cry out, but He does not answer, because of the pride of evil men.
35.13: Indeed, God does not listen to empty cries, and the Almighty does not take note of it—
35.14: how much less when you complain that you do not see Him, that your case is before Him and you are waiting for Him.
35.15: But now, because God’s anger does not punish and He does not pay attention to transgression,
35.16: Job opens his mouth in vain and multiplies words without knowledge.

36.2: Be patient with me a little longer, and I will inform you, for there is still more to be said on God’s behalf.
36.3: I will get my knowledge from a distant place and ascribe justice to my Maker.
36.4: For my arguments are without flaw; one who has perfect knowledge is with you.
36.5: Yes, God is mighty, but He despises no one; He understands all things.
36.6: He does not keep the wicked alive, but He gives justice to the afflicted.
36.7: He does not remove His gaze from the righteous, but He seats them forever with enthroned kings, and they are exalted.
36.8: If people are bound with chains and trapped by the cords of affliction,
36.9: God tells them what they have done and how arrogantly they have transgressed.
36.10: He opens their ears to correction and insists they repent from iniquity.
36.11: If they serve Him obediently, they will end their days in prosperity and their years in happiness.
36.12: But if they do not obey, they will cross the river of death and die without knowledge.
36.13: Those who have a godless heart harbor anger; even when God binds them, they do not cry for help.
36.14: They die in their youth; their life ends among male cult prostitutes.
36.15: God rescues the afflicted by their affliction; He instructs them by their torment.
36.16: Indeed, He lured you from the jaws of distress to a spacious and unconfined place. Your table was spread with choice food.
36.17: Yet now you are obsessed with the judgment due the wicked; judgment and justice have seized you.
36.18: Be careful that no one lures you with riches; do not let a large ransom lead you astray.
36.19: Can your wealth or all your physical exertion keep you from distress?
36.20: Do not long for the night when nations will disappear from their places.
36.21: Be careful that you do not turn to iniquity, for that is why you have been tested by affliction.
36.22: Look, God shows Himself exalted by His power. Who is a teacher like Him?
36.23: Who has appointed His way for Him, and who has declared, “You have done wrong"?
36.24: Remember that you should praise His work, which people have sung about.
36.25: All mankind has seen it; people have looked at it from a distance.
36.26: Yes, God is exalted beyond our knowledge; the number of His years cannot be counted.
36.27: For He makes waterdrops evaporate; they distill the rain into its mist,
36.28: which the clouds pour out and shower abundantly on mankind.
36.29: Can anyone understand how the clouds spread out or how the thunder roars from God’s pavilion?
36.30: See how He spreads His lightning around Him and covers the depths of the sea.
36.31: For He judges the nations with these; He gives food in abundance.
36.32: He covers His hands with lightning and commands it to hit its mark.
36.33: The thunder declares His presence; the cattle also, the approaching storm.

37.1: My heart pounds at this and leaps from my chest.
37.2: Just listen to His thunderous voice and the rumbling that comes from His mouth.
37.3: He lets it loose beneath the entire sky; His lightning to the ends of the earth.
37.4: Then there comes a roaring sound; God thunders with His majestic voice. He does not restrain the lightning when His rumbling voice is heard.
37.5: God thunders marvelously with His voice; He does great things that we cannot comprehend.
37.6: For He says to the snow, “Fall to the earth,” and the torrential rains, His mighty torrential rains,
37.7: serve as His sign to all mankind, so that all men may know His work.
37.8: The wild animals enter their lairs and stay in their dens.
37.9: The windstorm comes from its chamber, and the cold from the driving north winds.
37.10: Ice is formed by the breath of God, and watery expanses are frozen.
37.11: He saturates clouds with moisture; He scatters His lightning through them.
37.12: They swirl about, turning round and round at His direction, accomplishing everything He commands them over the surface of the inhabited world.
37.13: He causes this to happen for punishment, for His land, or for His faithful love.
37.14: Listen to this, Job. Stop and consider God’s wonders.
37.15: Do you know how God directs His clouds or makes their lightning flash?
37.16: Do you understand how the clouds float, those wonderful works of Him who has perfect knowledge?
37.17: You whose clothes get hot when the south wind brings calm to the land,
37.18: can you help God spread out the skies as hard as a cast metal mirror?
37.19: Teach us what we should say to Him; we cannot prepare our case because of our darkness.
37.20: Should He be told that I want to speak? Can a man speak when he is confused?
37.21: Now men cannot even look at the sun when it is in the skies, after a wind has swept through and cleared them away.
37.22: Yet out of the north He comes, shrouded in a golden glow; awesome majesty surrounds Him.
37.23: The Almighty—we cannot reach Him— He is exalted in power! He will not oppress justice and abundant righteousness,
37.24: Therefore, men fear Him. He does not look favorably on any who are wise in heart.

38.1: Then the LORD answered Job from the whirlwind. He said:
38.2: Who is this who obscures My counsel with ignorant words?
38.3: Get ready to answer Me like a man; when I question you, you will inform Me.
38.4: Where were you when I established the earth? Tell Me, if you have understanding.
38.5: Who fixed its dimensions? Certainly you know! Who stretched a measuring line across it?
38.6: What supports its foundations? Or who laid its cornerstone
38.7: while the morning stars sang together and all the sons of God shouted for joy?
38.8: Who enclosed the sea behind doors when it burst from the womb,
38.9: when I made the clouds its garment and thick darkness its blanket,
38.10: when I determined its boundaries and put its bars and doors in place,
38.11: when I declared: “You may come this far, but no farther; your proud waves stop here"?
38.12: Have you ever in your life commanded the morning or assigned the dawn its place,
38.13: so it may seize the edges of the earth and shake the wicked out of it?
38.14: The earth is changed as clay is by a seal; its hills stand out like the folds of a garment.
38.15: Light is withheld from the wicked, and the arm raised in violence is broken.
38.16: Have you traveled to the sources of the sea or walked in the depths of the oceans?
38.17: Have the gates of death been revealed to you? Have you seen the gates of deep darkness?
38.18: Have you comprehended the extent of the earth? Tell Me, if you know all this.
38.19: Where is the road to the home of light? Do you know where darkness lives,
38.20: so you can lead it back to its border? Are you familiar with the paths to its home?
38.21: Don’t you know? You were already born; you have lived so long!
38.22: Have you entered the place where the snow is stored? Or have you seen the storehouses of hail,
38.23: which I hold in reserve for times of trouble, for the day of warfare and battle?
38.24: What road leads to the place where light is dispersed? Where is the source of the east wind that spreads across the earth?
38.25: Who cuts a channel for the flooding rain or clears the way for lightning,
38.26: to bring rain on an uninhabited land, on a desert with no human life,
38.27: to satisfy the parched wasteland and cause the grass to sprout?
38.28: Does the rain have a father? Who fathered the drops of dew?
38.29: Whose womb did the ice come from? Who gave birth to the frost of heaven
38.30: when water becomes as hard as stone, and the surface of the watery depths is frozen?
38.31: Can you fasten the chains of the Pleiades or loosen the belt of Orion?
38.32: Can you bring out the constellations in their season and lead the Bear and her cubs?
38.33: Do you know the laws of heaven? Can you impose its authority on earth?
38.34: Can you command the clouds so that a flood of water covers you?
38.35: Can you send out lightning bolts, and they go? Do they report to you: “Here we are"?
38.36: Who put wisdom in the heart or gave the mind understanding?
38.37: Who has the wisdom to number the clouds? Or who can tilt the water jars of heaven
38.38: when the dust hardens like cast metal and the clods of dirt stick together?
38.39: Can you hunt prey for a lioness or satisfy the appetite of young lions
38.40: when they crouch in their dens and lie in wait within their lairs?
38.41: Who provides the raven’s food when its young cry out to God and wander about for lack of food?

39.1: Do you know when mountain goats give birth? Have you watched the deer in labor?
39.2: Can you count the months they are pregnant so you can know the time they give birth?
39.3: They crouch down to give birth to their young; they deliver their newborn.
39.4: Their offspring are healthy and grow up in the open field. They leave and do not return.
39.5: Who set the wild donkey free? Who released the swift donkey from its harness?
39.6: I made the wilderness its home, and the salty wasteland its dwelling.
39.7: It scoffs at the noise of the village and never hears the shouts of a driver.
39.8: It roams the mountains for its pastureland, searching for anything green.
39.9: Would the wild ox be willing to serve you? Would it spend the night by your feeding trough?
39.10: Can you hold the wild ox to a furrow by its harness? Will it plow the valleys behind you?
39.11: Can you depend on it because its strength is great? Would you leave it to do your hard work?
39.12: Can you trust the wild ox to harvest your grain and bring it to your threshing floor?
39.13: The wings of the ostrich flap joyfully, but are her feathers and plumage like the stork’s?
39.14: She abandons her eggs on the ground and lets them be warmed in the sand.
39.15: She forgets that a foot may crush them or that some wild animal may trample them.
39.16: She treats her young harshly, as if they were not her own, with no fear that her labor may have been in vain.
39.17: For God has deprived her of wisdom; He has not endowed her with understanding.
39.18: When she proudly spreads her wings, she laughs at the horse and its rider.
39.19: Do you give strength to the horse? Do you adorn his neck with a mane?
39.20: Do you make him leap like a locust? His proud snorting fills one with terror.
39.21: He paws in the valley and rejoices in his strength; He charges into battle.
39.22: He laughs at fear, since he is afraid of nothing; he does not run from the sword.
39.23: A quiver rattles at his side, along with a flashing spear and a lance.
39.24: He charges ahead with trembling rage; he cannot stand still at the trumpet’s sound.
39.25: When the trumpet blasts, he snorts defiantly. He smells the battle from a distance; he hears the officers’ shouts and the battle cry.
39.26: Does the hawk take flight by your understanding and spread its wings to the south?
39.27: Does the eagle soar at your command and make its nest on high?
39.28: It lives on a cliff where it spends the night; its stronghold is on a rocky crag.
39.29: From there it searches for prey; its eyes penetrate the distance.
39.30: Its brood gulps down blood, and where the slain are, it is there.

40.2: Will the one who contends with the Almighty correct Him? Let him who argues with God give an answer.
40.4: I am so insignificant. How can I answer You? I place my hand over my mouth.
40.5: I have spoken once, and I will not reply; twice, but now I can add nothing.
40.6: Then the LORD answered Job from the whirlwind:
40.7: Get ready to answer Me like a man; When I question you, you will inform Me.
40.8: Would you really challenge My justice? Would you declare Me guilty to justify yourself?
40.9: Do you have an arm like God’s? Can you thunder with a voice like His?
40.10: Adorn yourself with majesty and splendor, and clothe yourself with honor and glory.
40.11: Unleash your raging anger; look on every proud person and humiliate him.
40.12: Look on every proud person and humble him; trample the wicked where they stand.
40.13: Hide them together in the dust; imprison them in the grave.
40.14: Then I will confess to you that your own right hand can deliver you.
40.15: Look at Behemoth, which I made along with you. He eats grass like an ox.
40.16: Look at the strength of his loins and the power in the muscles of his belly.
40.17: He stiffens his tail like a cedar tree; the tendons of his thighs are woven firmly together.
40.18: His bones are bronze tubes; his limbs are like iron rods.
40.19: He is the foremost of God’s works; only his Maker can draw the sword against him.
40.20: The hills yield food for him, while all sorts of wild animals play there.
40.21: He lies under the lotus plants, hiding in the protection of marshy reeds.
40.22: Lotus plants cover him with their shade; the willows by the brook surround him.
40.23: Though the river rages, Behemoth is unafraid; he remains confident, even if the Jordan surges up to his mouth.
40.24: Can anyone capture him while he looks on, or pierce his nose with snares?

41.1: Can you pull in Leviathan with a hook or tie his tongue down with a rope?
41.2: Can you put a cord through his nose or pierce his jaw with a hook?
41.3: Will he beg you for mercy or speak softly to you?
41.4: Will he make a covenant with you so that you can take him as a slave forever?
41.5: Can you play with him like a bird or put him on a leash for your girls?
41.6: Will traders bargain for him or divide him among the merchants?
41.7: Can you fill his hide with harpoons or his head with fishing spears?
41.8: Lay a hand on him. You will remember the battle and never repeat it!
41.9: Any hope of capturing him proves false. Does a person not collapse at the very sight of him?
41.10: No one is ferocious enough to rouse Leviathan; who then can stand against Me?
41.11: Who confronted Me, that I should repay him? Everything under heaven belongs to Me.
41.12: I cannot be silent about his limbs, his power, and his graceful proportions.
41.13: Who can strip off his outer covering? Who can penetrate his double layer of armor?
41.14: Who can open his jaws, surrounded by those terrifying teeth?
41.15: His pride is in his rows of scales, closely sealed together.
41.16: One scale is so close to another that no air can pass between them.
41.17: They are joined to one another, so closely connected they cannot be separated.
41.18: His snorting flashes with light, while his eyes are like the rays of dawn.
41.19: Flaming torches shoot from his mouth; fiery sparks fly out!
41.20: Smoke billows from his nostrils as from a boiling pot or burning reeds.
41.21: His breath sets coals ablaze, and flames pour out of his mouth.
41.22: Strength resides in his neck, and dismay dances before him.
41.23: The folds of his flesh are joined together, solid as metal and immovable.
41.24: His heart is as hard as a rock, as hard as a lower millstone!
41.25: When Leviathan rises, the mighty are terrified; they withdraw because of his thrashing.
41.26: The sword that reaches him will have no effect, nor will a spear, dart, or arrow.
41.27: He regards iron as straw, and bronze as rotten wood.
41.28: No arrow can make him flee; slingstones become like stubble to him.
41.29: A club is regarded as stubble, and he laughs at the sound of a javelin.
41.30: His undersides are jagged potsherds, spreading the mud like a threshing sledge.
41.31: He makes the depths seethe like a cauldron; he makes the sea like an ointment jar.
41.32: He leaves a shining wake behind him; one would think the deep had gray hair!
41.33: He has no equal on earth— a creature devoid of fear!
41.34: He surveys everything that is haughty; he is king over all the proud beasts.

42.1: Then Job replied to the LORD:
42.2: I know that You can do anything and no plan of Yours can be thwarted.
42.3: You asked, “Who is this who conceals My counsel with ignorance?” Surely I spoke about things I did not understand, things too wonderful for me to know.
42.4: You said, “Listen now, and I will speak. When I question you, you will inform Me.”
42.5: I had heard rumors about You, but now my eyes have seen You.
42.6: Therefore I take back my words and repent in dust and ashes.
42.7: After the LORD had finished speaking to Job, He said to Eliphaz the Temanite: “I am angry with you and your two friends, for you have not spoken the truth about Me, as My servant Job has.
42.8: Now take seven bulls and seven rams, go to My servant Job, and offer a burnt offering for yourselves. Then My servant Job will pray for you. I will surely accept his prayer and not deal with you as your folly deserves. For you have not spoken the truth about Me, as My servant Job has.”
42.9: Then Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite went and did as the LORD had told them, and the LORD accepted Job’s prayer.
42.10: After Job had prayed for his friends, the LORD restored his prosperity and doubled his previous possessions.
42.11: All his brothers, sisters, and former acquaintances came to his house and dined with him in his house. They sympathized with him and comforted him concerning all the adversity the LORD had brought on him. Each one gave him a qesitah and a gold earring.
42.12: So the LORD blessed the last part of Job’s life more than the first. He owned 14,000 sheep, 6,000 camels, 1,000 yoke of oxen, and 1,000 female donkeys.
42.13: He also had seven sons and three daughters.
42.14: He named his first daughter Jemimah, his second Keziah, and his third Keren-happuch.
42.15: No women as beautiful as Job’s daughters could be found in all the land, and their father granted them an inheritance with their brothers.
42.16: Job lived 140 years after this and saw his children and their children to the fourth generation.
42.17: Then Job died, old and full of days.

1.1: How happy is the man who does not follow the advice of the wicked or take the path of sinners or join a group of mockers!
1.2: Instead, his delight is in the LORD’s instruction, and he meditates on it day and night.
1.3: He is like a tree planted beside streams of water that bears its fruit in season and whose leaf does not wither. Whatever he does prospers.
1.4: The wicked are not like this; instead, they are like chaff that the wind blows away.
1.5: Therefore the wicked will not survive the judgment, and sinners will not be in the community of the righteous.
1.6: For the LORD watches over the way of the righteous, but the way of the wicked leads to ruin.

2.1: Why do the nations rebel and the peoples plot in vain?
2.2: The kings of the earth take their stand, and the rulers conspire together against the LORD and His Anointed One:”
2.3: Let us tear off their chains and free ourselves from their restraints.”
2.4: The One enthroned in heaven laughs; the Lord ridicules them.
2.5: Then He speaks to them in His anger and terrifies them in His wrath:”
2.6: I have consecrated My King on Zion, My holy mountain.”
2.7: I will declare the LORD’s decree: He said to Me, “You are My Son; today I have become Your Father.
2.8: Ask of Me, and I will make the nations Your inheritance and the ends of the earth Your possession.
2.9: You will break them with a rod of iron; You will shatter them like pottery.”
2.10: So now, kings, be wise; receive instruction, you judges of the earth.
2.11: Serve the LORD with reverential awe and rejoice with trembling.
2.12: Pay homage to the Son or He will be angry and you will perish in your rebellion, for His anger may ignite at any moment. All those who take refuge in Him are happy.

3.1: A psalm of David when he fled from his son Absalom. LORD, how my foes increase! There are many who attack me.
3.2: Many say about me,” There is no help for him in God.” Selah
3.3: But You, LORD, are a shield around me, my glory, and the One who lifts up my head.
3.4: I cry aloud to the LORD, and He answers me from His holy mountain. Selah
3.5: I lie down and sleep; I wake again because the LORD sustains me.
3.6: I am not afraid of the thousands of people who have taken their stand against me on every side.
3.7: Rise up, LORD! Save me, my God! You strike all my enemies on the cheek; You break the teeth of the wicked.
3.8: Salvation belongs to the LORD; may Your blessing be on Your people. Selah

4.1: For the choir director: with stringed instruments. A Davidic psalm. Answer me when I call, God, who vindicates me. You freed me from affliction; be gracious to me and hear my prayer.
4.2: How long, exalted men, will my honor be insulted? How long will you love what is worthless and pursue a lie? Selah
4.3: Know that the LORD has set apart the faithful for Himself; the LORD will hear when I call to Him.
4.4: Be angry and do not sin; on your bed, reflect in your heart and be still. Selah
4.5: Offer sacrifices in righteousness and trust in the LORD.
4.6: Many are saying, “Who can show us anything good?” Look on us with favor, LORD.
4.7: You have put more joy in my heart than they have when their grain and new wine abound.
4.8: I will both lie down and sleep in peace, for You alone, LORD, make me live in safety.

5.1: For the choir director: with the flutes. A Davidic psalm. Listen to my words, LORD; consider my sighing.
5.2: Pay attention to the sound of my cry, my King and my God, for I pray to You.
5.3: At daybreak, LORD, You hear my voice; at daybreak I plead my case to You and watch expectantly.
5.4: For You are not a God who delights in wickedness; evil cannot dwell with You.
5.5: The boastful cannot stand in Your presence; You hate all evildoers.
5.6: You destroy those who tell lies; the LORD abhors a man of bloodshed and treachery.
5.7: But I enter Your house by the abundance of Your faithful love; I bow down toward Your holy temple in reverential awe of You.
5.8: LORD, lead me in Your righteousness because of my adversaries; make Your way straight before me.
5.9: For there is nothing reliable in what they say; destruction is within them; their throat is an open grave; they flatter with their tongues.
5.10: Punish them, God; let them fall by their own schemes. Drive them out because of their many crimes, for they rebel against You.
5.11: But let all who take refuge in You rejoice; let them shout for joy forever. May You shelter them, and may those who love Your name boast about You.
5.12: For You, LORD, bless the righteous one; You surround him with favor like a shield.

6.1: For the choir director: with stringed instruments, according to Sheminith. A Davidic psalm. LORD, do not rebuke me in Your anger; do not discipline me in Your wrath.
6.2: Be gracious to me, LORD, for I am weak; heal me, LORD, for my bones are shaking;
6.3: my whole being is shaken with terror. And You, LORD—how long?
6.4: Turn, LORD! Rescue me; save me because of Your faithful love.
6.5: For there is no remembrance of You in death; who can thank You in Sheol?
6.6: I am weary from my groaning; with my tears I dampen my pillow and drench my bed every night.
6.7: My eyes are swollen from grief; they grow old because of all my enemies.
6.8: Depart from me, all evildoers, for the LORD has heard the sound of my weeping.
6.9: The LORD has heard my plea for help; the LORD accepts my prayer.
6.10: All my enemies will be ashamed and shake with terror; they will turn back and suddenly be disgraced.

7.1: A Shiggaion of David, which he sang to the LORD concerning the words of Cush, a Benjaminite. Yahweh my God, I seek refuge in You; save me from all my pursuers and rescue me
7.2: or they will tear me like a lion, ripping me apart with no one to rescue me.
7.3: Yahweh my God, if I have done this, if there is injustice on my hands,
7.4: if I have done harm to one at peace with me or have plundered my adversary without cause,
7.5: may an enemy pursue and overtake me; may he trample me to the ground and leave my honor in the dust. Selah
7.6: Rise up, LORD, in Your anger; lift Yourself up against the fury of my adversaries; awake for me; You have ordained a judgment.
7.7: Let the assembly of peoples gather around You; take Your seat on high over it.
7.8: The LORD judges the peoples; vindicate me, LORD, according to my righteousness and my integrity.
7.9: Let the evil of the wicked come to an end, but establish the righteous. The One who examines the thoughts and emotions is a righteous God.
7.10: My shield is with God, who saves the upright in heart.
7.11: God is a righteous judge and a God who shows His wrath every day.
7.12: If anyone does not repent, God will sharpen His sword; He has strung His bow and made it ready.
7.13: He has prepared His deadly weapons; He tips His arrows with fire.
7.14: See, the wicked one is pregnant with evil, conceives trouble, and gives birth to deceit.
7.15: He dug a pit and hollowed it out but fell into the hole he had made.
7.16: His trouble comes back on his own head, and his violence falls on the top of his head.
7.17: I will thank the LORD for His righteousness; I will sing about the name of Yahweh the Most High.

8.1: For the choir director: on the Gittith. A Davidic psalm. Yahweh, our Lord, how magnificent is Your name throughout the earth! You have covered the heavens with Your majesty.
8.2: Because of Your adversaries, You have established a stronghold from the mouths of children and nursing infants to silence the enemy and the avenger.
8.3: When I observe Your heavens, the work of Your fingers, the moon and the stars, which You set in place,
8.4: what is man that You remember him, the son of man that You look after him?
8.5: You made him little less than God and crowned him with glory and honor.
8.6: You made him lord over the works of Your hands; You put everything under his feet:
8.7: all the sheep and oxen, as well as the animals in the wild,
8.8: the birds of the sky, and the fish of the sea that pass through the currents of the seas.
8.9: Yahweh, our Lord, how magnificent is Your name throughout the earth!

9.1: For the choir director: according to Muth-labben. A Davidic psalm. I will thank Yahweh with all my heart; I will declare all Your wonderful works.
9.2: I will rejoice and boast about You; I will sing about Your name, Most High.
9.3: When my enemies retreat, they stumble and perish before You.
9.4: For You have upheld my just cause; You are seated on Your throne as a righteous judge.
9.5: You have rebuked the nations: You have destroyed the wicked; You have erased their name forever and ever.
9.6: The enemy has come to eternal ruin; You have uprooted the cities, and the very memory of them has perished.
9.7: But the LORD sits enthroned forever; He has established His throne for judgment.
9.8: He judges the world with righteousness; He executes judgment on the nations with fairness.
9.9: The LORD is a refuge for the oppressed, a refuge in times of trouble.
9.10: Those who know Your name trust in You because You have not abandoned those who seek You, Yahweh.
9.11: Sing to the LORD, who dwells in Zion; proclaim His deeds among the nations.
9.12: For the One who seeks an accounting for bloodshed remembers them; He does not forget the cry of the afflicted.
9.13: Be gracious to me, LORD; consider my affliction at the hands of those who hate me. Lift me up from the gates of death,
9.14: so that I may declare all Your praises. I will rejoice in Your salvation within the gates of Daughter Zion.
9.15: The nations have fallen into the pit they made; their foot is caught in the net they have concealed.
9.16: The LORD has revealed Himself; He has executed justice, striking down the wicked by the work of their hands. Higgaion. Selah
9.17: The wicked will return to Sheol— all the nations that forget God.
9.18: For the oppressed will not always be forgotten; the hope of the afflicted will not perish forever.
9.19: Rise up, LORD! Do not let man prevail; let the nations be judged in Your presence.
9.20: Put terror in them, LORD; let the nations know they are only men. Selah

10.1: LORD, why do You stand so far away? Why do You hide in times of trouble?
10.2: In arrogance the wicked relentlessly pursue the afflicted; let them be caught in the schemes they have devised.
10.3: For the wicked one boasts about his own cravings; the one who is greedy curses and despises the LORD.
10.4: In all his scheming, the wicked arrogantly thinks:” There is no accountability, since God does not exist.”
10.5: His ways are always secure; Your lofty judgments are beyond his sight; he scoffs at all his adversaries.
10.6: He says to himself, “I will never be moved— from generation to generation without calamity.”
10.7: Cursing, deceit, and violence fill his mouth; trouble and malice are under his tongue.
10.8: He waits in ambush near the villages; he kills the innocent in secret places. His eyes are on the lookout for the helpless;
10.9: he lurks in secret like a lion in a thicket. He lurks in order to seize the afflicted; he seizes the afflicted and drags him in his net.
10.10: So he is oppressed and beaten down; the helpless fall because of his strength.
10.11: He says to himself, “God has forgotten; He hides His face and will never see.”
10.12: Rise up, LORD God! Lift up Your hand. Do not forget the afflicted.
10.13: Why has the wicked person despised God? He says to himself, “You will not demand an account.”
10.14: But You Yourself have seen trouble and grief, observing it in order to take the matter into Your hands. The helpless entrusts himself to You; You are a helper of the fatherless.
10.15: Break the arm of the wicked and evil person; call his wickedness into account until nothing remains of it.
10.16: The LORD is King forever and ever; the nations will perish from His land.
10.17: LORD, You have heard the desire of the humble; You will strengthen their hearts. You will listen carefully,
10.18: doing justice for the fatherless and the oppressed so that men of the earth may terrify them no more.

11.1: For the choir director. Davidic. I have taken refuge in the LORD. How can you say to me,” Escape to the mountain like a bird!
11.2: For look, the wicked string the bow; they put the arrow on the bowstring to shoot from the shadows at the upright in heart.
11.3: When the foundations are destroyed, what can the righteous do?”
11.4: The LORD is in His holy temple; the LORD’s throne is in heaven. His eyes watch; He examines everyone.
11.5: The LORD examines the righteous and the wicked. He hates the lover of violence.
11.6: He will rain burning coals and sulfur on the wicked; a scorching wind will be their portion.
11.7: For the LORD is righteous; He loves righteous deeds. The upright will see His face.

12.1: For the choir director: according to Sheminith. A Davidic psalm. Help, LORD, for no faithful one remains; the loyal have disappeared from the human race.
12.2: They lie to one another; they speak with flattering lips and deceptive hearts.
12.3: May the LORD cut off all flattering lips and the tongue that speaks boastfully.
12.4: They say, “Through our tongues we have power; our lips are our own—who can be our master?"”
12.5: Because of the oppression of the afflicted and the groaning of the poor, I will now rise up,” says the LORD.” I will put the one who longs for it in a safe place.”
12.6: The words of the LORD are pure words, like silver refined in an earthen furnace, purified seven times.
12.7: You, LORD, will guard us; You will protect us from this generation forever.
12.8: The wicked wander everywhere, and what is worthless is exalted by the human race.

13.1: For the choir director. A Davidic psalm. LORD, how long will You forget me? Forever? How long will You hide Your face from me?
13.2: How long will I store up anxious concerns within me, agony in my mind every day? How long will my enemy dominate me?
13.3: Consider me and answer, LORD my God. Restore brightness to my eyes; otherwise, I will sleep in death.
13.4: My enemy will say, “I have triumphed over him,” and my foes will rejoice because I am shaken.
13.5: But I have trusted in Your faithful love; my heart will rejoice in Your deliverance.
13.6: I will sing to the LORD because He has treated me generously.

14.1: For the choir director. Davidic. The fool says in his heart, “God does not exist.” They are corrupt; they do vile deeds. There is no one who does good.
14.2: The LORD looks down from heaven on the human race to see if there is one who is wise, one who seeks God.
14.3: All have turned away; all alike have become corrupt. There is no one who does good, not even one.
14.4: Will evildoers never understand? They consume My people as they consume bread; they do not call on the LORD.
14.5: Then they will be filled with terror, for God is with those who are righteous.
14.6: You sinners frustrate the plans of the afflicted, but the LORD is his refuge.
14.7: Oh, that Israel’s deliverance would come from Zion! When the LORD restores the fortunes of His people, Jacob will rejoice; Israel will be glad.

15.1: A Davidic psalm. LORD, who can dwell in Your tent? Who can live on Your holy mountain?
15.2: The one who lives honestly, practices righteousness, and acknowledges the truth in his heart—
15.3: who does not slander with his tongue, who does not harm his friend or discredit his neighbor,
15.4: who despises the one rejected by the LORD but honors those who fear the LORD, who keeps his word whatever the cost,
15.5: who does not lend his money at interest or take a bribe against the innocent— the one who does these things will never be moved.

16.1: A Davidic Miktam. Protect me, God, for I take refuge in You.
16.2: I said to Yahweh, “You are my Lord; I have nothing good besides You.”
16.3: As for the holy people who are in the land, they are the noble ones. All my delight is in them.
16.4: The sorrows of those who take another god for themselves will multiply; I will not pour out their drink offerings of blood, and I will not speak their names with my lips.
16.5: LORD, You are my portion and my cup of blessing; You hold my future.
16.6: The boundary lines have fallen for me in pleasant places; indeed, I have a beautiful inheritance.
16.7: I will praise the LORD who counsels me— even at night my conscience instructs me.
16.8: I keep the LORD in mind always. Because He is at my right hand, I will not be shaken.
16.9: Therefore my heart is glad and my spirit rejoices; my body also rests securely.
16.10: For You will not abandon me to Sheol; You will not allow Your Faithful One to see decay.
16.11: You reveal the path of life to me; in Your presence is abundant joy; in Your right hand are eternal pleasures.

17.1: A Davidic prayer. LORD, hear a just cause; pay attention to my cry; listen to my prayer— from lips free of deceit.
17.2: Let my vindication come from You, for You see what is right.
17.3: You have tested my heart; You have examined me at night. You have tried me and found nothing evil; I have determined that my mouth will not sin.
17.4: Concerning what people do: by the word of Your lips I have avoided the ways of the violent.
17.5: My steps are on Your paths; my feet have not slipped.
17.6: I call on You, God, because You will answer me; listen closely to me; hear what I say.
17.7: Display the wonders of Your faithful love, Savior of all who seek refuge from those who rebel against Your right hand.
17.8: Protect me as the pupil of Your eye; hide me in the shadow of Your wings
17.9: from the wicked who treat me violently, my deadly enemies who surround me.
17.10: They have become hardened; their mouths speak arrogantly.
17.11: They advance against me; now they surround me. They are determined to throw me to the ground.
17.12: They are like a lion eager to tear, like a young lion lurking in ambush.
17.13: Rise up, LORD! Confront him; bring him down. With Your sword, save me from the wicked.
17.14: With Your hand, LORD, save me from men, from men of the world whose portion is in this life: You fill their bellies with what You have in store; their sons are satisfied, and they leave their surplus to their children.
17.15: But I will see Your face in righteousness; when I awake, I will be satisfied with Your presence.

18.1: For the choir director. Of the servant of the LORD, David, who spoke the words of this song to the LORD on the day the LORD rescued him from the hand of all his enemies and from the hand of Saul. He said: I love You, LORD, my strength.
18.2: The LORD is my rock, my fortress, and my deliverer, my God, my mountain where I seek refuge, my shield and the horn of my salvation, my stronghold.
18.3: I called to the LORD, who is worthy of praise, and I was saved from my enemies.
18.4: The ropes of death were wrapped around me; the torrents of destruction terrified me.
18.5: The ropes of Sheol entangled me; the snares of death confronted me.
18.6: I called to the LORD in my distress, and I cried to my God for help. From His temple He heard my voice, and my cry to Him reached His ears.
18.7: Then the earth shook and quaked; the foundations of the mountains trembled; they shook because He burned with anger.
18.8: Smoke rose from His nostrils, and consuming fire came from His mouth; coals were set ablaze by it.
18.9: He parted the heavens and came down, a dark cloud beneath His feet.
18.10: He rode on a cherub and flew, soaring on the wings of the wind.
18.11: He made darkness His hiding place, dark storm clouds His canopy around Him.
18.12: From the radiance of His presence, His clouds swept onward with hail and blazing coals.
18.13: The LORD thundered from heaven; the Most High projected His voice.
18.14: He shot His arrows and scattered them; He hurled lightning bolts and routed them.
18.15: The depths of the sea became visible, the foundations of the world were exposed, at Your rebuke, LORD, at the blast of the breath of Your nostrils.
18.16: He reached down from heaven and took hold of me; He pulled me out of deep waters.
18.17: He rescued me from my powerful enemy and from those who hated me, for they were too strong for me.
18.18: They confronted me in the day of my distress, but the LORD was my support.
18.19: He brought me out to a spacious place; He rescued me because He delighted in me.
18.20: The LORD rewarded me according to my righteousness; He repaid me according to the cleanness of my hands.
18.21: For I have kept the ways of the LORD and have not turned from my God to wickedness.
18.22: Indeed, I have kept all His ordinances in mind and have not disregarded His statutes.
18.23: I was blameless toward Him and kept myself from sinning.
18.24: So the LORD repaid me according to my righteousness, according to the cleanness of my hands in His sight.
18.25: With the faithful You prove Yourself faithful; with the blameless man You prove Yourself blameless;
18.26: with the pure You prove Yourself pure, but with the crooked You prove Yourself shrewd.
18.27: For You rescue an afflicted people, but You humble those with haughty eyes.
18.28: LORD, You light my lamp; my God illuminates my darkness.
18.29: With You I can attack a barrier, and with my God I can leap over a wall.
18.30: God—His way is perfect; the word of the LORD is pure. He is a shield to all who take refuge in Him.
18.31: For who is God besides Yahweh? And who is a rock? Only our God.
18.32: God—He clothes me with strength and makes my way perfect.
18.33: He makes my feet like the feet of a deer and sets me securely on the heights.
18.34: He trains my hands for war; my arms can bend a bow of bronze.
18.35: You have given me the shield of Your salvation; Your right hand upholds me, and Your humility exalts me.
18.36: You widen a place beneath me for my steps, and my ankles do not give way.
18.37: I pursue my enemies and overtake them; I do not turn back until they are wiped out.
18.38: I crush them, and they cannot get up; they fall beneath my feet.
18.39: You have clothed me with strength for battle; You subdue my adversaries beneath me.
18.40: You have made my enemies retreat before me; I annihilate those who hate me.
18.41: They cry for help, but there is no one to save them— they cry to the LORD, but He does not answer them.
18.42: I pulverize them like dust before the wind; I trample them like mud in the streets.
18.43: You have freed me from the feuds among the people; You have appointed me the head of nations; a people I had not known serve me.
18.44: Foreigners submit to me grudgingly; as soon as they hear, they obey me.
18.45: Foreigners lose heart and come trembling from their fortifications.
18.46: The LORD lives—may my rock be praised! The God of my salvation is exalted.
18.47: God—He gives me vengeance and subdues peoples under me.
18.48: He frees me from my enemies. You exalt me above my adversaries; You rescue me from violent men.
18.49: Therefore I will praise You, Yahweh, among the nations; I will sing about Your name.
18.50: He gives great victories to His king; He shows loyalty to His anointed, to David and his descendants forever.

19.1: For the choir director. A Davidic psalm. The heavens declare the glory of God, and the sky proclaims the work of His hands.
19.2: Day after day they pour out speech; night after night they communicate knowledge.
19.3: There is no speech; there are no words; their voice is not heard.
19.4: Their message has gone out to all the earth, and their words to the ends of the world. In the heavens He has pitched a tent for the sun.
19.5: It is like a groom coming from the bridal chamber; it rejoices like an athlete running a course.
19.6: It rises from one end of the heavens and circles to their other end; nothing is hidden from its heat.
19.7: The instruction of the LORD is perfect, renewing one’s life; the testimony of the LORD is trustworthy, making the inexperienced wise.
19.8: The precepts of the LORD are right, making the heart glad; the command of the LORD is radiant, making the eyes light up.
19.9: The fear of the LORD is pure, enduring forever; the ordinances of the LORD are reliable and altogether righteous.
19.10: They are more desirable than gold— than an abundance of pure gold; and sweeter than honey, which comes from the honeycomb.
19.11: In addition, Your servant is warned by them; there is great reward in keeping them.
19.12: Who perceives his unintentional sins? Cleanse me from my hidden faults.
19.13: Moreover, keep Your servant from willful sins; do not let them rule over me. Then I will be innocent and cleansed from blatant rebellion.
19.14: May the words of my mouth and the meditation of my heart be acceptable to You, LORD, my rock and my Redeemer.

20.1: For the choir director. A Davidic psalm. May Yahweh answer you in a day of trouble; may the name of Jacob’s God protect you.
20.2: May He send you help from the sanctuary and sustain you from Zion.
20.3: May He remember all your offerings and accept your burnt offering. Selah
20.4: May He give you what your heart desires and fulfill your whole purpose.
20.5: Let us shout for joy at your victory and lift the banner in the name of our God. May Yahweh fulfill all your requests.
20.6: Now I know that the LORD gives victory to His anointed; He will answer him from His holy heaven with mighty victories from His right hand.
20.7: Some take pride in chariots, and others in horses, but we take pride in the name of Yahweh our God.
20.8: They collapse and fall, but we rise and stand firm.
20.9: LORD, give victory to the king! May He answer us on the day that we call.

21.1: For the choir director. A Davidic psalm. LORD, the king finds joy in Your strength. How greatly he rejoices in Your victory!
21.2: You have given him his heart’s desire and have not denied the request of his lips. Selah
21.3: For You meet him with rich blessings; You place a crown of pure gold on his head.
21.4: He asked You for life, and You gave it to him— length of days forever and ever.
21.5: His glory is great through Your victory; You confer majesty and splendor on him.
21.6: You give him blessings forever; You cheer him with joy in Your presence.
21.7: For the king relies on the LORD; through the faithful love of the Most High he is not shaken.
21.8: Your hand will capture all your enemies; your right hand will seize those who hate you.
21.9: You will make them burn like a fiery furnace when you appear; the LORD will engulf them in His wrath, and fire will devour them.
21.10: You will wipe their descendants from the earth and their offspring from the human race.
21.11: Though they intend to harm you and devise a wicked plan, they will not prevail.
21.12: Instead, you will put them to flight when you aim your bow at their faces.
21.13: Be exalted, LORD, in Your strength; we will sing and praise Your might.

22.1: For the choir director: according to “The Deer of the Dawn.” A Davidic psalm. My God, my God, why have You forsaken me? Why are You so far from my deliverance and from my words of groaning?
22.2: My God, I cry by day, but You do not answer, by night, yet I have no rest.
22.3: But You are holy, enthroned on the praises of Israel.
22.4: Our fathers trusted in You; they trusted, and You rescued them.
22.5: They cried to You and were set free; they trusted in You and were not disgraced.
22.6: But I am a worm and not a man, scorned by men and despised by people.
22.7: Everyone who sees me mocks me; they sneer and shake their heads:”
22.8: He relies on the LORD; let Him rescue him; let the LORD deliver him, since He takes pleasure in him.”
22.9: You took me from the womb, making me secure while at my mother’s breast.
22.10: I was given over to You at birth; You have been my God from my mother’s womb.
22.11: Do not be far from me, because distress is near and there is no one to help.
22.12: Many bulls surround me; strong ones of Bashan encircle me.
22.13: They open their mouths against me— lions, mauling and roaring.
22.14: I am poured out like water, and all my bones are disjointed; my heart is like wax, melting within me.
22.15: My strength is dried up like baked clay; my tongue sticks to the roof of my mouth. You put me into the dust of death.
22.16: For dogs have surrounded me; a gang of evildoers has closed in on me; they pierced my hands and my feet.
22.17: I can count all my bones; people look and stare at me.
22.18: They divided my garments among themselves, and they cast lots for my clothing.
22.19: But You, LORD, don’t be far away. My strength, come quickly to help me.
22.20: Deliver my life from the sword, my only life from the power of these dogs.
22.21: Save me from the mouth of the lion! You have rescued me from the horns of the wild oxen.
22.22: I will proclaim Your name to my brothers; I will praise You in the congregation.
22.23: You who fear Yahweh, praise Him! All you descendants of Jacob, honor Him! All you descendants of Israel, revere Him!
22.24: For He has not despised or detested the torment of the afflicted. He did not hide His face from him but listened when he cried to Him for help.
22.25: I will give praise in the great congregation because of You; I will fulfill my vows before those who fear You.
22.26: The humble will eat and be satisfied; those who seek the LORD will praise Him. May your hearts live forever!
22.27: All the ends of the earth will remember and turn to the LORD. All the families of the nations will bow down before You,
22.28: for kingship belongs to the LORD; He rules over the nations.
22.29: All who prosper on earth will eat and bow down; all those who go down to the dust will kneel before Him— even the one who cannot preserve his life.
22.30: Their descendants will serve Him; the next generation will be told about the Lord.
22.31: They will come and tell a people yet to be born about His righteousness— what He has done.

23.1: A Davidic psalm. The LORD is my shepherd; there is nothing I lack.
23.2: He lets me lie down in green pastures; He leads me beside quiet waters.
23.3: He renews my life; He leads me along the right paths for His name’s sake.
23.4: Even when I go through the darkest valley, I fear no danger, for You are with me; Your rod and Your staff—they comfort me.
23.5: You prepare a table before me in the presence of my enemies; You anoint my head with oil; my cup overflows.
23.6: Only goodness and faithful love will pursue me all the days of my life, and I will dwell in the house of the LORD as long as I live.

24.1: A Davidic psalm. The earth and everything in it, the world and its inhabitants, belong to the LORD;
24.2: for He laid its foundation on the seas and established it on the rivers.
24.3: Who may ascend the mountain of the LORD? Who may stand in His holy place?
24.4: The one who has clean hands and a pure heart, who has not set his mind on what is false, and who has not sworn deceitfully.
24.5: He will receive blessing from the LORD, and righteousness from the God of his salvation.
24.6: Such is the generation of those who seek Him, who seek the face of the God of Jacob. Selah
24.7: Lift up your heads, you gates! Rise up, ancient doors! Then the King of glory will come in.
24.8: Who is this King of glory? The LORD, strong and mighty, the LORD, mighty in battle.
24.9: Lift up your heads, you gates! Rise up, ancient doors! Then the King of glory will come in.
24.10: Who is He, this King of glory? The LORD of Hosts, He is the King of glory. Selah

25.1: Davidic. LORD, I turn to You.
25.2: My God, I trust in You. Do not let me be disgraced; do not let my enemies gloat over me.
25.3: No one who waits for You will be disgraced; those who act treacherously without cause will be disgraced.
25.4: Make Your ways known to me, LORD; teach me Your paths.
25.5: Guide me in Your truth and teach me, for You are the God of my salvation; I wait for You all day long.
25.6: Remember, LORD, Your compassion and Your faithful love, for they have existed from antiquity.
25.7: Do not remember the sins of my youth or my acts of rebellion; in keeping with Your faithful love, remember me because of Your goodness, LORD.
25.8: The LORD is good and upright; therefore He shows sinners the way.
25.9: He leads the humble in what is right and teaches them His way.
25.10: All the LORD’s ways show faithful love and truth to those who keep His covenant and decrees.
25.11: Because of Your name, Yahweh, forgive my sin, for it is great.
25.12: Who is the man who fears the LORD? He will show him the way he should choose.
25.13: He will live a good life, and his descendants will inherit the land.
25.14: The secret counsel of the LORD is for those who fear Him, and He reveals His covenant to them.
25.15: My eyes are always on the LORD, for He will pull my feet out of the net.
25.16: Turn to me and be gracious to me, for I am alone and afflicted.
25.17: The distresses of my heart increase; bring me out of my sufferings.
25.18: Consider my affliction and trouble, and take away all my sins.
25.19: Consider my enemies; they are numerous, and they hate me violently.
25.20: Guard me and deliver me; do not let me be put to shame, for I take refuge in You.
25.21: May integrity and what is right watch over me, for I wait for You.
25.22: God, redeem Israel, from all its distresses.

26.1: Davidic. Vindicate me, LORD, because I have lived with integrity and have trusted in the LORD without wavering.
26.2: Test me, LORD, and try me; examine my heart and mind.
26.3: For Your faithful love is before my eyes, and I live by Your truth.
26.4: I do not sit with the worthless or associate with hypocrites.
26.5: I hate a crowd of evildoers, and I do not sit with the wicked.
26.6: I wash my hands in innocence and go around Your altar, LORD,
26.7: raising my voice in thanksgiving and telling about Your wonderful works.
26.8: LORD, I love the house where You dwell, the place where Your glory resides.
26.9: Do not destroy me along with sinners, or my life along with men of bloodshed
26.10: in whose hands are evil schemes and whose right hands are filled with bribes.
26.11: But I live with integrity; redeem me and be gracious to me.
26.12: My foot stands on level ground; I will praise the LORD in the assemblies.

27.1: Davidic. The LORD is my light and my salvation— whom should I fear? The LORD is the stronghold of my life— of whom should I be afraid?
27.2: When evildoers came against me to devour my flesh, my foes and my enemies stumbled and fell.
27.3: Though an army deploys against me, my heart is not afraid; though a war breaks out against me, still I am confident.
27.4: I have asked one thing from the LORD; it is what I desire: to dwell in the house of the LORD all the days of my life, gazing on the beauty of the LORD and seeking Him in His temple.
27.5: For He will conceal me in His shelter in the day of adversity; He will hide me under the cover of His tent; He will set me high on a rock.
27.6: Then my head will be high above my enemies around me; I will offer sacrifices in His tent with shouts of joy. I will sing and make music to the LORD.
27.7: LORD, hear my voice when I call; be gracious to me and answer me.
27.8: My heart says this about You,” You are to seek My face.” LORD, I will seek Your face.
27.9: Do not hide Your face from me; do not turn Your servant away in anger. You have been my helper; do not leave me or abandon me, God of my salvation.
27.10: Even if my father and mother abandon me, the LORD cares for me.
27.11: Because of my adversaries, show me Your way, LORD, and lead me on a level path.
27.12: Do not give me over to the will of my foes, for false witnesses rise up against me, breathing violence.
27.13: I am certain that I will see the LORD’s goodness in the land of the living.
27.14: Wait for the LORD; be strong and courageous. Wait for the LORD.

28.1: Davidic. LORD, I call to You; my rock, do not be deaf to me. If You remain silent to me, I will be like those going down to the Pit.
28.2: Listen to the sound of my pleading when I cry to You for help, when I lift up my hands toward Your holy sanctuary.
28.3: Do not drag me away with the wicked, with the evildoers, who speak in friendly ways with their neighbors while malice is in their hearts.
28.4: Repay them according to what they have done— according to the evil of their deeds. Repay them according to the work of their hands; give them back what they deserve.
28.5: Because they do not consider what the LORD has done or the work of His hands, He will tear them down and not rebuild them.
28.6: May the LORD be praised, for He has heard the sound of my pleading.
28.7: The LORD is my strength and my shield; my heart trusts in Him, and I am helped. Therefore my heart rejoices, and I praise Him with my song.
28.8: The LORD is the strength of His people; He is a stronghold of salvation for His anointed.
28.9: Save Your people, bless Your possession, shepherd them, and carry them forever.

29.1: A Davidic psalm. Ascribe to Yahweh, you heavenly beings, ascribe to the LORD glory and strength.
29.2: Ascribe to Yahweh the glory due His name; worship Yahweh in the splendor of His holiness.
29.3: The voice of the LORD is above the waters. The God of glory thunders— the LORD, above vast waters,
29.4: the voice of the LORD in power, the voice of the LORD in splendor.
29.5: The voice of the LORD breaks the cedars; the LORD shatters the cedars of Lebanon.
29.6: He makes Lebanon skip like a calf, and Sirion, like a young wild ox.
29.7: The voice of the LORD flashes flames of fire.
29.8: The voice of the LORD shakes the wilderness; the LORD shakes the wilderness of Kadesh.
29.9: The voice of the LORD makes the deer give birth and strips the woodlands bare. In His temple all cry, “Glory!”
29.10: The LORD sat enthroned at the flood; the LORD sits enthroned, King forever.
29.11: The LORD gives His people strength; the LORD blesses His people with peace.

30.1: A psalm; a dedication song for the house. Davidic. I will exalt You, LORD, because You have lifted me up and have not allowed my enemies to triumph over me.
30.2: LORD my God, I cried to You for help, and You healed me.
30.3: LORD, You brought me up from Sheol; You spared me from among those going down to the Pit.
30.4: Sing to Yahweh, you His faithful ones, and praise His holy name.
30.5: For His anger lasts only a moment, but His favor, a lifetime. Weeping may spend the night, but there is joy in the morning.
30.6: When I was secure, I said,” I will never be shaken.”
30.7: LORD, when You showed Your favor, You made me stand like a strong mountain; when You hid Your face, I was terrified.
30.8: LORD, I called to You; I sought favor from my Lord:”
30.9: What gain is there in my death, if I go down to the Pit? Will the dust praise You? Will it proclaim Your truth?
30.10: LORD, listen and be gracious to me; LORD, be my helper.”
30.11: You turned my lament into dancing; You removed my sackcloth and clothed me with gladness,
30.12: so that I can sing to You and not be silent. LORD my God, I will praise You forever.

31.1: For the choir director. A Davidic psalm. LORD, I seek refuge in You; let me never be disgraced. Save me by Your righteousness.
31.2: Listen closely to me; rescue me quickly. Be a rock of refuge for me, a mountain fortress to save me.
31.3: For You are my rock and my fortress; You lead and guide me because of Your name.
31.4: You will free me from the net that is secretly set for me, for You are my refuge.
31.5: Into Your hand I entrust my spirit; You redeem me, LORD, God of truth.
31.6: I hate those who are devoted to worthless idols, but I trust in the LORD.
31.7: I will rejoice and be glad in Your faithful love because You have seen my affliction. You have known the troubles of my life
31.8: and have not handed me over to the enemy. You have set my feet in a spacious place.
31.9: Be gracious to me, LORD, because I am in distress; my eyes are worn out from angry sorrow— my whole being as well.
31.10: Indeed, my life is consumed with grief and my years with groaning; my strength has failed because of my sinfulness, and my bones waste away.
31.11: I am ridiculed by all my adversaries and even by my neighbors. I am dreaded by my acquaintances; those who see me in the street run from me.
31.12: I am forgotten: gone from memory like a dead person—like broken pottery.
31.13: I have heard the gossip of many; terror is on every side. When they conspired against me, they plotted to take my life.
31.14: But I trust in You, LORD; I say, “You are my God.”
31.15: The course of my life is in Your power; deliver me from the power of my enemies and from my persecutors.
31.16: Show Your favor to Your servant; save me by Your faithful love.
31.17: LORD, do not let me be disgraced when I call on You. Let the wicked be disgraced; let them be silent in Sheol.
31.18: Let lying lips be quieted; they speak arrogantly against the righteous with pride and contempt.
31.19: How great is Your goodness that You have stored up for those who fear You and accomplished in the sight of everyone for those who take refuge in You.
31.20: You hide them in the protection of Your presence; You conceal them in a shelter from the schemes of men, from quarrelsome tongues.
31.21: May the LORD be praised, for He has wonderfully shown His faithful love to me in a city under siege.
31.22: In my alarm I had said,” I am cut off from Your sight.” But You heard the sound of my pleading when I cried to You for help.
31.23: Love the LORD, all His faithful ones. The LORD protects the loyal, but fully repays the arrogant.
31.24: Be strong and courageous, all you who put your hope in the LORD.

32.1: Davidic. A Maskil. How joyful is the one whose transgression is forgiven, whose sin is covered!
32.2: How joyful is the man the LORD does not charge with sin and in whose spirit is no deceit!
32.3: When I kept silent, my bones became brittle from my groaning all day long.
32.4: For day and night Your hand was heavy on me; my strength was drained as in the summer’s heat. Selah
32.5: Then I acknowledged my sin to You and did not conceal my iniquity. I said,” I will confess my transgressions to the LORD,” and You took away the guilt of my sin. Selah
32.6: Therefore let everyone who is faithful pray to You at a time that You may be found. When great floodwaters come, they will not reach him.
32.7: You are my hiding place; You protect me from trouble. You surround me with joyful shouts of deliverance. Selah
32.8: I will instruct you and show you the way to go; with My eye on you, I will give counsel.
32.9: Do not be like a horse or mule, without understanding, that must be controlled with bit and bridle or else it will not come near you.
32.10: Many pains come to the wicked, but the one who trusts in the LORD will have faithful love surrounding him.
32.11: Be glad in the LORD and rejoice, you righteous ones; shout for joy, all you upright in heart.

33.1: Rejoice in the LORD, you righteous ones; praise from the upright is beautiful.
33.2: Praise the LORD with the lyre; make music to Him with a ten-stringed harp.
33.3: Sing a new song to Him; play skillfully on the strings, with a joyful shout.
33.4: For the word of the LORD is right, and all His work is trustworthy.
33.5: He loves righteousness and justice; the earth is full of the LORD’s unfailing love.
33.6: The heavens were made by the word of the LORD, and all the stars, by the breath of His mouth.
33.7: He gathers the waters of the sea into a heap; He puts the depths into storehouses.
33.8: Let the whole earth tremble before the LORD; let all the inhabitants of the world stand in awe of Him.
33.9: For He spoke, and it came into being; He commanded, and it came into existence.
33.10: The LORD frustrates the counsel of the nations; He thwarts the plans of the peoples.
33.11: The counsel of the LORD stands forever, the plans of His heart from generation to generation.
33.12: Happy is the nation whose God is Yahweh— the people He has chosen to be His own possession!
33.13: The LORD looks down from heaven; He observes everyone.
33.14: He gazes on all the inhabitants of the earth from His dwelling place.
33.15: He alone shapes their hearts; He considers all their works.
33.16: A king is not saved by a large army; a warrior will not be delivered by great strength.
33.17: The horse is a false hope for safety; it provides no escape by its great power.
33.18: Now the eye of the LORD is on those who fear Him— those who depend on His faithful love
33.19: to deliver them from death and to keep them alive in famine.
33.20: We wait for Yahweh; He is our help and shield.
33.21: For our hearts rejoice in Him because we trust in His holy name.
33.22: May Your faithful love rest on us, Yahweh, for we put our hope in You.

34.1: Concerning David, when he pretended to be insane in the presence of Abimelech, who drove him out, and he departed. I will praise the LORD at all times; His praise will always be on my lips.
34.2: I will boast in the LORD; the humble will hear and be glad.
34.3: Proclaim Yahweh’s greatness with me; let us exalt His name together.
34.4: I sought the LORD, and He answered me and delivered me from all my fears.
34.5: Those who look to Him are radiant with joy; their faces will never be ashamed.
34.6: This poor man cried, and the LORD heard him and saved him from all his troubles.
34.7: The Angel of the LORD encamps around those who fear Him, and rescues them.
34.8: Taste and see that the LORD is good. How happy is the man who takes refuge in Him!
34.9: You who are His holy ones, fear Yahweh, for those who fear Him lack nothing.
34.10: Young lions lack food and go hungry, but those who seek the LORD will not lack any good thing.
34.11: Come, children, listen to me; I will teach you the fear of the LORD.
34.12: Who is the man who delights in life, loving a long life to enjoy what is good?
34.13: Keep your tongue from evil and your lips from deceitful speech.
34.14: Turn away from evil and do what is good; seek peace and pursue it.
34.15: The eyes of the LORD are on the righteous, and His ears are open to their cry for help.
34.16: The face of the LORD is set against those who do what is evil, to erase all memory of them from the earth.
34.17: The righteous cry out, and the LORD hears, and delivers them from all their troubles.
34.18: The LORD is near the brokenhearted; He saves those crushed in spirit.
34.19: Many adversities come to the one who is righteous, but the LORD delivers him from them all.
34.20: He protects all his bones; not one of them is broken.
34.21: Evil brings death to the wicked, and those who hate the righteous will be punished.
34.22: The LORD redeems the life of His servants, and all who take refuge in Him will not be punished.

35.1: Davidic. Oppose my opponents, LORD; fight those who fight me.
35.2: Take Your shields—large and small— and come to my aid.
35.3: Draw the spear and javelin against my pursuers, and assure me: “I am your deliverance.”
35.4: Let those who seek to kill me be disgraced and humiliated; let those who plan to harm me be turned back and ashamed.
35.5: Let them be like chaff in the wind, with the angel of the LORD driving them away.
35.6: Let their way be dark and slippery, with the angel of the LORD pursuing them.
35.7: They hid their net for me without cause; they dug a pit for me without cause.
35.8: Let ruin come on him unexpectedly, and let the net that he hid ensnare him; let him fall into it—to his ruin.
35.9: Then I will rejoice in the LORD; I will delight in His deliverance.
35.10: My very bones will say,” LORD, who is like You, rescuing the poor from one too strong for him, the poor or the needy from one who robs him?”
35.11: Malicious witnesses come forward; they question me about things I do not know.
35.12: They repay me evil for good, making me desolate.
35.13: Yet when they were sick, my clothing was sackcloth; I humbled myself with fasting, and my prayer was genuine.
35.14: I went about grieving as if for my friend or brother; I was bowed down with grief, like one mourning a mother.
35.15: But when I stumbled, they gathered in glee; they gathered against me. Assailants I did not know tore at me and did not stop.
35.16: With godless mockery they gnashed their teeth at me.
35.17: Lord, how long will You look on? Rescue my life from their ravages, my only one from the young lions.
35.18: I will praise You in the great congregation; I will exalt You among many people.
35.19: Do not let my deceitful enemies rejoice over me; do not let those who hate me without cause look at me maliciously.
35.20: For they do not speak in friendly ways, but contrive deceitful schemes against those who live peacefully in the land.
35.21: They open their mouths wide against me and say,” Aha, aha! We saw it!”
35.22: You saw it, LORD; do not be silent. Lord, do not be far from me.
35.23: Wake up and rise to my defense, to my cause, my God and my LORD!
35.24: Vindicate me, LORD my God, in keeping with Your righteousness, and do not let them rejoice over me.
35.25: Do not let them say in their hearts,” Aha! Just what we wanted.” Do not let them say,” We have swallowed him up!”
35.26: Let those who rejoice at my misfortune be disgraced and humiliated; let those who exalt themselves over me be clothed with shame and reproach.
35.27: Let those who want my vindication shout for joy and be glad; let them continually say,” The LORD be exalted. He takes pleasure in His servant’s well-being.”
35.28: And my tongue will proclaim Your righteousness, Your praise all day long.

36.1: For the choir director. A psalm of David, the LORD’s servant. An oracle within my heart concerning the transgression of the wicked person: There is no dread of God before his eyes,
36.2: for in his own eyes he flatters himself too much to discover and hate his sin.
36.3: The words of his mouth are malicious and deceptive; he has stopped acting wisely and doing good.
36.4: Even on his bed he makes malicious plans. He sets himself on a path that is not good and does not reject evil.
36.5: LORD, Your faithful love reaches to heaven, Your faithfulness to the clouds.
36.6: Your righteousness is like the highest mountains; Your judgments, like the deepest sea. LORD, You preserve man and beast.
36.7: God, Your faithful love is so valuable that people take refuge in the shadow of Your wings.
36.8: They are filled from the abundance of Your house; You let them drink from Your refreshing stream,
36.9: for with You is life’s fountain. In Your light we will see light.
36.10: Spread Your faithful love over those who know You, and Your righteousness over the upright in heart.
36.11: Do not let the foot of the arrogant man come near me or the hand of the wicked one drive me away.
36.12: There the evildoers fall; they have been thrown down and cannot rise.

37.1: Davidic. Do not be agitated by evildoers; do not envy those who do wrong.
37.2: For they wither quickly like grass and wilt like tender green plants.
37.3: Trust in the LORD and do what is good; dwell in the land and live securely.
37.4: Take delight in the LORD, and He will give you your heart’s desires.
37.5: Commit your way to the LORD; trust in Him, and He will act,
37.6: making your righteousness shine like the dawn, your justice like the noonday.
37.7: Be silent before the LORD and wait expectantly for Him; do not be agitated by one who prospers in his way, by the man who carries out evil plans.
37.8: Refrain from anger and give up your rage; do not be agitated—it can only bring harm.
