37.9: For evildoers will be destroyed, but those who put their hope in the LORD will inherit the land.
37.10: A little while, and the wicked person will be no more; though you look for him, he will not be there.
37.11: But the humble will inherit the land and will enjoy abundant prosperity.
37.12: The wicked person schemes against the righteous and gnashes his teeth at him.
37.13: The Lord laughs at him because He sees that his day is coming.
37.14: The wicked have drawn the sword and strung the bow to bring down the afflicted and needy and to slaughter those whose way is upright.
37.15: Their swords will enter their own hearts, and their bows will be broken.
37.16: The little that the righteous man has is better than the abundance of many wicked people.
37.17: For the arms of the wicked will be broken, but the LORD supports the righteous.
37.18: The LORD watches over the blameless all their days, and their inheritance will last forever.
37.19: They will not be disgraced in times of adversity; they will be satisfied in days of hunger.
37.20: But the wicked will perish; the LORD’s enemies, like the glory of the pastures, will fade away— they will fade away like smoke.
37.21: The wicked man borrows and does not repay, but the righteous one is gracious and giving.
37.22: Those who are blessed by Him will inherit the land, but those cursed by Him will be destroyed.
37.23: A man’s steps are established by the LORD, and He takes pleasure in his way.
37.24: Though he falls, he will not be overwhelmed, because the LORD holds his hand.
37.25: I have been young and now I am old, yet I have not seen the righteous abandoned or his children begging for bread.
37.26: He is always generous, always lending, and his children are a blessing.
37.27: Turn away from evil and do what is good, and dwell there forever.
37.28: For the LORD loves justice and will not abandon His faithful ones. They are kept safe forever, but the children of the wicked will be destroyed.
37.29: The righteous will inherit the land and dwell in it permanently.
37.30: The mouth of the righteous utters wisdom; his tongue speaks what is just.
37.31: The instruction of his God is in his heart; his steps do not falter.
37.32: The wicked one lies in wait for the righteous and seeks to kill him;
37.33: the LORD will not leave him in the power of the wicked one or allow him to be condemned when he is judged.
37.34: Wait for the LORD and keep His way, and He will exalt you to inherit the land. You will watch when the wicked are destroyed.
37.35: I have seen a wicked, violent man well-rooted like a flourishing native tree.
37.36: Then I passed by and noticed he was gone; I searched for him, but he could not be found.
37.37: Watch the blameless and observe the upright, for the man of peace will have a future.
37.38: But transgressors will all be eliminated; the future of the wicked will be destroyed.
37.39: The salvation of the righteous is from the LORD, their refuge in a time of distress.
37.40: The LORD helps and delivers them; He will deliver them from the wicked and will save them because they take refuge in Him.

38.1: A Davidic psalm for remembrance. LORD, do not punish me in Your anger or discipline me in Your wrath.
38.2: For Your arrows have sunk into me, and Your hand has pressed down on me.
38.3: There is no health in my body because of Your indignation; there is no strength in my bones because of my sin.
38.4: For my sins have flooded over my head; they are a burden too heavy for me to bear.
38.5: My wounds are foul and festering because of my foolishness.
38.6: I am bent over and brought low; all day long I go around in mourning.
38.7: For my loins are full of burning pain, and there is no health in my body.
38.8: I am faint and severely crushed; I groan because of the anguish of my heart.
38.9: Lord, my every desire is known to You; my sighing is not hidden from You.
38.10: My heart races, my strength leaves me, and even the light of my eyes has faded.
38.11: My loved ones and friends stand back from my affliction, and my relatives stand at a distance.
38.12: Those who seek my life set traps, and those who want to harm me threaten to destroy me; they plot treachery all day long.
38.13: I am like a deaf person; I do not hear. I am like a speechless person who does not open his mouth.
38.14: I am like a man who does not hear and has no arguments in his mouth.
38.15: I put my hope in You, LORD; You will answer, Lord my God.
38.16: For I said, “Don’t let them rejoice over me— those who are arrogant toward me when I stumble.”
38.17: For I am about to fall, and my pain is constantly with me.
38.18: So I confess my guilt; I am anxious because of my sin.
38.19: But my enemies are vigorous and powerful; many hate me for no reason.
38.20: Those who repay evil for good attack me for pursuing good.
38.21: LORD, do not abandon me; my God, do not be far from me.
38.22: Hurry to help me, Lord, my Savior.

39.1: For the choir director, for Jeduthun. A Davidic psalm. I said, “I will guard my ways so that I may not sin with my tongue; I will guard my mouth with a muzzle as long as the wicked are in my presence.”
39.2: I was speechless and quiet; I kept silent, even from speaking good, and my pain intensified.
39.3: My heart grew hot within me; as I mused, a fire burned. I spoke with my tongue:”
39.4: LORD, reveal to me the end of my life and the number of my days. Let me know how short-lived I am.
39.5: You, indeed, have made my days short in length, and my life span as nothing in Your sight. Yes, every mortal man is only a vapor. Selah “
39.6: Certainly, man walks about like a mere shadow. Indeed, they frantically rush around in vain, gathering possessions without knowing who will get them.
39.7: Now, Lord, what do I wait for? My hope is in You.
39.8: Deliver me from all my transgressions; do not make me the taunt of fools.
39.9: I am speechless; I do not open my mouth because of what You have done.
39.10: Remove Your torment from me; I fade away because of the force of Your hand.
39.11: You discipline a man with punishment for sin, consuming like a moth what is precious to him; every man is only a vapor. Selah “
39.12: Hear my prayer, LORD, and listen to my cry for help; do not be silent at my tears. For I am a foreigner residing with You, a temporary resident like all my fathers.
39.13: Turn Your angry gaze from me so that I may be cheered up before I die and am gone.”

40.1: For the choir director. A Davidic psalm. I waited patiently for the LORD, and He turned to me and heard my cry for help.
40.2: He brought me up from a desolate pit, out of the muddy clay, and set my feet on a rock, making my steps secure.
40.3: He put a new song in my mouth, a hymn of praise to our God. Many will see and fear and put their trust in the LORD.
40.4: How happy is the man who has put his trust in the LORD and has not turned to the proud or to those who run after lies!
40.5: LORD my God, You have done many things— Your wonderful works and Your plans for us; none can compare with You. If I were to report and speak of them, they are more than can be told.
40.6: You do not delight in sacrifice and offering; You open my ears to listen. You do not ask for a whole burnt offering or a sin offering.
40.7: Then I said, “See, I have come; it is written about me in the volume of the scroll.
40.8: I delight to do Your will, my God; Your instruction lives within me.”
40.9: I proclaim righteousness in the great assembly; see, I do not keep my mouth closed— as You know, LORD.
40.10: I did not hide Your righteousness in my heart; I spoke about Your faithfulness and salvation; I did not conceal Your constant love and truth from the great assembly.
40.11: LORD, do not withhold Your compassion from me; Your constant love and truth will always guard me.
40.12: For troubles without number have surrounded me; my sins have overtaken me; I am unable to see. They are more than the hairs of my head, and my courage leaves me.
40.13: LORD, be pleased to deliver me; hurry to help me, LORD.
40.14: Let those who seek to take my life be disgraced and confounded. Let those who wish me harm be driven back and humiliated.
40.15: Let those who say to me, “Aha, aha!” be horrified because of their shame.
40.16: Let all who seek You rejoice and be glad in You; let those who love Your salvation continually say,” The LORD is great!”
40.17: I am afflicted and needy; the Lord thinks of me. You are my helper and my deliverer; my God, do not delay.

41.1: For the choir director. A Davidic psalm. Happy is one who cares for the poor; the LORD will save him in a day of adversity.
41.2: The LORD will keep him and preserve him; he will be blessed in the land. You will not give him over to the desire of his enemies.
41.3: The LORD will sustain him on his sickbed; You will heal him on the bed where he lies.
41.4: I said, “ LORD, be gracious to me; heal me, for I have sinned against You.”
41.5: My enemies speak maliciously about me:” When will he die and be forgotten?”
41.6: When one of them comes to visit, he speaks deceitfully; he stores up evil in his heart; he goes out and talks.
41.7: All who hate me whisper together about me; they plan to harm me.”
41.8: Lethal poison has been poured into him, and he won’t rise again from where he lies!”
41.9: Even my friend in whom I trusted, one who ate my bread, has raised his heel against me.
41.10: But You, LORD, be gracious to me and raise me up; then I will repay them.
41.11: By this I know that You delight in me: my enemy does not shout in triumph over me.
41.12: You supported me because of my integrity and set me in Your presence forever.
41.13: May Yahweh, the God of Israel, be praised from everlasting to everlasting. Amen and amen.

42.1: For the choir director. A Maskil of the sons of Korah. As a deer longs for streams of water, so I long for You, God.
42.2: I thirst for God, the living God. When can I come and appear before God?
42.3: My tears have been my food day and night, while all day long people say to me,” Where is your God?”
42.4: I remember this as I pour out my heart: how I walked with many, leading the festive procession to the house of God, with joyful and thankful shouts.
42.5: Why am I so depressed? Why this turmoil within me? Put your hope in God, for I will still praise Him, my Savior and my God.
42.6: I am deeply depressed; therefore I remember You from the land of Jordan and the peaks of Hermon, from Mount Mizar.
42.7: Deep calls to deep in the roar of Your waterfalls; all Your breakers and Your billows have swept over me.
42.8: The LORD will send His faithful love by day; His song will be with me in the night— a prayer to the God of my life.
42.9: I will say to God, my rock,” Why have You forgotten me? Why must I go about in sorrow because of the enemy’s oppression?”
42.10: My adversaries taunt me, as if crushing my bones, while all day long they say to me,” Where is your God?”
42.11: Why am I so depressed? Why this turmoil within me? Put your hope in God, for I will still praise Him, my Savior and my God.

43.1: Vindicate me, God, and defend my cause against an ungodly nation; rescue me from the deceitful and unjust man.
43.2: For You are the God of my refuge. Why have You rejected me? Why must I go about in sorrow because of the enemy’s oppression?
43.3: Send Your light and Your truth; let them lead me. Let them bring me to Your holy mountain, to Your dwelling place.
43.4: Then I will come to the altar of God, to God, my greatest joy. I will praise You with the lyre, God, my God.
43.5: Why am I so depressed? Why this turmoil within me? Put your hope in God, for I will still praise Him, my Savior and my God.

44.1: For the choir director. A Maskil of the sons of Korah. God, we have heard with our ears— our ancestors have told us— the work You accomplished in their days, in days long ago:
44.2: to plant them, You drove out the nations with Your hand; to settle them, You crushed the peoples.
44.3: For they did not take the land by their sword— their arm did not bring them victory— but by Your right hand, Your arm, and the light of Your face, for You were pleased with them.
44.4: You are my King, my God, who ordains victories for Jacob.
44.5: Through You we drive back our foes; through Your name we trample our enemies.
44.6: For I do not trust in my bow, and my sword does not bring me victory.
44.7: But You give us victory over our foes and let those who hate us be disgraced.
44.8: We boast in God all day long; we will praise Your name forever. Selah
44.9: But You have rejected and humiliated us; You do not march out with our armies.
44.10: You make us retreat from the foe, and those who hate us have taken plunder for themselves.
44.11: You hand us over to be eaten like sheep and scatter us among the nations.
44.12: You sell Your people for nothing; You make no profit from selling them.
44.13: You make us an object of reproach to our neighbors, a source of mockery and ridicule to those around us.
44.14: You make us a joke among the nations, a laughingstock among the peoples.
44.15: My disgrace is before me all day long, and shame has covered my face,
44.16: because of the voice of the scorner and reviler, because of the enemy and avenger.
44.17: All this has happened to us, but we have not forgotten You or betrayed Your covenant.
44.18: Our hearts have not turned back; our steps have not strayed from Your path.
44.19: But You have crushed us in a haunt of jackals and have covered us with deepest darkness.
44.20: If we had forgotten the name of our God and spread out our hands to a foreign god,
44.21: wouldn’t God have found this out, since He knows the secrets of the heart?
44.22: Because of You we are slain all day long; we are counted as sheep to be slaughtered.
44.23: Wake up, LORD! Why are You sleeping? Get up! Don’t reject us forever!
44.24: Why do You hide Yourself and forget our affliction and oppression?
44.25: For we have sunk down to the dust; our bodies cling to the ground.
44.26: Rise up! Help us! Redeem us because of Your faithful love.

45.1: For the choir director: according to “The Lilies.” A Maskil of the sons of Korah. A love song. My heart is moved by a noble theme as I recite my verses to the king; my tongue is the pen of a skillful writer.
45.2: You are the most handsome of men; grace flows from your lips. Therefore God has blessed you forever.
45.3: Mighty warrior, strap your sword at your side. In your majesty and splendor—
45.4: in your splendor ride triumphantly in the cause of truth, humility, and justice. May your right hand show your awe-inspiring acts.
45.5: Your arrows pierce the hearts of the king’s enemies; the peoples fall under you.
45.6: Your throne, God, is forever and ever; the scepter of Your kingdom is a scepter of justice.
45.7: You love righteousness and hate wickedness; therefore God, your God, has anointed you with the oil of joy more than your companions.
45.8: Myrrh, aloes, and cassia perfume all your garments; from ivory palaces harps bring you joy.
45.9: Kings’ daughters are among your honored women; the queen, adorned with gold from Ophir, stands at your right hand.
45.10: Listen, daughter, pay attention and consider: forget your people and your father’s house,
45.11: and the king will desire your beauty. Bow down to him, for he is your lord.
45.12: The daughter of Tyre, the wealthy people, will seek your favor with gifts.
45.13: In her chamber, the royal daughter is all glorious, her clothing embroidered with gold.
45.14: In colorful garments she is led to the king; after her, the virgins, her companions, are brought to you.
45.15: They are led in with gladness and rejoicing; they enter the king’s palace.
45.16: Your sons will succeed your ancestors; you will make them princes throughout the land.
45.17: I will cause your name to be remembered for all generations; therefore the peoples will praise you forever and ever.

46.1: For the choir director. A song of the sons of Korah. According to Alamoth. God is our refuge and strength, a helper who is always found in times of trouble.
46.2: Therefore we will not be afraid, though the earth trembles and the mountains topple into the depths of the seas,
46.3: though its waters roar and foam and the mountains quake with its turmoil. Selah
46.4: There is a river— its streams delight the city of God, the holy dwelling place of the Most High.
46.5: God is within her; she will not be toppled. God will help her when the morning dawns.
46.6: Nations rage, kingdoms topple; the earth melts when He lifts His voice.
46.7: The LORD of Hosts is with us; the God of Jacob is our stronghold. Selah
46.8: Come, see the works of the LORD, who brings devastation on the earth.
46.9: He makes wars cease throughout the earth. He shatters bows and cuts spears to pieces; He burns up the chariots.”
46.10: Stop your fighting—and know that I am God, exalted among the nations, exalted on the earth.”
46.11: Yahweh of Hosts is with us; the God of Jacob is our stronghold. Selah

47.1: For the choir director. A psalm of the sons of Korah. Clap your hands, all you peoples; shout to God with a jubilant cry.
47.2: For Yahweh, the Most High, is awe-inspiring, a great King over all the earth.
47.3: He subdues peoples under us and nations under our feet.
47.4: He chooses for us our inheritance— the pride of Jacob, whom He loves. Selah
47.5: God ascends among shouts of joy, the LORD, among the sound of trumpets.
47.6: Sing praise to God, sing praise; sing praise to our King, sing praise!
47.7: Sing a song of wisdom, for God is King of all the earth.
47.8: God reigns over the nations; God is seated on His holy throne.
47.9: The nobles of the peoples have assembled with the people of the God of Abraham. For the leaders of the earth belong to God; He is greatly exalted.

48.1: A song. A psalm of the sons of Korah. The LORD is great and highly praised in the city of our God. His holy mountain,
48.2: rising splendidly, is the joy of the whole earth. Mount Zion on the slopes of the north is the city of the great King.
48.3: God is known as a stronghold in its citadels.
48.4: Look! The kings assembled; they advanced together.
48.5: They looked and froze with fear; they fled in terror.
48.6: Trembling seized them there, agony like that of a woman in labor,
48.7: as You wrecked the ships of Tarshish with the east wind.
48.8: Just as we heard, so we have seen in the city of Yahweh of Hosts, in the city of our God; God will establish it forever. Selah
48.9: God, within Your temple, we contemplate Your faithful love.
48.10: Your name, God, like Your praise, reaches to the ends of the earth; Your right hand is filled with justice.
48.11: Mount Zion is glad. The towns of Judah rejoice because of Your judgments.
48.12: Go around Zion, encircle it; count its towers,
48.13: note its ramparts; tour its citadels so that you can tell a future generation:”
48.14: This God, our God forever and ever— He will always lead us.”

49.1: For the choir director. A psalm of the sons of Korah. Hear this, all you peoples; listen, all who inhabit the world,
49.2: both low and high, rich and poor together.
49.3: My mouth speaks wisdom; my heart’s meditation brings understanding.
49.4: I turn my ear to a proverb; I explain my riddle with a lyre.
49.5: Why should I fear in times of trouble? The iniquity of my foes surrounds me.
49.6: They trust in their wealth and boast of their abundant riches.
49.7: Yet these cannot redeem a person or pay his ransom to God—
49.8: since the price of redeeming him is too costly, one should forever stop trying—
49.9: so that he may live forever and not see the Pit.
49.10: For one can see that wise men die; foolish and stupid men also pass away. Then they leave their wealth to others.
49.11: Their graves are their eternal homes, their homes from generation to generation, though they have named estates after themselves.
49.12: But despite his assets, man will not last; he is like the animals that perish.
49.13: This is the way of those who are arrogant, and of their followers, who approve of their words. Selah
49.14: Like sheep they are headed for Sheol; Death will shepherd them. The upright will rule over them in the morning, and their form will waste away in Sheol, far from their lofty abode.
49.15: But God will redeem my life from the power of Sheol, for He will take me. Selah
49.16: Do not be afraid when a man gets rich, when the wealth of his house increases.
49.17: For when he dies, he will take nothing at all; his wealth will not follow him down.
49.18: Though he praises himself during his lifetime— and people praise you when you do well for yourself—
49.19: he will go to the generation of his fathers; they will never see the light.
49.20: A man with valuable possessions but without understanding is like the animals that perish.

50.1: A psalm of Asaph. Yahweh, the God of gods speaks; He summons the earth from east to west.
50.2: From Zion, the perfection of beauty, God appears in radiance.
50.3: Our God is coming; He will not be silent! Devouring fire precedes Him, and a storm rages around Him.
50.4: On high, He summons heaven and earth in order to judge His people.”
50.5: Gather My faithful ones to Me, those who made a covenant with Me by sacrifice.”
50.6: The heavens proclaim His righteousness, for God is the Judge. Selah “
50.7: Listen, My people, and I will speak; I will testify against you, Israel. I am God, your God.
50.8: I do not rebuke you for your sacrifices or for your burnt offerings, which are continually before Me.
50.9: I will not accept a bull from your household or male goats from your pens,
50.10: for every animal of the forest is Mine, the cattle on a thousand hills.
50.11: I know every bird of the mountains, and the creatures of the field are Mine.
50.12: If I were hungry, I would not tell you, for the world and everything in it is Mine.
50.13: Do I eat the flesh of bulls or drink the blood of goats?
50.14: Sacrifice a thank offering to God, and pay your vows to the Most High.
50.15: Call on Me in a day of trouble; I will rescue you, and you will honor Me.”
50.16: But God says to the wicked:” What right do you have to recite My statutes and to take My covenant on your lips?
50.17: You hate instruction and turn your back on My words.
50.18: When you see a thief, you make friends with him, and you associate with adulterers.
50.19: You unleash your mouth for evil and harness your tongue for deceit.
50.20: You sit, maligning your brother, slandering your mother’s son.
50.21: You have done these things, and I kept silent; you thought I was just like you. But I will rebuke you and lay out the case before you.”
50.22: Understand this, you who forget God, or I will tear you apart, and there will be no one to rescue you.
50.23: Whoever sacrifices a thank offering honors Me, and whoever orders his conduct, I will show him the salvation of God.”

51.1: For the choir director. A Davidic psalm, when Nathan the prophet came to him after he had gone to Bathsheba. Be gracious to me, God, according to Your faithful love; according to Your abundant compassion, blot out my rebellion.
51.2: Wash away my guilt and cleanse me from my sin.
51.3: For I am conscious of my rebellion, and my sin is always before me.
51.4: Against You—You alone—I have sinned and done this evil in Your sight. So You are right when You pass sentence; You are blameless when You judge.
51.5: Indeed, I was guilty when I was born; I was sinful when my mother conceived me.
51.6: Surely You desire integrity in the inner self, and You teach me wisdom deep within.
51.7: Purify me with hyssop, and I will be clean; wash me, and I will be whiter than snow.
51.8: Let me hear joy and gladness; let the bones You have crushed rejoice.
51.9: Turn Your face away from my sins and blot out all my guilt.
51.10: God, create a clean heart for me and renew a steadfast spirit within me.
51.11: Do not banish me from Your presence or take Your Holy Spirit from me.
51.12: Restore the joy of Your salvation to me, and give me a willing spirit.
51.13: Then I will teach the rebellious Your ways, and sinners will return to You.
51.14: Save me from the guilt of bloodshed, God, the God of my salvation, and my tongue will sing of Your righteousness.
51.15: Lord, open my lips, and my mouth will declare Your praise.
51.16: You do not want a sacrifice, or I would give it; You are not pleased with a burnt offering.
51.17: The sacrifice pleasing to God is a broken spirit. God, You will not despise a broken and humbled heart.
51.18: In Your good pleasure, cause Zion to prosper; build the walls of Jerusalem.
51.19: Then You will delight in righteous sacrifices, whole burnt offerings; then bulls will be offered on Your altar.

52.1: For the choir director. A Davidic Maskil. When Doeg the Edomite went and reported to Saul, telling him, “David went to Ahimelech’s house.” Why brag about evil, you hero! God’s faithful love is constant.
52.2: Like a sharpened razor, your tongue devises destruction, working treachery.
52.3: You love evil instead of good, lying instead of speaking truthfully. Selah
52.4: You love any words that destroy, you treacherous tongue!
52.5: This is why God will bring you down forever. He will take you, ripping you out of your tent; He will uproot you from the land of the living. Selah
52.6: The righteous will look on with awe and will ridicule him:”
52.7: Here is the man who would not make God his refuge, but trusted in the abundance of his riches, taking refuge in his destructive behavior.”
52.8: But I am like a flourishing olive tree in the house of God; I trust in God’s faithful love forever and ever.
52.9: I will praise You forever for what You have done. In the presence of Your faithful people, I will put my hope in Your name, for it is good.

53.1: For the choir director: on Mahalath. A Davidic Maskil. The fool says in his heart, “God does not exist.” They are corrupt, and they do vile deeds. There is no one who does good.
53.2: God looks down from heaven on the human race to see if there is one who is wise, one who seeks God.
53.3: All have turned away; all alike have become corrupt. There is no one who does good, not even one.
53.4: Will evildoers never understand? They consume My people as they consume bread; they do not call on God.
53.5: Then they will be filled with terror— terror like no other— because God will scatter the bones of those who besiege you. You will put them to shame, for God has rejected them.
53.6: Oh, that Israel’s deliverance would come from Zion! When God restores the fortunes of His people, Jacob will rejoice; Israel will be glad.

54.1: For the choir director: with stringed instruments. A Davidic Maskil. When the Ziphites went and said to Saul, “Is David not hiding among us?” God, save me by Your name, and vindicate me by Your might!
54.2: God, hear my prayer; listen to the words of my mouth.
54.3: For strangers rise up against me, and violent men seek my life. They have no regard for God. Selah
54.4: God is my helper; the Lord is the sustainer of my life.
54.5: He will repay my adversaries for their evil. Because of Your faithfulness, annihilate them.
54.6: I will sacrifice a freewill offering to You. I will praise Your name, Yahweh, because it is good.
54.7: For He has delivered me from every trouble, and my eye has looked down on my enemies.

55.1: For the choir director: with stringed instruments. A Davidic Maskil. God, listen to my prayer and do not ignore my plea for help.
55.2: Pay attention to me and answer me. I am restless and in turmoil with my complaint,
55.3: because of the enemy’s voice, because of the pressure of the wicked. For they bring down disaster on me and harass me in anger.
55.4: My heart shudders within me; terrors of death sweep over me.
55.5: Fear and trembling grip me; horror has overwhelmed me.
55.6: I said, “If only I had wings like a dove! I would fly away and find rest.
55.7: How far away I would flee; I would stay in the wilderness. Selah
55.8: I would hurry to my shelter from the raging wind and the storm.”
55.9: Lord, confuse and confound their speech, for I see violence and strife in the city;
55.10: day and night they make the rounds on its walls. Crime and trouble are within it;
55.11: destruction is inside it; oppression and deceit never leave its marketplace.
55.12: Now it is not an enemy who insults me— otherwise I could bear it; it is not a foe who rises up against me— otherwise I could hide from him.
55.13: But it is you, a man who is my peer, my companion and good friend!
55.14: We used to have close fellowship; we walked with the crowd into the house of God.
55.15: Let death take them by surprise; let them go down to Sheol alive, because evil is in their homes and within them.
55.16: But I call to God, and the LORD will save me.
55.17: I complain and groan morning, noon, and night, and He hears my voice.
55.18: Though many are against me, He will redeem me from my battle unharmed.
55.19: God, the One enthroned from long ago, will hear and will humiliate them Selah because they do not change and do not fear God.
55.20: My friend acts violently against those at peace with him; he violates his covenant.
55.21: His buttery words are smooth, but war is in his heart. His words are softer than oil, but they are drawn swords.
55.22: Cast your burden on the LORD, and He will sustain you; He will never allow the righteous to be shaken.
55.23: God, You will bring them down to the Pit of destruction; men of bloodshed and treachery will not live out half their days. But I will trust in You.

56.1: For the choir director: according to “A Silent Dove Far Away.” A Davidic Miktam. When the Philistines seized him in Gath. Be gracious to me, God, for man tramples me; he fights and oppresses me all day long.
56.2: My adversaries trample me all day, for many arrogantly fight against me.
56.3: When I am afraid, I will trust in You.
56.4: In God, whose word I praise, in God I trust; I will not fear. What can man do to me?
56.5: They twist my words all day long; all their thoughts against me are evil.
56.6: They stir up strife, they lurk; they watch my steps while they wait to take my life.
56.7: Will they escape in spite of such sin? God, bring down the nations in wrath.
56.8: You Yourself have recorded my wanderings. Put my tears in Your bottle. Are they not in Your records?
56.9: Then my enemies will retreat on the day when I call. This I know: God is for me.
56.10: In God, whose word I praise, in the LORD, whose word I praise,
56.11: in God I trust; I will not fear. What can man do to me?
56.12: I am obligated by vows to You, God; I will make my thank offerings to You.
56.13: For You delivered me from death, even my feet from stumbling, to walk before God in the light of life.

57.1: For the choir director: “Do Not Destroy.” A Davidic Miktam. When he fled before Saul into the cave. Be gracious to me, God, be gracious to me, for I take refuge in You. I will seek refuge in the shadow of Your wings until danger passes.
57.2: I call to God Most High, to God who fulfills His purpose for me.
57.3: He reaches down from heaven and saves me, challenging the one who tramples me. Selah God sends His faithful love and truth.
57.4: I am surrounded by lions; I lie down with those who devour men. Their teeth are spears and arrows; their tongues are sharp swords.
57.5: God, be exalted above the heavens; let Your glory be over the whole earth.
57.6: They prepared a net for my steps; I was despondent. They dug a pit ahead of me, but they fell into it! Selah
57.7: My heart is confident, God, my heart is confident. I will sing; I will sing praises.
57.8: Wake up, my soul! Wake up, harp and lyre! I will wake up the dawn.
57.9: I will praise You, Lord, among the peoples; I will sing praises to You among the nations.
57.10: For Your faithful love is as high as the heavens; Your faithfulness reaches the clouds.
57.11: God, be exalted above the heavens; let Your glory be over the whole earth.

58.1: For the choir director: “Do Not Destroy.” A Davidic Miktam. Do you really speak righteously, you mighty ones? Do you judge people fairly?
58.2: No, you practice injustice in your hearts; with your hands you weigh out violence in the land.
58.3: The wicked go astray from the womb; liars err from birth.
58.4: They have venom like the venom of a snake, like the deaf cobra that stops up its ears,
58.5: that does not listen to the sound of the charmers who skillfully weave spells.
58.6: God, knock the teeth out of their mouths; LORD, tear out the young lions’ fangs.
58.7: They will vanish like water that flows by; they will aim their useless arrows.
58.8: Like a slug that moves along in slime, like a woman’s miscarried child, they will not see the sun.
58.9: Before your pots can feel the heat of the thorns— whether green or burning— He will sweep them away.
58.10: The righteous one will rejoice when he sees the retribution; he will wash his feet in the blood of the wicked.
58.11: Then people will say,” Yes, there is a reward for the righteous! There is a God who judges on earth!”

59.1: For the choir director: “Do Not Destroy.” A Davidic Miktam. When Saul sent agents to watch the house and kill him. Deliver me from my enemies, my God; protect me from those who rise up against me.
59.2: Deliver me from those who practice sin, and save me from men of bloodshed.
59.3: LORD, look! They set an ambush for me. Powerful men attack me, but not because of any sin or rebellion of mine.
59.4: For no fault of mine, they run and take up a position. Awake to help me, and take notice.
59.5: LORD God of Hosts, You are the God of Israel, rise up to punish all the nations; do not show grace to any wicked traitors. Selah
59.6: They return at evening, snarling like dogs and prowling around the city.
59.7: Look, they spew from their mouths— sharp words from their lips.” For who,” they say, “will hear?”
59.8: But You laugh at them, LORD; You ridicule all the nations.
59.9: I will keep watch for You, my strength, because God is my stronghold.
59.10: My faithful God will come to meet me; God will let me look down on my adversaries.
59.11: Do not kill them; otherwise, my people will forget. By Your power, make them homeless wanderers and bring them down, Lord, our shield.
59.12: For the sin of their mouths and the words of their lips, let them be caught in their pride. They utter curses and lies.
59.13: Consume them in rage; consume them until they are gone. Then people will know throughout the earth that God rules over Jacob. Selah
59.14: And they return at evening, snarling like dogs and prowling around the city.
59.15: They scavenge for food; they growl if they are not satisfied.
59.16: But I will sing of Your strength and will joyfully proclaim Your faithful love in the morning. For You have been a stronghold for me, a refuge in my day of trouble.
59.17: To You, my strength, I sing praises, because God is my stronghold— my faithful God.

60.1: For the choir director: according to “The Lily of Testimony.” A Davidic Miktam for teaching. When he fought with Aram-naharaim and Aram-zobah, and Joab returned and struck Edom in the Valley of Salt, killing 12,000. God, You have rejected us; You have broken out against us; You have been angry. Restore us!
60.2: You have shaken the land and split it open. Heal its fissures, for it shudders.
60.3: You have made Your people suffer hardship; You have given us wine to drink that made us stagger.
60.4: You have given a signal flag to those who fear You, so that they can flee before the archers. Selah
60.5: Save with Your right hand, and answer me, so that those You love may be rescued.
60.6: God has spoken in His sanctuary:” I will triumph! I will divide up Shechem. I will apportion the Valley of Succoth.
60.7: Gilead is Mine, Manasseh is Mine, and Ephraim is My helmet; Judah is My scepter.
60.8: Moab is My washbasin. I throw My sandal on Edom; I shout in triumph over Philistia.”
60.9: Who will bring me to the fortified city? Who will lead me to Edom?
60.10: God, haven’t You rejected us? God, You do not march out with our armies.
60.11: Give us aid against the foe, for human help is worthless.
60.12: With God we will perform valiantly; He will trample our foes.

61.1: For the choir director: on stringed instruments. Davidic. God, hear my cry; pay attention to my prayer.
61.2: I call to You from the ends of the earth when my heart is without strength. Lead me to a rock that is high above me,
61.3: for You have been a refuge for me, a strong tower in the face of the enemy.
61.4: I will live in Your tent forever and take refuge under the shelter of Your wings. Selah
61.5: God, You have heard my vows; You have given a heritage to those who fear Your name.
61.6: Add days to the king’s life; may his years span many generations.
61.7: May he sit enthroned before God forever; appoint faithful love and truth to guard him.
61.8: Then I will continually sing of Your name, fulfilling my vows day by day.

62.1: For the choir director: according to Jeduthun. A Davidic psalm. I am at rest in God alone; my salvation comes from Him.
62.2: He alone is my rock and my salvation, my stronghold; I will never be shaken.
62.3: How long will you threaten a man? Will all of you attack as if he were a leaning wall or a tottering stone fence?
62.4: They only plan to bring him down from his high position. They take pleasure in lying; they bless with their mouths, but they curse inwardly. Selah
62.5: Rest in God alone, my soul, for my hope comes from Him.
62.6: He alone is my rock and my salvation, my stronghold; I will not be shaken.
62.7: My salvation and glory depend on God, my strong rock. My refuge is in God.
62.8: Trust in Him at all times, you people; pour out your hearts before Him. God is our refuge. Selah
62.9: Men are only a vapor; exalted men, an illusion. Weighed in the scales, they go up; together they are less than a vapor.
62.10: Place no trust in oppression, or false hope in robbery. If wealth increases, pay no attention to it.
62.11: God has spoken once; I have heard this twice: strength belongs to God,
62.12: and faithful love belongs to You, LORD. For You repay each according to his works.

63.1: A Davidic psalm. When he was in the Wilderness of Judah. God, You are my God; I eagerly seek You. I thirst for You; my body faints for You in a land that is dry, desolate, and without water.
63.2: So I gaze on You in the sanctuary to see Your strength and Your glory.
63.3: My lips will glorify You because Your faithful love is better than life.
63.4: So I will praise You as long as I live; at Your name, I will lift up my hands.
63.5: You satisfy me as with rich food; my mouth will praise You with joyful lips.
63.6: When I think of You as I lie on my bed, I meditate on You during the night watches
63.7: because You are my helper; I will rejoice in the shadow of Your wings.
63.8: I follow close to You; Your right hand holds on to me.
63.9: But those who seek to destroy my life will go into the depths of the earth.
63.10: They will be given over to the power of the sword; they will become the jackals’ prey.
63.11: But the king will rejoice in God; all who swear by Him will boast, for the mouths of liars will be shut.

64.1: For the choir director. A Davidic psalm. God, hear my voice when I complain. Protect my life from the terror of the enemy.
64.2: Hide me from the scheming of wicked people, from the mob of evildoers,
64.3: who sharpen their tongues like swords and aim bitter words like arrows,
64.4: shooting from concealed places at the innocent. They shoot at him suddenly and are not afraid.
64.5: They encourage each other in an evil plan; they talk about hiding traps and say,” Who will see them?”
64.6: They devise crimes and say,” We have perfected a secret plan.” The inner man and the heart are mysterious.
64.7: But God will shoot them with arrows; suddenly, they will be wounded.
64.8: They will be made to stumble; their own tongues work against them. All who see them will shake their heads.
64.9: Then everyone will fear and will tell about God’s work, for they will understand what He has done.
64.10: The righteous one rejoices in the LORD and takes refuge in Him; all those who are upright in heart will offer praise.

65.1: For the choir director. A Davidic psalm. A song. Praise is rightfully Yours, God, in Zion; vows to You will be fulfilled.
65.2: All humanity will come to You, the One who hears prayer.
65.3: Iniquities overwhelm me; only You can atone for our rebellions.
65.4: How happy is the one You choose and bring near to live in Your courts! We will be satisfied with the goodness of Your house, the holiness of Your temple.
65.5: You answer us in righteousness, with awe-inspiring works, God of our salvation, the hope of all the ends of the earth and of the distant seas.
65.6: You establish the mountains by Your power, robed with strength.
65.7: You silence the roar of the seas, the roar of their waves, and the tumult of the nations.
65.8: Those who live far away are awed by Your signs; You make east and west shout for joy.
65.9: You visit the earth and water it abundantly, enriching it greatly. God’s stream is filled with water, for You prepare the earth in this way, providing people with grain.
65.10: You soften it with showers and bless its growth, soaking its furrows and leveling its ridges.
65.11: You crown the year with Your goodness; Your ways overflow with plenty.
65.12: The wilderness pastures overflow, and the hills are robed with joy.
65.13: The pastures are clothed with flocks and the valleys covered with grain. They shout in triumph; indeed, they sing.

66.1: For the choir director. A song. A psalm. Shout joyfully to God, all the earth!
66.2: Sing about the glory of His name; make His praise glorious.
66.3: Say to God, “How awe-inspiring are Your works! Your enemies will cringe before You because of Your great strength.
66.4: All the earth will worship You and sing praise to You. They will sing praise to Your name.” Selah
66.5: Come and see the wonders of God; His acts for humanity are awe-inspiring.
66.6: He turned the sea into dry land, and they crossed the river on foot. There we rejoiced in Him.
66.7: He rules forever by His might; He keeps His eye on the nations. The rebellious should not exalt themselves. Selah
66.8: Praise our God, you peoples; let the sound of His praise be heard.
66.9: He keeps us alive and does not allow our feet to slip.
66.10: For You, God, tested us; You refined us as silver is refined.
66.11: You lured us into a trap; You placed burdens on our backs.
66.12: You let men ride over our heads; we went through fire and water, but You brought us out to abundance.
66.13: I will enter Your house with burnt offerings; I will pay You my vows
66.14: that my lips promised and my mouth spoke during my distress.
66.15: I will offer You fattened sheep as burnt offerings, with the fragrant smoke of rams; I will sacrifice oxen with goats. Selah
66.16: Come and listen, all who fear God, and I will tell what He has done for me.
66.17: I cried out to Him with my mouth, and praise was on my tongue.
66.18: If I had been aware of malice in my heart, the Lord would not have listened.
66.19: However, God has listened; He has paid attention to the sound of my prayer.
66.20: May God be praised! He has not turned away my prayer or turned His faithful love from me.

67.1: For the choir director: with stringed instruments. A psalm. A song. May God be gracious to us and bless us; look on us with favor Selah
67.2: so that Your way may be known on earth, Your salvation among all nations.
67.3: Let the peoples praise You, God; let all the peoples praise You.
67.4: Let the nations rejoice and shout for joy, for You judge the peoples with fairness and lead the nations on earth. Selah
67.5: Let the peoples praise You, God, let all the peoples praise You.
67.6: The earth has produced its harvest; God, our God, blesses us.
67.7: God will bless us, and all the ends of the earth will fear Him.

68.1: For the choir director. A Davidic psalm. A song. God arises. His enemies scatter, and those who hate Him flee from His presence.
68.2: As smoke is blown away, so You blow them away. As wax melts before the fire, so the wicked are destroyed before God.
68.3: But the righteous are glad; they rejoice before God and celebrate with joy.
68.4: Sing to God! Sing praises to His name. Exalt Him who rides on the clouds — His name is Yahweh—and rejoice before Him.
68.5: God in His holy dwelling is a father of the fatherless and a champion of widows.
68.6: God provides homes for those who are deserted. He leads out the prisoners to prosperity, but the rebellious live in a scorched land.
68.7: God, when You went out before Your people, when You marched through the desert, Selah
68.8: the earth trembled and the skies poured down rain before God, the God of Sinai, before God, the God of Israel.
68.9: You, God, showered abundant rain; You revived Your inheritance when it languished.
68.10: Your people settled in it; God, You provided for the poor by Your goodness.
68.11: The Lord gave the command; a great company of women brought the good news:”
68.12: The kings of the armies flee—they flee!” She who stays at home divides the spoil.
68.13: While you lie among the sheepfolds, the wings of a dove are covered with silver, and its feathers with glistening gold.
68.14: When the Almighty scattered kings in the land, it snowed on Zalmon.
68.15: Mount Bashan is God’s towering mountain; Mount Bashan is a mountain of many peaks.
68.16: Why gaze with envy, you mountain peaks, at the mountain God desired for His dwelling? The LORD will live there forever!
68.17: God’s chariots are tens of thousands, thousands and thousands; the Lord is among them in the sanctuary as He was at Sinai.
68.18: You ascended to the heights, taking away captives; You received gifts from people, even from the rebellious, so that the LORD God might live there.
68.19: May the Lord be praised! Day after day He bears our burdens; God is our salvation. Selah
68.20: Our God is a God of salvation, and escape from death belongs to the Lord GOD.
68.21: Surely God crushes the heads of His enemies, the hairy head of one who goes on in his guilty acts.
68.22: The Lord said, “I will bring them back from Bashan; I will bring them back from the depths of the sea
68.23: so that your foot may wade in blood and your dogs’ tongues may have their share from the enemies.”
68.24: People have seen Your procession, God, the procession of my God, my King, in the sanctuary.
68.25: Singers lead the way, with musicians following; among them are young women playing tambourines.
68.26: Praise God in the assemblies; praise the LORD from the fountain of Israel.
68.27: There is Benjamin, the youngest, leading them, the rulers of Judah in their assembly, the rulers of Zebulun, the rulers of Naphtali.
68.28: Your God has decreed your strength. Show Your strength, God, You who have acted on our behalf.
68.29: Because of Your temple at Jerusalem, kings will bring tribute to You.
68.30: Rebuke the beast in the reeds, the herd of bulls with the calves of the peoples. Trample underfoot those with bars of silver. Scatter the peoples who take pleasure in war.
68.31: Ambassadors will come from Egypt; Cush will stretch out its hands to God.
68.32: Sing to God, you kingdoms of the earth; sing praise to the Lord, Selah
68.33: to Him who rides in the ancient, highest heavens. Look, He thunders with His powerful voice!
68.34: Ascribe power to God. His majesty is over Israel, His power among the clouds.
68.35: God, You are awe-inspiring in Your sanctuaries. The God of Israel gives power and strength to His people. May God be praised!

69.1: For the choir director: according to “The Lilies.” Davidic. Save me, God, for the water has risen to my neck.
69.2: I have sunk in deep mud, and there is no footing; I have come into deep waters, and a flood sweeps over me.
69.3: I am weary from my crying; my throat is parched. My eyes fail, looking for my God.
69.4: Those who hate me without cause are more numerous than the hairs of my head; my deceitful enemies, who would destroy me, are powerful. Though I did not steal, I must repay.
69.5: God, You know my foolishness, and my guilty acts are not hidden from You.
69.6: Do not let those who put their hope in You be disgraced because of me, Lord GOD of Hosts; do not let those who seek You be humiliated because of me, God of Israel.
69.7: For I have endured insults because of You, and shame has covered my face.
69.8: I have become a stranger to my brothers and a foreigner to my mother’s sons
69.9: because zeal for Your house has consumed me, and the insults of those who insult You have fallen on me.
69.10: I mourned and fasted, but it brought me insults.
69.11: I wore sackcloth as my clothing, and I was a joke to them.
69.12: Those who sit at the city gate talk about me, and drunkards make up songs about me.
69.13: But as for me, LORD, my prayer to You is for a time of favor. In Your abundant, faithful love, God, answer me with Your sure salvation.
69.14: Rescue me from the miry mud; don’t let me sink. Let me be rescued from those who hate me and from the deep waters.
69.15: Don’t let the floodwaters sweep over me or the deep swallow me up; don’t let the Pit close its mouth over me.
69.16: Answer me, LORD, for Your faithful love is good; in keeping with Your great compassion, turn to me.
69.17: Don’t hide Your face from Your servant, for I am in distress. Answer me quickly!
69.18: Draw near to me and redeem me; ransom me because of my enemies.
69.19: You know the insults I endure— my shame and disgrace. You are aware of all my adversaries.
69.20: Insults have broken my heart, and I am in despair. I waited for sympathy, but there was none; for comforters, but found no one.
69.21: Instead, they gave me gall for my food, and for my thirst they gave me vinegar to drink.
69.22: Let their table set before them be a snare, and let it be a trap for their allies.
69.23: Let their eyes grow too dim to see, and let their loins continually shake.
69.24: Pour out Your rage on them, and let Your burning anger overtake them.
69.25: Make their fortification desolate; may no one live in their tents.
69.26: For they persecute the one You struck and talk about the pain of those You wounded.
69.27: Add guilt to their guilt; do not let them share in Your righteousness.
69.28: Let them be erased from the book of life and not be recorded with the righteous.
69.29: But as for me—poor and in pain— let Your salvation protect me, God.
69.30: I will praise God’s name with song and exalt Him with thanksgiving.
69.31: That will please Yahweh more than an ox, more than a bull with horns and hooves.
69.32: The humble will see it and rejoice. You who seek God, take heart!
69.33: For the LORD listens to the needy and does not despise His own who are prisoners.
69.34: Let heaven and earth praise Him, the seas and everything that moves in them,
69.35: for God will save Zion and build up the cities of Judah. They will live there and possess it.
69.36: The descendants of His servants will inherit it, and those who love His name will live in it.

70.1: For the choir director. Davidic. To bring remembrance. God, deliver me. Hurry to help me, LORD!
70.2: Let those who seek my life be disgraced and confounded; let those who wish me harm be driven back and humiliated.
70.3: Let those who say, “Aha, aha!” retreat because of their shame.
70.4: Let all who seek You rejoice and be glad in You; let those who love Your salvation continually say, “God is great!”
70.5: I am afflicted and needy; hurry to me, God. You are my help and my deliverer; LORD, do not delay.

71.1: LORD, I seek refuge in You; let me never be disgraced.
71.2: In Your justice, rescue and deliver me; listen closely to me and save me.
71.3: Be a rock of refuge for me, where I can always go. Give the command to save me, for You are my rock and fortress.
71.4: Deliver me, my God, from the power of the wicked, from the grasp of the unjust and oppressive.
71.5: For You are my hope, Lord GOD, my confidence from my youth.
71.6: I have leaned on You from birth; You took me from my mother’s womb. My praise is always about You.
71.7: I have become an ominous sign to many, but You are my strong refuge.
71.8: My mouth is full of praise and honor to You all day long.
71.9: Don’t discard me in my old age; as my strength fails, do not abandon me.
71.10: For my enemies talk about me, and those who spy on me plot together,
71.11: saying, “God has abandoned him; chase him and catch him, for there is no one to rescue him.”
71.12: God, do not be far from me; my God, hurry to help me.
71.13: May my adversaries be disgraced and destroyed; may those who seek my harm be covered with disgrace and humiliation.
71.14: But I will hope continually and will praise You more and more.
71.15: My mouth will tell about Your righteousness and Your salvation all day long, though I cannot sum them up.
71.16: I come because of the mighty acts of the Lord GOD; I will proclaim Your righteousness, Yours alone.
71.17: God, You have taught me from my youth, and I still proclaim Your wonderful works.
71.18: Even when I am old and gray, God, do not abandon me. Then I will proclaim Your power to another generation, Your strength to all who are to come.
71.19: Your righteousness reaches heaven, God, You who have done great things; God, who is like You?
71.20: You caused me to experience many troubles and misfortunes, but You will revive me again. You will bring me up again, even from the depths of the earth.
71.21: You will increase my honor and comfort me once again.
71.22: Therefore, I will praise You with a harp for Your faithfulness, my God; I will sing to You with a lyre, Holy One of Israel.
71.23: My lips will shout for joy when I sing praise to You because You have redeemed me.
71.24: Therefore, my tongue will proclaim Your righteousness all day long, for those who seek my harm will be disgraced and confounded.

72.1: Solomonic. God, give Your justice to the king and Your righteousness to the king’s son.
72.2: He will judge Your people with righteousness and Your afflicted ones with justice.
72.3: May the mountains bring prosperity to the people and the hills, righteousness.
72.4: May he vindicate the afflicted among the people, help the poor, and crush the oppressor.
72.5: May he continue while the sun endures and as long as the moon, throughout all generations.
72.6: May he be like rain that falls on the cut grass, like spring showers that water the earth.
72.7: May the righteous flourish in his days and prosperity abound until the moon is no more.
72.8: May he rule from sea to sea and from the Euphrates to the ends of the earth.
72.9: May desert tribes kneel before him and his enemies lick the dust.
72.10: May the kings of Tarshish and the coasts and islands bring tribute, the kings of Sheba and Seba offer gifts.
72.11: Let all kings bow down to him, all nations serve him.
72.12: For he will rescue the poor who cry out and the afflicted who have no helper.
72.13: He will have pity on the poor and helpless and save the lives of the poor.
72.14: He will redeem them from oppression and violence, for their lives are precious in his sight.
72.15: May he live long! May gold from Sheba be given to him. May prayer be offered for him continually, and may he be blessed all day long.
72.16: May there be plenty of grain in the land; may it wave on the tops of the mountains. May its crops be like Lebanon. May people flourish in the cities like the grass of the field.
72.17: May his name endure forever; as long as the sun shines, may his fame increase. May all nations be blessed by him and call him blessed.
72.18: May the LORD God, the God of Israel, who alone does wonders, be praised.
72.19: May His glorious name be praised forever; the whole earth is filled with His glory. Amen and amen.
72.20: The prayers of David son of Jesse are concluded.

73.1: A psalm of Asaph. God is indeed good to Israel, to the pure in heart.
73.2: But as for me, my feet almost slipped; my steps nearly went astray.
73.3: For I envied the arrogant; I saw the prosperity of the wicked.
73.4: They have an easy time until they die, and their bodies are well fed.
73.5: They are not in trouble like others; they are not afflicted like most people.
73.6: Therefore, pride is their necklace, and violence covers them like a garment.
73.7: Their eyes bulge out from fatness; the imaginations of their hearts run wild.
73.8: They mock, and they speak maliciously; they arrogantly threaten oppression.
73.9: They set their mouths against heaven, and their tongues strut across the earth.
73.10: Therefore His people turn to them and drink in their overflowing words.
73.11: The wicked say, “How can God know? Does the Most High know everything?”
73.12: Look at them—the wicked! They are always at ease, and they increase their wealth.
73.13: Did I purify my heart and wash my hands in innocence for nothing?
73.14: For I am afflicted all day long and punished every morning.
73.15: If I had decided to say these things aloud, I would have betrayed Your people.
73.16: When I tried to understand all this, it seemed hopeless
73.17: until I entered God’s sanctuary. Then I understood their destiny.
73.18: Indeed, You put them in slippery places; You make them fall into ruin.
73.19: How suddenly they become a desolation! They come to an end, swept away by terrors.
73.20: Like one waking from a dream, Lord, when arising, You will despise their image.
73.21: When I became embittered and my innermost being was wounded,
73.22: I was stupid and didn’t understand; I was an unthinking animal toward You.
73.23: Yet I am always with You; You hold my right hand.
73.24: You guide me with Your counsel, and afterward You will take me up in glory.
73.25: Who do I have in heaven but You? And I desire nothing on earth but You.
73.26: My flesh and my heart may fail, but God is the strength of my heart, my portion forever.
73.27: Those far from You will certainly perish; You destroy all who are unfaithful to You.
73.28: But as for me, God’s presence is my good. I have made the Lord GOD my refuge, so I can tell about all You do.

74.1: A Maskil of Asaph. Why have You rejected us forever, God? Why does Your anger burn against the sheep of Your pasture?
74.2: Remember Your congregation, which You purchased long ago and redeemed as the tribe for Your own possession. Remember Mount Zion where You dwell.
74.3: Make Your way to the everlasting ruins, to all that the enemy has destroyed in the sanctuary.
74.4: Your adversaries roared in the meeting place where You met with us. They set up their emblems as signs.
74.5: It was like men in a thicket of trees, wielding axes,
74.6: then smashing all the carvings with hatchets and picks.
74.7: They set Your sanctuary on fire; they utterly desecrated the dwelling place of Your name.
74.8: They said in their hearts,” Let us oppress them relentlessly.” They burned down every place throughout the land where God met with us.
74.9: There are no signs for us to see. There is no longer a prophet. And none of us knows how long this will last.
74.10: God, how long will the enemy mock? Will the foe insult Your name forever?
74.11: Why do You hold back Your hand? Stretch out Your right hand and destroy them!
74.12: God my King is from ancient times, performing saving acts on the earth.
74.13: You divided the sea with Your strength; You smashed the heads of the sea monsters in the waters;
74.14: You crushed the heads of Leviathan; You fed him to the creatures of the desert.
74.15: You opened up springs and streams; You dried up ever-flowing rivers.
74.16: The day is Yours, also the night; You established the moon and the sun.
74.17: You set all the boundaries of the earth; You made summer and winter.
74.18: Remember this: the enemy has mocked Yahweh, and a foolish people has insulted Your name.
74.19: Do not give the life of Your dove to beasts; do not forget the lives of Your poor people forever.
74.20: Consider the covenant, for the dark places of the land are full of violence.
74.21: Do not let the oppressed turn away in shame; let the poor and needy praise Your name.
74.22: Rise up, God, defend Your cause! Remember the insults that fools bring against You all day long.
74.23: Do not forget the clamor of Your adversaries, the tumult of Your opponents that goes up constantly.

75.1: For the choir director: “Do Not Destroy.” A psalm of Asaph. A song. We give thanks to You, God; we give thanks to You, for Your name is near. People tell about Your wonderful works.”
75.2: When I choose a time, I will judge fairly.
75.3: When the earth and all its inhabitants shake, I am the One who steadies its pillars. Selah
75.4: I say to the boastful, ‘Do not boast,’ and to the wicked, ‘Do not lift up your horn.
75.5: Do not lift up your horn against heaven or speak arrogantly.’”
75.6: Exaltation does not come from the east, the west, or the desert,
75.7: for God is the Judge: He brings down one and exalts another.
75.8: For there is a cup in the LORD’s hand, full of wine blended with spices, and He pours from it. All the wicked of the earth will drink, draining it to the dregs.
75.9: As for me, I will tell about Him forever; I will sing praise to the God of Jacob.”
75.10: I will cut off all the horns of the wicked, but the horns of the righteous will be lifted up.”

76.1: For the choir director: with stringed instruments. A psalm of Asaph. A song. God is known in Judah; His name is great in Israel.
76.2: His tent is in Salem, His dwelling place in Zion.
76.3: There He shatters the bow’s flaming arrows, the shield, the sword, and the weapons of war. Selah
76.4: You are resplendent and majestic coming down from the mountains of prey.
76.5: The brave-hearted have been plundered; they have slipped into their final sleep. None of the warriors was able to lift a hand.
76.6: At Your rebuke, God of Jacob, both chariot and horse lay still.
76.7: And You—You are to be feared. When You are angry, who can stand before You?
76.8: From heaven You pronounced judgment. The earth feared and grew quiet
76.9: when God rose up to judge and to save all the lowly of the earth. Selah
76.10: Even human wrath will praise You; You will clothe Yourself with their remaining wrath.
76.11: Make and keep your vows to the LORD your God; let all who are around Him bring tribute to the awe-inspiring One.
76.12: He humbles the spirit of leaders; He is feared by the kings of the earth.

77.1: For the choir director: according to Jeduthun. Of Asaph. A psalm. I cry aloud to God, aloud to God, and He will hear me.
77.2: I sought the Lord in my day of trouble. My hands were continually lifted up all night long; I refused to be comforted.
77.3: I think of God; I groan; I meditate; my spirit becomes weak. Selah
77.4: You have kept me from closing my eyes; I am troubled and cannot speak.
77.5: I consider days of old, years long past.
77.6: At night I remember my music; I meditate in my heart, and my spirit ponders.”
77.7: Will the Lord reject forever and never again show favor?
77.8: Has His faithful love ceased forever? Is His promise at an end for all generations?
77.9: Has God forgotten to be gracious? Has He in anger withheld His compassion?” Selah
77.10: So I say, “I am grieved that the right hand of the Most High has changed.”
77.11: I will remember the LORD’s works; yes, I will remember Your ancient wonders.
77.12: I will reflect on all You have done and meditate on Your actions.
77.13: God, Your way is holy. What god is great like God?
77.14: You are the God who works wonders; You revealed Your strength among the peoples.
77.15: With power You redeemed Your people, the descendants of Jacob and Joseph. Selah
77.16: The waters saw You, God. The waters saw You; they trembled. Even the depths shook.
77.17: The clouds poured down water. The storm clouds thundered; Your arrows flashed back and forth.
77.18: The sound of Your thunder was in the whirlwind; lightning lit up the world. The earth shook and quaked.
77.19: Your way went through the sea and Your path through the great waters, but Your footprints were unseen.
77.20: You led Your people like a flock by the hand of Moses and Aaron.

78.1: A Maskil of Asaph. My people, hear my instruction; listen to what I say.
78.2: I will declare wise sayings; I will speak mysteries from the past—
78.3: things we have heard and known and that our fathers have passed down to us.
78.4: We must not hide them from their children, but must tell a future generation the praises of the LORD, His might, and the wonderful works He has performed.
78.5: He established a testimony in Jacob and set up a law in Israel, which He commanded our fathers to teach to their children
78.6: so that a future generation— children yet to be born—might know. They were to rise and tell their children
78.7: so that they might put their confidence in God and not forget God’s works, but keep His commands.
78.8: Then they would not be like their fathers, a stubborn and rebellious generation, a generation whose heart was not loyal and whose spirit was not faithful to God.
78.9: The Ephraimite archers turned back on the day of battle.
78.10: They did not keep God’s covenant and refused to live by His law.
78.11: They forgot what He had done, the wonderful works He had shown them.
78.12: He worked wonders in the sight of their fathers in the land of Egypt, the region of Zoan.
78.13: He split the sea and brought them across; the water stood firm like a wall.
78.14: He led them with a cloud by day and with a fiery light throughout the night.
78.15: He split rocks in the wilderness and gave them drink as abundant as the depths.
78.16: He brought streams out of the stone and made water flow down like rivers.
78.17: But they continued to sin against Him, rebelling in the desert against the Most High.
78.18: They deliberately tested God, demanding the food they craved.
78.19: They spoke against God, saying,” Is God able to provide food in the wilderness?
78.20: Look! He struck the rock and water gushed out; torrents overflowed. But can He also provide bread or furnish meat for His people?”
78.21: Therefore, the LORD heard and became furious; then fire broke out against Jacob, and anger flared up against Israel
78.22: because they did not believe God or rely on His salvation.
78.23: He gave a command to the clouds above and opened the doors of heaven.
78.24: He rained manna for them to eat; He gave them grain from heaven.
78.25: People ate the bread of angels. He sent them an abundant supply of food.
78.26: He made the east wind blow in the skies and drove the south wind by His might.
78.27: He rained meat on them like dust, and winged birds like the sand of the seas.
78.28: He made them fall in His camp, all around His tent.
78.29: They ate and were completely satisfied, for He gave them what they craved.
78.30: Before they had satisfied their desire, while the food was still in their mouths,
78.31: God’s anger flared up against them, and He killed some of their best men. He struck down Israel’s choice young men.
78.32: Despite all this, they kept sinning and did not believe His wonderful works.
78.33: He made their days end in futility, their years in sudden disaster.
78.34: When He killed some of them, the rest began to seek Him; they repented and searched for God.
78.35: They remembered that God was their rock, the Most High God, their Redeemer.
78.36: But they deceived Him with their mouths, they lied to Him with their tongues,
78.37: their hearts were insincere toward Him, and they were unfaithful to His covenant.
78.38: Yet He was compassionate; He atoned for their guilt and did not destroy them. He often turned His anger aside and did not unleash all His wrath.
78.39: He remembered that they were only flesh, a wind that passes and does not return.
78.40: How often they rebelled against Him in the wilderness and grieved Him in the desert.
78.41: They constantly tested God and provoked the Holy One of Israel.
78.42: They did not remember His power shown on the day He redeemed them from the foe,
78.43: when He performed His miraculous signs in Egypt and His wonders in the region of Zoan.
78.44: He turned their rivers into blood, and they could not drink from their streams.
78.45: He sent among them swarms of flies, which fed on them, and frogs, which devastated them.
78.46: He gave their crops to the caterpillar and the fruit of their labor to the locust.
78.47: He killed their vines with hail and their sycamore fig trees with a flood.
78.48: He handed over their livestock to hail and their cattle to lightning bolts.
78.49: He sent His burning anger against them: fury, indignation, and calamity— a band of deadly messengers.
78.50: He cleared a path for His anger. He did not spare them from death but delivered their lives to the plague.
78.51: He struck all the firstborn in Egypt, the first progeny of the tents of Ham.
78.52: He led His people out like sheep and guided them like a flock in the wilderness.
78.53: He led them safely, and they were not afraid; but the sea covered their enemies.
78.54: He brought them to His holy land, to the mountain His right hand acquired.
78.55: He drove out nations before them. He apportioned their inheritance by lot and settled the tribes of Israel in their tents.
78.56: But they rebelliously tested the Most High God, for they did not keep His decrees.
78.57: They treacherously turned away like their fathers; they became warped like a faulty bow.
78.58: They enraged Him with their high places and provoked His jealousy with their carved images.
78.59: God heard and became furious; He completely rejected Israel.
78.60: He abandoned the tabernacle at Shiloh, the tent where He resided among men.
78.61: He gave up His strength to captivity and His splendor to the hand of a foe.
78.62: He surrendered His people to the sword because He was enraged with His heritage.
78.63: Fire consumed His chosen young men, and His young women had no wedding songs.
78.64: His priests fell by the sword, but the widows could not lament.
78.65: Then the Lord awoke as if from sleep, like a warrior from the effects of wine.
78.66: He beat back His foes; He gave them lasting shame.
78.67: He rejected the tent of Joseph and did not choose the tribe of Ephraim.
78.68: He chose instead the tribe of Judah, Mount Zion, which He loved.
78.69: He built His sanctuary like the heights, like the earth that He established forever.
78.70: He chose David His servant and took him from the sheepfolds;
78.71: He brought him from tending ewes to be shepherd over His people Jacob— over Israel, His inheritance.
78.72: He shepherded them with a pure heart and guided them with his skillful hands.

79.1: A psalm of Asaph. God, the nations have invaded Your inheritance, desecrated Your holy temple, and turned Jerusalem into ruins.
79.2: They gave the corpses of Your servants to the birds of the sky for food, the flesh of Your godly ones to the beasts of the earth.
79.3: They poured out their blood like water all around Jerusalem, and there was no one to bury them.
79.4: We have become an object of reproach to our neighbors, a source of mockery and ridicule to those around us.
79.5: How long, Yahweh? Will You be angry forever? Will Your jealousy keep burning like fire?
79.6: Pour out Your wrath on the nations that don’t acknowledge You, on the kingdoms that don’t call on Your name,
79.7: for they have devoured Jacob and devastated his homeland.
79.8: Do not hold past sins against us; let Your compassion come to us quickly, for we have become weak.
79.9: God of our salvation, help us— for the glory of Your name. Deliver us and atone for our sins, because of Your name.
79.10: Why should the nations ask,” Where is their God?” Before our eyes, let vengeance for the shed blood of Your servants be known among the nations.
79.11: Let the groans of the prisoners reach You; according to Your great power, preserve those condemned to die.
79.12: Pay back sevenfold to our neighbors the reproach they have hurled at You, Lord.
79.13: Then we, Your people, the sheep of Your pasture, will thank You forever; we will declare Your praise to generation after generation.

80.1: For the choir director: according to “The Lilies.” A testimony of Asaph. A psalm. Listen, Shepherd of Israel, who leads Joseph like a flock; You who sit enthroned on the cherubim, rise up
80.2: before Ephraim, Benjamin, and Manasseh. Rally Your power and come to save us.
80.3: Restore us, God; look on us with favor, and we will be saved.
80.4: LORD God of Hosts, how long will You be angry with Your people’s prayers?
80.5: You fed them the bread of tears and gave them a full measure of tears to drink.
80.6: You make us quarrel with our neighbors; our enemies make fun of us.
80.7: Restore us, God of Hosts; look on us with favor, and we will be saved.
80.8: You uprooted a vine from Egypt; You drove out the nations and planted it.
80.9: You cleared a place for it; it took root and filled the land.
80.10: The mountains were covered by its shade, and the mighty cedars with its branches.
80.11: It sent out sprouts toward the Sea and shoots toward the River.
80.12: Why have You broken down its walls so that all who pass by pick its fruit?
80.13: The boar from the forest tears it and creatures of the field feed on it.
80.14: Return, God of Hosts. Look down from heaven and see; take care of this vine,
80.15: the root Your right hand has planted, the shoot that You made strong for Yourself.
80.16: It was cut down and burned up; they perish at the rebuke of Your countenance.
80.17: Let Your hand be with the man at Your right hand, with the son of man You have made strong for Yourself.
80.18: Then we will not turn away from You; revive us, and we will call on Your name.
80.19: Restore us, Yahweh, the God of Hosts; look on us with favor, and we will be saved.

81.1: For the choir director: on the Gittith. Of Asaph. Sing for joy to God our strength; shout in triumph to the God of Jacob.
81.2: Lift up a song—play the tambourine, the melodious lyre, and the harp.
81.3: Blow the horn on the day of our feasts during the new moon and during the full moon.
81.4: For this is a statute for Israel, a judgment of the God of Jacob.
81.5: He set it up as an ordinance for Joseph when He went throughout the land of Egypt. I heard an unfamiliar language:”
81.6: I relieved his shoulder from the burden; his hands were freed from carrying the basket.
81.7: You called out in distress, and I rescued you; I answered you from the thundercloud. I tested you at the waters of Meribah. Selah
81.8: Listen, My people, and I will admonish you. Israel, if you would only listen to Me!
81.9: There must not be a strange god among you; you must not bow down to a foreign god.
81.10: I am Yahweh your God, who brought you up from the land of Egypt. Open your mouth wide, and I will fill it.”
81.11: But My people did not listen to Me; Israel did not obey Me.
81.12: So I gave them over to their stubborn hearts to follow their own plans.
81.13: If only My people would listen to Me and Israel would follow My ways,
81.14: I would quickly subdue their enemies and turn My hand against their foes.”
81.15: Those who hate the LORD would pretend submission to Him; their doom would last forever.
81.16: But He would feed Israel with the best wheat.” I would satisfy you with honey from the rock.”

82.1: A psalm of Asaph. God has taken His place in the divine assembly; He judges among the gods:”
82.2: How long will you judge unjustly and show partiality to the wicked? Selah
82.3: Provide justice for the needy and the fatherless; uphold the rights of the oppressed and the destitute.
82.4: Rescue the poor and needy; save them from the power of the wicked.”
82.5: They do not know or understand; they wander in darkness. All the foundations of the earth are shaken.
82.6: I said, “You are gods; you are all sons of the Most High.
82.7: However, you will die like men and fall like any other ruler.”
82.8: Rise up, God, judge the earth, for all the nations belong to You.

83.1: A song. A psalm of Asaph. God, do not keep silent. Do not be deaf, God; do not be idle.
83.2: See how Your enemies make an uproar; those who hate You have acted arrogantly.
83.3: They devise clever schemes against Your people; they conspire against Your treasured ones.
83.4: They say, “Come, let us wipe them out as a nation so that Israel’s name will no longer be remembered.”
83.5: For they have conspired with one mind; they form an alliance against You—
83.6: the tents of Edom and the Ishmaelites, Moab and the Hagrites,
83.7: Gebal, Ammon, and Amalek, Philistia with the inhabitants of Tyre.
83.8: Even Assyria has joined them; they lend support to the sons of Lot. Selah
83.9: Deal with them as You did with Midian, as You did with Sisera and Jabin at the Kishon River.
83.10: They were destroyed at En-dor; they became manure for the ground.
83.11: Make their nobles like Oreb and Zeeb, and all their tribal leaders like Zebah and Zalmunna,
83.12: who said, “Let us seize God’s pastures for ourselves.”
83.13: Make them like tumbleweed, my God, like straw before the wind.
83.14: As fire burns a forest, as a flame blazes through mountains,
83.15: so pursue them with Your tempest and terrify them with Your storm.
83.16: Cover their faces with shame so that they will seek Your name Yahweh.
83.17: Let them be put to shame and terrified forever; let them perish in disgrace.
83.18: May they know that You alone— whose name is Yahweh— are the Most High over all the earth.

84.1: For the choir director: on the Gittith. A psalm of the sons of Korah. How lovely is Your dwelling place, LORD of Hosts.
84.2: I long and yearn for the courts of the LORD; my heart and flesh cry out for the living God.
84.3: Even a sparrow finds a home, and a swallow, a nest for herself where she places her young— near Your altars, LORD of Hosts, my King and my God.
84.4: How happy are those who reside in Your house, who praise You continually. Selah
84.5: Happy are the people whose strength is in You, whose hearts are set on pilgrimage.
84.6: As they pass through the Valley of Baca, they make it a source of springwater; even the autumn rain will cover it with blessings.
84.7: They go from strength to strength; each appears before God in Zion.
84.8: LORD God of Hosts, hear my prayer; listen, God of Jacob. Selah
84.9: Consider our shield, God; look on the face of Your anointed one.
84.10: Better a day in Your courts than a thousand anywhere else. I would rather be at the door of the house of my God than to live in the tents of wicked people.
84.11: For the LORD God is a sun and shield. The LORD gives grace and glory; He does not withhold the good from those who live with integrity.
84.12: Happy is the person who trusts in You, LORD of Hosts!

85.1: For the choir director. A psalm of the sons of Korah. LORD, You showed favor to Your land; You restored Jacob’s prosperity.
85.2: You took away Your people’s guilt; You covered all their sin. Selah
85.3: You withdrew all Your fury; You turned from Your burning anger.
85.4: Return to us, God of our salvation, and abandon Your displeasure with us.
85.5: Will You be angry with us forever? Will You prolong Your anger for all generations?
85.6: Will You not revive us again so that Your people may rejoice in You?
85.7: Show us Your faithful love, LORD, and give us Your salvation.
85.8: I will listen to what God will say; surely the LORD will declare peace to His people, His godly ones, and not let them go back to foolish ways.
85.9: His salvation is very near those who fear Him, so that glory may dwell in our land.
85.10: Faithful love and truth will join together; righteousness and peace will embrace.
85.11: Truth will spring up from the earth, and righteousness will look down from heaven.
