136.16: He led His people in the wilderness. His love is eternal.
136.17: He struck down great kings His love is eternal.
136.18: and slaughtered famous kings— His love is eternal.
136.19: Sihon king of the Amorites His love is eternal.
136.20: and Og king of Bashan— His love is eternal.
136.21: and gave their land as an inheritance, His love is eternal.
136.22: an inheritance to Israel His servant. His love is eternal.
136.23: He remembered us in our humiliation His love is eternal.
136.24: and rescued us from our foes. His love is eternal.
136.25: He gives food to every creature. His love is eternal.
136.26: Give thanks to the God of heaven! His love is eternal.

137.1: By the rivers of Babylon— there we sat down and wept when we remembered Zion.
137.2: There we hung up our lyres on the poplar trees,
137.3: for our captors there asked us for songs, and our tormentors, for rejoicing:” Sing us one of the songs of Zion.”
137.4: How can we sing the LORD’s song on foreign soil?
137.5: If I forget you, Jerusalem, may my right hand forget its skill.
137.6: May my tongue stick to the roof of my mouth if I do not remember you, if I do not exalt Jerusalem as my greatest joy!
137.7: Remember, LORD, what the Edomites said that day at Jerusalem:” Destroy it! Destroy it down to its foundations!”
137.8: Daughter Babylon, doomed to destruction, happy is the one who pays you back what you have done to us.
137.9: Happy is he who takes your little ones and dashes them against the rocks.

138.1: Davidic. I will give You thanks with all my heart; I will sing Your praise before the heavenly beings.
138.2: I will bow down toward Your holy temple and give thanks to Your name for Your constant love and truth. You have exalted Your name and Your promise above everything else.
138.3: On the day I called, You answered me; You increased strength within me.
138.4: All the kings on earth will give You thanks, LORD, when they hear what You have promised.
138.5: They will sing of the LORD’s ways, for the LORD’s glory is great.
138.6: Though the LORD is exalted, He takes note of the humble; but He knows the haughty from a distance.
138.7: If I walk into the thick of danger, You will preserve my life from the anger of my enemies. You will extend Your hand; Your right hand will save me.
138.8: The LORD will fulfill His purpose for me. LORD, Your love is eternal; do not abandon the work of Your hands.

139.1: For the choir director. A Davidic psalm. LORD, You have searched me and known me.
139.2: You know when I sit down and when I stand up; You understand my thoughts from far away.
139.3: You observe my travels and my rest; You are aware of all my ways.
139.4: Before a word is on my tongue, You know all about it, LORD.
139.5: You have encircled me; You have placed Your hand on me.
139.6: This extraordinary knowledge is beyond me. It is lofty; I am unable to reach it.
139.7: Where can I go to escape Your Spirit? Where can I flee from Your presence?
139.8: If I go up to heaven, You are there; if I make my bed in Sheol, You are there.
139.9: If I live at the eastern horizon or settle at the western limits,
139.10: even there Your hand will lead me; Your right hand will hold on to me.
139.11: If I say, “Surely the darkness will hide me, and the light around me will be night"—
139.12: even the darkness is not dark to You. The night shines like the day; darkness and light are alike to You.
139.13: For it was You who created my inward parts; You knit me together in my mother’s womb.
139.14: I will praise You because I have been remarkably and wonderfully made. Your works are wonderful, and I know this very well.
139.15: My bones were not hidden from You when I was made in secret, when I was formed in the depths of the earth.
139.16: Your eyes saw me when I was formless; all my days were written in Your book and planned before a single one of them began.
139.17: God, how difficult Your thoughts are for me to comprehend; how vast their sum is!
139.18: If I counted them, they would outnumber the grains of sand; when I wake up, I am still with You.
139.19: God, if only You would kill the wicked— you bloodthirsty men, stay away from me—
139.20: who invoke You deceitfully. Your enemies swear by You falsely.
139.21: LORD, don’t I hate those who hate You, and detest those who rebel against You?
139.22: I hate them with extreme hatred; I consider them my enemies.
139.23: Search me, God, and know my heart; test me and know my concerns.
139.24: See if there is any offensive way in me; lead me in the everlasting way.

140.1: For the choir director. A Davidic psalm. Rescue me, LORD, from evil men. Keep me safe from violent men
140.2: who plan evil in their hearts. They stir up wars all day long.
140.3: They make their tongues as sharp as a snake’s bite; viper’s venom is under their lips. Selah
140.4: Protect me, LORD, from the clutches of the wicked. Keep me safe from violent men who plan to make me stumble.
140.5: The proud hide a trap with ropes for me; they spread a net along the path and set snares for me. Selah
140.6: I say to the LORD, “You are my God.” Listen, LORD, to my cry for help.
140.7: Lord GOD, my strong Savior, You shield my head on the day of battle.
140.8: LORD, do not grant the desires of the wicked; do not let them achieve their goals. Otherwise, they will become proud. Selah
140.9: When those who surround me rise up, may the trouble their lips cause overwhelm them.
140.10: Let hot coals fall on them. Let them be thrown into the fire, into the abyss, never again to rise.
140.11: Do not let a slanderer stay in the land. Let evil relentlessly hunt down a violent man.
140.12: I know that the LORD upholds the just cause of the poor, justice for the needy.
140.13: Surely the righteous will praise Your name; the upright will live in Your presence.

141.1: A Davidic psalm. LORD, I call on You; hurry to help me. Listen to my voice when I call on You.
141.2: May my prayer be set before You as incense, the raising of my hands as the evening offering.
141.3: LORD, set up a guard for my mouth; keep watch at the door of my lips.
141.4: Do not let my heart turn to any evil thing or perform wicked acts with men who commit sin. Do not let me feast on their delicacies.
141.5: Let the righteous one strike me— it is an act of faithful love; let him rebuke me— it is oil for my head; let me not refuse it. Even now my prayer is against the evil acts of the wicked.
141.6: When their rulers will be thrown off the sides of a cliff, the people will listen to my words, for they are pleasing.
141.7: As when one plows and breaks up the soil, turning up rocks, so our bones have been scattered at the mouth of Sheol.
141.8: But my eyes look to You, Lord GOD. I seek refuge in You; do not let me die.
141.9: Protect me from the trap they have set for me, and from the snares of evildoers.
141.10: Let the wicked fall into their own nets, while I pass by safely.

142.1: A Davidic Maskil. When he was in the cave. A prayer. I cry aloud to the LORD; I plead aloud to the LORD for mercy.
142.2: I pour out my complaint before Him; I reveal my trouble to Him.
142.3: Although my spirit is weak within me, You know my way. Along this path I travel they have hidden a trap for me.
142.4: Look to the right and see: no one stands up for me; there is no refuge for me; no one cares about me.
142.5: I cry to You, LORD; I say, “You are my shelter, my portion in the land of the living.”
142.6: Listen to my cry, for I am very weak. Rescue me from those who pursue me, for they are too strong for me.
142.7: Free me from prison so that I can praise Your name. The righteous will gather around me because You deal generously with me.

143.1: A Davidic psalm. LORD, hear my prayer. In Your faithfulness listen to my plea, and in Your righteousness answer me.
143.2: Do not bring Your servant into judgment, for no one alive is righteous in Your sight.
143.3: For the enemy has pursued me, crushing me to the ground, making me live in darkness like those long dead.
143.4: My spirit is weak within me; my heart is overcome with dismay.
143.5: I remember the days of old; I meditate on all You have done; I reflect on the work of Your hands.
143.6: I spread out my hands to You; I am like parched land before You. Selah
143.7: Answer me quickly, LORD; my spirit fails. Don’t hide Your face from me, or I will be like those going down to the Pit.
143.8: Let me experience Your faithful love in the morning, for I trust in You. Reveal to me the way I should go because I long for You.
143.9: Rescue me from my enemies, LORD; I come to You for protection.
143.10: Teach me to do Your will, for You are my God. May Your gracious Spirit lead me on level ground.
143.11: Because of Your name, Yahweh, let me live. In Your righteousness deliver me from trouble,
143.12: and in Your faithful love destroy my enemies. Wipe out all those who attack me, for I am Your servant.

144.1: Davidic. May the LORD, my rock, be praised, who trains my hands for battle and my fingers for warfare.
144.2: He is my faithful love and my fortress, my stronghold and my deliverer. He is my shield, and I take refuge in Him; He subdues my people under me.
144.3: LORD, what is man, that You care for him, the son of man, that You think of him?
144.4: Man is like a breath; his days are like a passing shadow.
144.5: LORD, part Your heavens and come down. Touch the mountains, and they will smoke.
144.6: Flash Your lightning and scatter the foe; shoot Your arrows and rout them.
144.7: Reach down from heaven; rescue me from deep water, and set me free from the grasp of foreigners
144.8: whose mouths speak lies, whose right hands are deceptive.
144.9: God, I will sing a new song to You; I will play on a ten-stringed harp for You—
144.10: the One who gives victory to kings, who frees His servant David from the deadly sword.
144.11: Set me free and rescue me from the grasp of foreigners whose mouths speak lies, whose right hands are deceptive.
144.12: Then our sons will be like plants nurtured in their youth, our daughters, like corner pillars that are carved in the palace style.
144.13: Our storehouses will be full, supplying all kinds of produce; our flocks will increase by thousands and tens of thousands in our open fields.
144.14: Our cattle will be well fed. There will be no breach in the walls, no going into captivity, and no cry of lament in our public squares.
144.15: Happy are the people with such blessings. Happy are the people whose God is Yahweh.

145.1: A Davidic hymn. I exalt You, my God the King, and praise Your name forever and ever.
145.2: I will praise You every day; I will honor Your name forever and ever.
145.3: Yahweh is great and is highly praised; His greatness is unsearchable.
145.4: One generation will declare Your works to the next and will proclaim Your mighty acts.
145.5: I will speak of Your splendor and glorious majesty and Your wonderful works.
145.6: They will proclaim the power of Your awe-inspiring acts, and I will declare Your greatness.
145.7: They will give a testimony of Your great goodness and will joyfully sing of Your righteousness.
145.8: The LORD is gracious and compassionate, slow to anger and great in faithful love.
145.9: The LORD is good to everyone; His compassion rests on all He has made.
145.10: All You have made will thank You, LORD; the godly will praise You.
145.11: They will speak of the glory of Your kingdom and will declare Your might,
145.12: informing all people of Your mighty acts and of the glorious splendor of Your kingdom.
145.13: Your kingdom is an everlasting kingdom; Your rule is for all generations. The LORD is faithful in all His words and gracious in all His actions.
145.14: The LORD helps all who fall; He raises up all who are oppressed.
145.15: All eyes look to You, and You give them their food at the proper time.
145.16: You open Your hand and satisfy the desire of every living thing.
145.17: The LORD is righteous in all His ways and gracious in all His acts.
145.18: The LORD is near all who call out to Him, all who call out to Him with integrity.
145.19: He fulfills the desires of those who fear Him; He hears their cry for help and saves them.
145.20: The LORD guards all those who love Him, but He destroys all the wicked.
145.21: My mouth will declare Yahweh’s praise; let every living thing praise His holy name forever and ever.

146.1: Hallelujah! My soul, praise the LORD.
146.2: I will praise the LORD all my life; I will sing to my God as long as I live.
146.3: Do not trust in nobles, in man, who cannot save.
146.4: When his breath leaves him, he returns to the ground; on that day his plans die.
146.5: Happy is the one whose help is the God of Jacob, whose hope is in the LORD his God,
146.6: the Maker of heaven and earth, the sea and everything in them. He remains faithful forever,
146.7: executing justice for the exploited and giving food to the hungry. The LORD frees prisoners.
146.8: The LORD opens the eyes of the blind. The LORD raises up those who are oppressed. The LORD loves the righteous.
146.9: The LORD protects foreigners and helps the fatherless and the widow, but He frustrates the ways of the wicked.
146.10: The LORD reigns forever; Zion, your God reigns for all generations. Hallelujah!

147.1: Hallelujah! How good it is to sing to our God, for praise is pleasant and lovely.
147.2: The LORD rebuilds Jerusalem; He gathers Israel’s exiled people.
147.3: He heals the brokenhearted and binds up their wounds.
147.4: He counts the number of the stars; He gives names to all of them.
147.5: Our Lord is great, vast in power; His understanding is infinite.
147.6: The LORD helps the afflicted but brings the wicked to the ground.
147.7: Sing to the LORD with thanksgiving; play the lyre to our God,
147.8: who covers the sky with clouds, prepares rain for the earth, and causes grass to grow on the hills.
147.9: He provides the animals with their food, and the young ravens, what they cry for.
147.10: He is not impressed by the strength of a horse; He does not value the power of a man.
147.11: The LORD values those who fear Him, those who put their hope in His faithful love.
147.12: Exalt the LORD, Jerusalem; praise your God, Zion!
147.13: For He strengthens the bars of your gates and blesses your children within you.
147.14: He endows your territory with prosperity; He satisfies you with the finest wheat.
147.15: He sends His command throughout the earth; His word runs swiftly.
147.16: He spreads snow like wool; He scatters frost like ashes;
147.17: He throws His hailstones like crumbs. Who can withstand His cold?
147.18: He sends His word and melts them; He unleashes His winds, and the waters flow.
147.19: He declares His word to Jacob, His statutes and judgments to Israel.
147.20: He has not done this for any nation; they do not know His judgments. Hallelujah!

148.1: Hallelujah! Praise the LORD from the heavens; praise Him in the heights.
148.2: Praise Him, all His angels; praise Him, all His hosts.
148.3: Praise Him, sun and moon; praise Him, all you shining stars.
148.4: Praise Him, highest heavens, and you waters above the heavens.
148.5: Let them praise the name of Yahweh, for He commanded, and they were created.
148.6: He set them in position forever and ever; He gave an order that will never pass away.
148.7: Praise the LORD from the earth, all sea monsters and ocean depths,
148.8: lightning and hail, snow and cloud, powerful wind that executes His command,
148.9: mountains and all hills, fruit trees and all cedars,
148.10: wild animals and all cattle, creatures that crawl and flying birds,
148.11: kings of the earth and all peoples, princes and all judges of the earth,
148.12: young men as well as young women, old and young together.
148.13: Let them praise the name of Yahweh, for His name alone is exalted. His majesty covers heaven and earth.
148.14: He has raised up a horn for His people, resulting in praise to all His godly ones, to the Israelites, the people close to Him. Hallelujah!

149.1: Hallelujah! Sing to the LORD a new song, His praise in the assembly of the godly.
149.2: Let Israel celebrate its Maker; let the children of Zion rejoice in their King.
149.3: Let them praise His name with dancing and make music to Him with tambourine and lyre.
149.4: For Yahweh takes pleasure in His people; He adorns the humble with salvation.
149.5: Let the godly celebrate in triumphal glory; let them shout for joy on their beds.
149.6: Let the exaltation of God be in their mouths and a double-edged sword in their hands,
149.7: inflicting vengeance on the nations and punishment on the peoples,
149.8: binding their kings with chains and their dignitaries with iron shackles,
149.9: carrying out the judgment decreed against them. This honor is for all His godly people. Hallelujah!

150.1: Hallelujah! Praise God in His sanctuary. Praise Him in His mighty heavens.
150.2: Praise Him for His powerful acts; praise Him for His abundant greatness.
150.3: Praise Him with trumpet blast; praise Him with harp and lyre.
150.4: Praise Him with tambourine and dance; praise Him with flute and strings.
150.5: Praise Him with resounding cymbals; praise Him with clashing cymbals.
150.6: Let everything that breathes praise the LORD. Hallelujah!

1.1: The proverbs of Solomon son of David, king of Israel:
1.2: For learning what wisdom and discipline are; for understanding insightful sayings;
1.3: for receiving wise instruction in righteousness, justice, and integrity;
1.4: for teaching shrewdness to the inexperienced, knowledge and discretion to a young man—
1.5: a wise man will listen and increase his learning, and a discerning man will obtain guidance—
1.6: for understanding a proverb or a parable, the words of the wise, and their riddles.
1.7: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge; fools despise wisdom and discipline.
1.8: Listen, my son, to your father’s instruction, and don’t reject your mother’s teaching,
1.9: for they will be a garland of grace on your head and a gold chain around your neck.
1.10: My son, if sinners entice you, don’t be persuaded.
1.11: If they say—"Come with us! Let’s set an ambush and kill someone. Let’s attack some innocent person just for fun!
1.12: Let’s swallow them alive, like Sheol, still healthy as they go down to the Pit.
1.13: We’ll find all kinds of valuable property and fill our houses with plunder.
1.14: Throw in your lot with us, and we’ll all share our money"—
1.15: my son, don’t travel that road with them or set foot on their path,
1.16: because their feet run toward trouble and they hurry to commit murder.
1.17: It is foolish to spread a net where any bird can see it,
1.18: but they set an ambush to kill themselves; they attack their own lives.
1.19: Such are the paths of all who make profit dishonestly; it takes the lives of those who receive it.
1.20: Wisdom calls out in the street; she raises her voice in the public squares.
1.21: She cries out above the commotion; she speaks at the entrance of the city gates:”
1.22: How long, foolish ones, will you love ignorance? How long will you mockers enjoy mocking and you fools hate knowledge?
1.23: If you respond to my warning, then I will pour out my spirit on you and teach you my words.
1.24: Since I called out and you refused, extended my hand and no one paid attention,
1.25: since you neglected all my counsel and did not accept my correction,
1.26: I, in turn, will laugh at your calamity. I will mock when terror strikes you,
1.27: when terror strikes you like a storm and your calamity comes like a whirlwind, when trouble and stress overcome you.
1.28: Then they will call me, but I won’t answer; they will search for me, but won’t find me.
1.29: Because they hated knowledge, didn’t choose to fear the LORD,
1.30: were not interested in my counsel, and rejected all my correction,
1.31: they will eat the fruit of their way and be glutted with their own schemes.
1.32: For the turning away of the inexperienced will kill them, and the complacency of fools will destroy them.
1.33: But whoever listens to me will live securely and be free from the fear of danger.”

2.1: My son, if you accept my words and store up my commands within you,
2.2: listening closely to wisdom and directing your heart to understanding;
2.3: furthermore, if you call out to insight and lift your voice to understanding,
2.4: if you seek it like silver and search for it like hidden treasure,
2.5: then you will understand the fear of the LORD and discover the knowledge of God.
2.6: For the LORD gives wisdom; from His mouth come knowledge and understanding.
2.7: He stores up success for the upright; He is a shield for those who live with integrity
2.8: so that He may guard the paths of justice and protect the way of His loyal followers.
2.9: Then you will understand righteousness, justice, and integrity—every good path.
2.10: For wisdom will enter your mind, and knowledge will delight your heart.
2.11: Discretion will watch over you, and understanding will guard you,
2.12: rescuing you from the way of evil— from the one who says perverse things,
2.13: from those who abandon the right paths to walk in ways of darkness,
2.14: from those who enjoy doing evil and celebrate perversion,
2.15: whose paths are crooked, and whose ways are devious.
2.16: It will rescue you from a forbidden woman, from a stranger with her flattering talk,
2.17: who abandons the companion of her youth and forgets the covenant of her God;
2.18: for her house sinks down to death and her ways to the land of the departed spirits.
2.19: None return who go to her; none reach the paths of life.
2.20: So follow the way of good people, and keep to the paths of the righteous.
2.21: For the upright will inhabit the land, and those of integrity will remain in it;
2.22: but the wicked will be cut off from the land, and the treacherous uprooted from it.

3.1: My son, don’t forget my teaching, but let your heart keep my commands;
3.2: for they will bring you many days, a full life, and well-being.
3.3: Never let loyalty and faithfulness leave you. Tie them around your neck; write them on the tablet of your heart.
3.4: Then you will find favor and high regard in the sight of God and man.
3.5: Trust in the LORD with all your heart, and do not rely on your own understanding;
3.6: think about Him in all your ways, and He will guide you on the right paths.
3.7: Don’t consider yourself to be wise; fear the LORD and turn away from evil.
3.8: This will be healing for your body and strengthening for your bones.
3.9: Honor the LORD with your possessions and with the first produce of your entire harvest;
3.10: then your barns will be completely filled, and your vats will overflow with new wine.
3.11: Do not despise the LORD’s instruction, my son, and do not loathe His discipline;
3.12: for the LORD disciplines the one He loves, just as a father, the son he delights in.
3.13: Happy is a man who finds wisdom and who acquires understanding,
3.14: for she is more profitable than silver, and her revenue is better than gold.
3.15: She is more precious than jewels; nothing you desire compares with her.
3.16: Long life is in her right hand; in her left, riches and honor.
3.17: Her ways are pleasant, and all her paths, peaceful.
3.18: She is a tree of life to those who embrace her, and those who hold on to her are happy.
3.19: The LORD founded the earth by wisdom and established the heavens by understanding.
3.20: By His knowledge the watery depths broke open, and the clouds dripped with dew.
3.21: Maintain your competence and discretion. My son, don’t lose sight of them.
3.22: They will be life for you and adornment for your neck.
3.23: Then you will go safely on your way; your foot will not stumble.
3.24: When you lie down, you will not be afraid; you will lie down, and your sleep will be pleasant.
3.25: Don’t fear sudden danger or the ruin of the wicked when it comes,
3.26: for the LORD will be your confidence and will keep your foot from a snare.
3.27: When it is in your power, don’t withhold good from the one it belongs to.
3.28: Don’t say to your neighbor, “Go away! Come back later. I’ll give it tomorrow"—when it is there with you.
3.29: Don’t plan any harm against your neighbor, for he trusts you and lives near you.
3.30: Don’t accuse anyone without cause, when he has done you no harm.
3.31: Don’t envy a violent man or choose any of his ways;
3.32: for the devious are detestable to the LORD, but He is a friend to the upright.
3.33: The LORD’s curse is on the household of the wicked, but He blesses the home of the righteous;
3.34: He mocks those who mock, but gives grace to the humble.
3.35: The wise will inherit honor, but He holds up fools to dishonor.

4.1: Listen, my sons, to a father’s discipline, and pay attention so that you may gain understanding,
4.2: for I am giving you good instruction. Don’t abandon my teaching.
4.3: When I was a son with my father, tender and precious to my mother,
4.4: he taught me and said:” Your heart must hold on to my words. Keep my commands and live.
4.5: Get wisdom, get understanding; don’t forget or turn away from the words of my mouth.
4.6: Don’t abandon wisdom, and she will watch over you; love her, and she will guard you.
4.7: Wisdom is supreme—so get wisdom. And whatever else you get, get understanding.
4.8: Cherish her, and she will exalt you; if you embrace her, she will honor you.
4.9: She will place a garland of grace on your head; she will give you a crown of beauty.”
4.10: Listen, my son. Accept my words, and you will live many years.
4.11: I am teaching you the way of wisdom; I am guiding you on straight paths.
4.12: When you walk, your steps will not be hindered; when you run, you will not stumble.
4.13: Hold on to instruction; don’t let go. Guard it, for it is your life.
4.14: Don’t set foot on the path of the wicked; don’t proceed in the way of evil ones.
4.15: Avoid it; don’t travel on it. Turn away from it, and pass it by.
4.16: For they can’t sleep unless they have done what is evil; they are robbed of sleep unless they make someone stumble.
4.17: They eat the bread of wickedness and drink the wine of violence.
4.18: The path of the righteous is like the light of dawn, shining brighter and brighter until midday.
4.19: But the way of the wicked is like the darkest gloom; they don’t know what makes them stumble.
4.20: My son, pay attention to my words; listen closely to my sayings.
4.21: Don’t lose sight of them; keep them within your heart.
4.22: For they are life to those who find them, and health to one’s whole body.
4.23: Guard your heart above all else, for it is the source of life.
4.24: Don’t let your mouth speak dishonestly, and don’t let your lips talk deviously.
4.25: Let your eyes look forward; fix your gaze straight ahead.
4.26: Carefully consider the path for your feet, and all your ways will be established.
4.27: Don’t turn to the right or to the left; keep your feet away from evil.

5.1: My son, pay attention to my wisdom; listen closely to my understanding
5.2: so that you may maintain discretion and your lips safeguard knowledge.
5.3: Though the lips of the forbidden woman drip honey and her words are smoother than oil,
5.4: in the end she’s as bitter as wormwood and as sharp as a double-edged sword.
5.5: Her feet go down to death; her steps head straight for Sheol.
5.6: She doesn’t consider the path of life; she doesn’t know that her ways are unstable.
5.7: So now, my sons, listen to me, and don’t turn away from the words of my mouth.
5.8: Keep your way far from her. Don’t go near the door of her house.
5.9: Otherwise, you will give up your vitality to others and your years to someone cruel;
5.10: strangers will drain your resources, and your earnings will end up in a foreigner’s house.
5.11: At the end of your life, you will lament when your physical body has been consumed,
5.12: and you will say, “How I hated discipline, and how my heart despised correction.
5.13: I didn’t obey my teachers or listen closely to my mentors.
5.14: I am on the verge of complete ruin before the entire community.”
5.15: Drink water from your own cistern, water flowing from your own well.
5.16: Should your springs flow in the streets, streams of water in the public squares?
5.17: They should be for you alone and not for you to share with strangers.
5.18: Let your fountain be blessed, and take pleasure in the wife of your youth.
5.19: A loving doe, a graceful fawn— let her breasts always satisfy you; be lost in her love forever.
5.20: Why, my son, would you be infatuated with a forbidden woman or embrace the breast of a stranger?
5.21: For a man’s ways are before the LORD’s eyes, and He considers all his paths.
5.22: A wicked man’s iniquities entrap him; he is entangled in the ropes of his own sin.
5.23: He will die because there is no discipline, and be lost because of his great stupidity.

6.1: My son, if you have put up security for your neighbor or entered into an agreement with a stranger,
6.2: you have been trapped by the words of your lips— ensnared by the words of your mouth.
6.3: Do this, then, my son, and free yourself, for you have put yourself in your neighbor’s power: Go, humble yourself, and plead with your neighbor.
6.4: Don’t give sleep to your eyes or slumber to your eyelids.
6.5: Escape like a gazelle from a hunter, like a bird from a fowler’s trap.
6.6: Go to the ant, you slacker! Observe its ways and become wise.
6.7: Without leader, administrator, or ruler,
6.8: it prepares its provisions in summer; it gathers its food during harvest.
6.9: How long will you stay in bed, you slacker? When will you get up from your sleep?
6.10: A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the arms to rest,
6.11: and your poverty will come like a robber, your need, like a bandit.
6.12: A worthless person, a wicked man goes around speaking dishonestly,
6.13: winking his eyes, signaling with his feet, and gesturing with his fingers.
6.14: He always plots evil with perversity in his heart— he stirs up trouble.
6.15: Therefore calamity will strike him suddenly; he will be shattered instantly—beyond recovery.
6.16: The LORD hates six things; in fact, seven are detestable to Him:
6.17: arrogant eyes, a lying tongue, hands that shed innocent blood,
6.18: a heart that plots wicked schemes, feet eager to run to evil,
6.19: a lying witness who gives false testimony, and one who stirs up trouble among brothers.
6.20: My son, keep your father’s command, and don’t reject your mother’s teaching.
6.21: Always bind them to your heart; tie them around your neck.
6.22: When you walk here and there, they will guide you; when you lie down, they will watch over you; when you wake up, they will talk to you.
6.23: For a command is a lamp, teaching is a light, and corrective discipline is the way to life.
6.24: They will protect you from an evil woman, from the flattering tongue of a stranger.
6.25: Don’t lust in your heart for her beauty or let her captivate you with her eyelashes.
6.26: For a prostitute’s fee is only a loaf of bread, but an adulteress goes after a precious life.
6.27: Can a man embrace fire and his clothes not be burned?
6.28: Can a man walk on burning coals without scorching his feet?
6.29: So it is with the one who sleeps with another man’s wife; no one who touches her will go unpunished.
6.30: People don’t despise the thief if he steals to satisfy himself when he is hungry.
6.31: Still, if caught, he must pay seven times as much; he must give up all the wealth in his house.
6.32: The one who commits adultery lacks sense; whoever does so destroys himself.
6.33: He will get a beating and dishonor, and his disgrace will never be removed.
6.34: For jealousy enrages a husband, and he will show no mercy when he takes revenge.
6.35: He will not be appeased by anything or be persuaded by lavish gifts.

7.1: My son, obey my words, and treasure my commands.
7.2: Keep my commands and live; protect my teachings as the pupil of your eye.
7.3: Tie them to your fingers; write them on the tablet of your heart.
7.4: Say to wisdom, “You are my sister,” and call understanding your relative.
7.5: She will keep you from a forbidden woman, a stranger with her flattering talk.
7.6: At the window of my house I looked through my lattice.
7.7: I saw among the inexperienced, I noticed among the youths, a young man lacking sense.
7.8: Crossing the street near her corner, he strolled down the road to her house
7.9: at twilight, in the evening, in the dark of the night.
7.10: A woman came to meet him dressed like a prostitute, having a hidden agenda.
7.11: She is loud and defiant; her feet do not stay at home.
7.12: Now in the street, now in the squares, she lurks at every corner.
7.13: She grabs him and kisses him; she brazenly says to him,”
7.14: I’ve made fellowship offerings; today I’ve fulfilled my vows.
7.15: So I came out to meet you, to search for you, and I’ve found you.
7.16: I’ve spread coverings on my bed— richly colored linen from Egypt.
7.17: I’ve perfumed my bed with myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.
7.18: Come, let’s drink deeply of lovemaking until morning. Let’s feast on each other’s love!
7.19: My husband isn’t home; he went on a long journey.
7.20: He took a bag of money with him and will come home at the time of the full moon.”
7.21: She seduces him with her persistent pleading; she lures with her flattering talk.
7.22: He follows her impulsively like an ox going to the slaughter, like a deer bounding toward a trap
7.23: until an arrow pierces its liver, like a bird darting into a snare— he doesn’t know it will cost him his life.
7.24: Now, my sons, listen to me, and pay attention to the words of my mouth.
7.25: Don’t let your heart turn aside to her ways; don’t stray onto her paths.
7.26: For she has brought many down to death; her victims are countless.
7.27: Her house is the road to Sheol, descending to the chambers of death.

8.1: Doesn’t Wisdom call out? Doesn’t Understanding make her voice heard?
8.2: At the heights overlooking the road, at the crossroads, she takes her stand.
8.3: Beside the gates at the entry to the city, at the main entrance, she cries out:”
8.4: People, I call out to you; my cry is to mankind.
8.5: Learn to be shrewd, you who are inexperienced; develop common sense, you who are foolish.
8.6: Listen, for I speak of noble things, and what my lips say is right.
8.7: For my mouth tells the truth, and wickedness is detestable to my lips.
8.8: All the words of my mouth are righteous; none of them are deceptive or perverse.
8.9: All of them are clear to the perceptive, and right to those who discover knowledge.
8.10: Accept my instruction instead of silver, and knowledge rather than pure gold.
8.11: For wisdom is better than jewels, and nothing desirable can compare with it.
8.12: I, Wisdom, share a home with shrewdness and have knowledge and discretion.
8.13: To fear the LORD is to hate evil. I hate arrogant pride, evil conduct, and perverse speech.
8.14: I possess good advice and competence; I have understanding and strength.
8.15: It is by me that kings reign and rulers enact just law;
8.16: by me, princes lead, as do nobles and all righteous judges.
8.17: I love those who love me, and those who search for me find me.
8.18: With me are riches and honor, lasting wealth and righteousness.
8.19: My fruit is better than solid gold, and my harvest than pure silver.
8.20: I walk in the way of righteousness, along the paths of justice,
8.21: giving wealth as an inheritance to those who love me, and filling their treasuries.”
8.22: The LORD made me at the beginning of His creation, before His works of long ago.
8.23: I was formed before ancient times, from the beginning, before the earth began.
8.24: I was born when there were no watery depths and no springs filled with water.
8.25: I was delivered before the mountains and hills were established,
8.26: before He made the land, the fields, or the first soil on earth.
8.27: I was there when He established the heavens, when He laid out the horizon on the surface of the ocean,
8.28: when He placed the skies above, when the fountains of the ocean gushed out,
8.29: when He set a limit for the sea so that the waters would not violate His command, when He laid out the foundations of the earth.
8.30: I was a skilled craftsman beside Him. I was His delight every day, always rejoicing before Him.
8.31: I was rejoicing in His inhabited world, delighting in the human race.”
8.32: And now, my sons, listen to me; those who keep my ways are happy.
8.33: Listen to instruction and be wise; don’t ignore it.
8.34: Anyone who listens to me is happy, watching at my doors every day, waiting by the posts of my doorway.
8.35: For the one who finds me finds life and obtains favor from the LORD,
8.36: but the one who misses me harms himself; all who hate me love death.”

9.1: Wisdom has built her house; she has carved out her seven pillars.
9.2: She has prepared her meat; she has mixed her wine; she has also set her table.
9.3: She has sent out her female servants; she calls out from the highest points of the city:”
9.4: Whoever is inexperienced, enter here!” To the one who lacks sense, she says,”
9.5: Come, eat my bread, and drink the wine I have mixed.
9.6: Leave inexperience behind, and you will live; pursue the way of understanding.
9.7: The one who corrects a mocker will bring dishonor on himself; the one who rebukes a wicked man will get hurt.
9.8: Don’t rebuke a mocker, or he will hate you; rebuke a wise man, and he will love you.
9.9: Instruct a wise man, and he will be wiser still; teach a righteous man, and he will learn more.”
9.10: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom, and the knowledge of the Holy One is understanding.
9.11: For by Wisdom your days will be many, and years will be added to your life.
9.12: If you are wise, you are wise for your own benefit; if you mock, you alone will bear the consequences.”
9.13: The woman Folly is rowdy; she is gullible and knows nothing.
9.14: She sits by the doorway of her house, on a seat at the highest point of the city,
9.15: calling to those who pass by, who go straight ahead on their paths:”
9.16: Whoever is inexperienced, enter here!” To the one who lacks sense, she says,”
9.17: Stolen water is sweet, and bread eaten secretly is tasty!”
9.18: But he doesn’t know that the departed spirits are there, that her guests are in the depths of Sheol.

10.1: Solomon’s proverbs: A wise son brings joy to his father, but a foolish son, heartache to his mother.
10.2: Ill-gotten gains do not profit anyone, but righteousness rescues from death.
10.3: The LORD will not let the righteous go hungry, but He denies the wicked what they crave.
10.4: Idle hands make one poor, but diligent hands bring riches.
10.5: The son who gathers during summer is prudent; the son who sleeps during harvest is disgraceful.
10.6: Blessings are on the head of the righteous, but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.
10.7: The remembrance of the righteous is a blessing, but the name of the wicked will rot.
10.8: A wise heart accepts commands, but foolish lips will be destroyed.
10.9: The one who lives with integrity lives securely, but whoever perverts his ways will be found out.
10.10: A sly wink of the eye causes grief, and foolish lips will be destroyed.
10.11: The mouth of the righteous is a fountain of life, but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.
10.12: Hatred stirs up conflicts, but love covers all offenses.
10.13: Wisdom is found on the lips of the discerning, but a rod is for the back of the one who lacks sense.
10.14: The wise store up knowledge, but the mouth of the fool hastens destruction.
10.15: A rich man’s wealth is his fortified city; the poverty of the poor is their destruction.
10.16: The labor of the righteous leads to life; the activity of the wicked leads to sin.
10.17: The one who follows instruction is on the path to life, but the one who rejects correction goes astray.
10.18: The one who conceals hatred has lying lips, and whoever spreads slander is a fool.
10.19: When there are many words, sin is unavoidable, but the one who controls his lips is wise.
10.20: The tongue of the righteous is pure silver; the heart of the wicked is of little value.
10.21: The lips of the righteous feed many, but fools die for lack of sense.
10.22: The LORD’s blessing enriches, and struggle adds nothing to it.
10.23: As shameful conduct is pleasure for a fool, so wisdom is for a man of understanding.
10.24: What the wicked dreads will come to him, but what the righteous desire will be given to them.
10.25: When the whirlwind passes, the wicked are no more, but the righteous are secure forever.
10.26: Like vinegar to the teeth and smoke to the eyes, so the slacker is to the one who sends him on an errand.
10.27: The fear of the LORD prolongs life, but the years of the wicked are cut short.
10.28: The hope of the righteous is joy, but the expectation of the wicked comes to nothing.
10.29: The way of the LORD is a stronghold for the honorable, but destruction awaits the malicious.
10.30: The righteous will never be shaken, but the wicked will not remain on the earth.
10.31: The mouth of the righteous produces wisdom, but a perverse tongue will be cut out.
10.32: The lips of the righteous know what is appropriate, but the mouth of the wicked, only what is perverse.

11.1: Dishonest scales are detestable to the LORD, but an accurate weight is His delight.
11.2: When pride comes, disgrace follows, but with humility comes wisdom.
11.3: The integrity of the upright guides them, but the perversity of the treacherous destroys them.
11.4: Wealth is not profitable on a day of wrath, but righteousness rescues from death.
11.5: The righteousness of the blameless clears his path, but the wicked person will fall because of his wickedness.
11.6: The righteousness of the upright rescues them, but the treacherous are trapped by their own desires.
11.7: When the wicked man dies, his expectation comes to nothing, and hope placed in wealth vanishes.
11.8: The righteous one is rescued from trouble; in his place, the wicked one goes in.
11.9: With his mouth the ungodly destroys his neighbor, but through knowledge the righteous are rescued.
11.10: When the righteous thrive, a city rejoices, and when the wicked die, there is joyful shouting.
11.11: A city is built up by the blessing of the upright, but it is torn down by the mouth of the wicked.
11.12: Whoever shows contempt for his neighbor lacks sense, but a man with understanding keeps silent.
11.13: A gossip goes around revealing a secret, but a trustworthy person keeps a confidence.
11.14: Without guidance, people fall, but with many counselors there is deliverance.
11.15: If someone puts up security for a stranger, he will suffer for it, but the one who hates such agreements is protected.
11.16: A gracious woman gains honor, but violent men gain only riches.
11.17: A kind man benefits himself, but a cruel man brings disaster on himself.
11.18: The wicked man earns an empty wage, but the one who sows righteousness, a true reward.
11.19: Genuine righteousness leads to life, but pursuing evil leads to death.
11.20: Those with twisted minds are detestable to the LORD, but those with blameless conduct are His delight.
11.21: Be assured that the wicked will not go unpunished, but the offspring of the righteous will escape.
11.22: A beautiful woman who rejects good sense is like a gold ring in a pig’s snout.
11.23: The desire of the righteous turns out well, but the hope of the wicked leads to wrath.
11.24: One person gives freely, yet gains more; another withholds what is right, only to become poor.
11.25: A generous person will be enriched, and the one who gives a drink of water will receive water.
11.26: People will curse anyone who hoards grain, but a blessing will come to the one who sells it.
11.27: The one who searches for what is good finds favor, but if someone looks for trouble, it will come to him.
11.28: Anyone trusting in his riches will fall, but the righteous will flourish like foliage.
11.29: The one who brings ruin on his household will inherit the wind, and a fool will be a slave to someone whose heart is wise.
11.30: The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life, but violence takes lives.
11.31: If the righteous will be repaid on earth, how much more the wicked and sinful.

12.1: Whoever loves discipline loves knowledge, but one who hates correction is stupid.
12.2: The good person obtains favor from the LORD, but He condemns a man who schemes.
12.3: Man cannot be made secure by wickedness, but the root of the righteous is immovable.
12.4: A capable wife is her husband’s crown, but a wife who causes shame is like rottenness in his bones.
12.5: The thoughts of the righteous are just, but guidance from the wicked leads to deceit.
12.6: The words of the wicked are a deadly ambush, but the speech of the upright rescues them.
12.7: The wicked are overthrown and perish, but the house of the righteous will stand.
12.8: A man is praised for his insight, but a twisted mind is despised.
12.9: Better to be dishonored, yet have a servant, than to act important but have no food.
12.10: A righteous man cares about his animal’s health, but even the merciful acts of the wicked are cruel.
12.11: The one who works his land will have plenty of food, but whoever chases fantasies lacks sense.
12.12: The wicked desire what evil men have, but the root of the righteous produces fruit.
12.13: An evil man is trapped by his rebellious speech, but a righteous one escapes from trouble.
12.14: A man will be satisfied with good by the words of his mouth, and the work of a man’s hands will reward him.
12.15: A fool’s way is right in his own eyes, but whoever listens to counsel is wise.
12.16: A fool’s displeasure is known at once, but whoever ignores an insult is sensible.
12.17: Whoever speaks the truth declares what is right, but a false witness, deceit.
12.18: There is one who speaks rashly, like a piercing sword; but the tongue of the wise brings healing.
12.19: Truthful lips endure forever, but a lying tongue, only a moment.
12.20: Deceit is in the hearts of those who plot evil, but those who promote peace have joy.
12.21: No disaster overcomes the righteous, but the wicked are full of misery.
12.22: Lying lips are detestable to the LORD, but faithful people are His delight.
12.23: A shrewd person conceals knowledge, but a foolish heart publicizes stupidity.
12.24: The diligent hand will rule, but laziness will lead to forced labor.
12.25: Anxiety in a man’s heart weighs it down, but a good word cheers it up.
12.26: A righteous man is careful in dealing with his neighbor, but the ways of the wicked lead them astray.
12.27: A lazy man doesn’t roast his game, but to a diligent man, his wealth is precious.
12.28: There is life in the path of righteousness, but another path leads to death.

13.1: A wise son responds to his father’s discipline, but a mocker doesn’t listen to rebuke.
13.2: From the words of his mouth, a man will enjoy good things, but treacherous people have an appetite for violence.
13.3: The one who guards his mouth protects his life; the one who opens his lips invites his own ruin.
13.4: The slacker craves, yet has nothing, but the diligent is fully satisfied.
13.5: The righteous hate lying, but the wicked act disgustingly and disgracefully.
13.6: Righteousness guards people of integrity, but wickedness undermines the sinner.
13.7: One man pretends to be rich but has nothing; another pretends to be poor but has great wealth.
13.8: Riches are a ransom for a man’s life, but a poor man hears no threat.
13.9: The light of the righteous shines brightly, but the lamp of the wicked is put out.
13.10: Arrogance leads to nothing but strife, but wisdom is gained by those who take advice.
13.11: Wealth obtained by fraud will dwindle, but whoever earns it through labor will multiply it.
13.12: Delayed hope makes the heart sick, but fulfilled desire is a tree of life.
13.13: The one who has contempt for instruction will pay the penalty, but the one who respects a command will be rewarded.
13.14: A wise man’s instruction is a fountain of life, turning people away from the snares of death.
13.15: Good sense wins favor, but the way of the treacherous never changes.
13.16: Every sensible person acts knowledgeably, but a fool displays his stupidity.
13.17: A wicked messenger falls into trouble, but a trustworthy courier brings healing.
13.18: Poverty and disgrace come to those who ignore discipline, but the one who accepts correction will be honored.
13.19: Desire fulfilled is sweet to the taste, but to turn from evil is an abomination to fools.
13.20: The one who walks with the wise will become wise, but a companion of fools will suffer harm.
13.21: Disaster pursues sinners, but good rewards the righteous.
13.22: A good man leaves an inheritance to his grandchildren, but the sinner’s wealth is stored up for the righteous.
13.23: The uncultivated field of the poor yields abundant food, but without justice, it is swept away.
13.24: The one who will not use the rod hates his son, but the one who loves him disciplines him diligently.
13.25: A righteous man eats until he is satisfied, but the stomach of the wicked is empty.

14.1: Every wise woman builds her house, but a foolish one tears it down with her own hands.
14.2: Whoever lives with integrity fears the LORD, but the one who is devious in his ways despises Him.
14.3: The proud speech of a fool brings a rod of discipline, but the lips of the wise protect them.
14.4: Where there are no oxen, the feeding trough is empty, but an abundant harvest comes through the strength of an ox.
14.5: An honest witness does not deceive, but a dishonest witness utters lies.
14.6: A mocker seeks wisdom and doesn’t find it, but knowledge comes easily to the perceptive.
14.7: Stay away from a foolish man; you will gain no knowledge from his speech.
14.8: The sensible man’s wisdom is to consider his way, but the stupidity of fools deceives them.
14.9: Fools mock at making restitution, but there is goodwill among the upright.
14.10: The heart knows its own bitterness, and no outsider shares in its joy.
14.11: The house of the wicked will be destroyed, but the tent of the upright will stand.
14.12: There is a way that seems right to a man, but its end is the way to death.
14.13: Even in laughter a heart may be sad, and joy may end in grief.
14.14: The disloyal one will get what his conduct deserves, and a good man, what his deeds deserve.
14.15: The inexperienced one believes anything, but the sensible one watches his steps.
14.16: A wise man is cautious and turns from evil, but a fool is easily angered and is careless.
14.17: A quick-tempered man acts foolishly, and a man who schemes is hated.
14.18: The inexperienced inherit foolishness, but the sensible are crowned with knowledge.
14.19: The evil bow before those who are good, the wicked, at the gates of the righteous.
14.20: A poor man is hated even by his neighbor, but there are many who love the rich.
14.21: The one who despises his neighbor sins, but whoever shows kindness to the poor will be happy.
14.22: Don’t those who plan evil go astray? But those who plan good find loyalty and faithfulness.
14.23: There is profit in all hard work, but endless talk leads only to poverty.
14.24: The crown of the wise is their wealth, but the foolishness of fools produces foolishness.
14.25: A truthful witness rescues lives, but one who utters lies is deceitful.
14.26: In the fear of the LORD one has strong confidence and his children have a refuge.
14.27: The fear of the LORD is a fountain of life, turning people away from the snares of death.
14.28: A large population is a king’s splendor, but a shortage of people is a ruler’s devastation.
14.29: A patient person shows great understanding, but a quick-tempered one promotes foolishness.
14.30: A tranquil heart is life to the body, but jealousy is rottenness to the bones.
14.31: The one who oppresses the poor person insults his Maker, but one who is kind to the needy honors Him.
14.32: The wicked one is thrown down by his own sin, but the righteous one has a refuge in his death.
14.33: Wisdom resides in the heart of the discerning; she is known even among fools.
14.34: Righteousness exalts a nation, but sin is a disgrace to any people.
14.35: A king favors a wise servant, but his anger falls on a disgraceful one.

15.1: A gentle answer turns away anger, but a harsh word stirs up wrath.
15.2: The tongue of the wise makes knowledge attractive, but the mouth of fools blurts out foolishness.
15.3: The eyes of the LORD are everywhere, observing the wicked and the good.
15.4: The tongue that heals is a tree of life, but a devious tongue breaks the spirit.
15.5: A fool despises his father’s discipline, but a person who accepts correction is sensible.
15.6: The house of the righteous has great wealth, but trouble accompanies the income of the wicked.
15.7: The lips of the wise broadcast knowledge, but not so the heart of fools.
15.8: The sacrifice of the wicked is detestable to the LORD, but the prayer of the upright is His delight.
15.9: The LORD detests the way of the wicked, but He loves the one who pursues righteousness.
15.10: Discipline is harsh for the one who leaves the path; the one who hates correction will die.
15.11: Sheol and Abaddon lie open before the LORD— how much more, human hearts.
15.12: A mocker doesn’t love one who corrects him; he will not consult the wise.
15.13: A joyful heart makes a face cheerful, but a sad heart produces a broken spirit.
15.14: A discerning mind seeks knowledge, but the mouth of fools feeds on foolishness.
15.15: All the days of the oppressed are miserable, but a cheerful heart has a continual feast.
15.16: Better a little with the fear of the LORD than great treasure with turmoil.
15.17: Better a meal of vegetables where there is love than a fattened ox with hatred.
15.18: A hot-tempered man stirs up conflict, but a man slow to anger calms strife.
15.19: A slacker’s way is like a thorny hedge, but the path of the upright is a highway.
15.20: A wise son brings joy to his father, but a foolish man despises his mother.
15.21: Foolishness brings joy to one without sense, but a man with understanding walks a straight path.
15.22: Plans fail when there is no counsel, but with many advisers they succeed.
15.23: A man takes joy in giving an answer; and a timely word—how good that is!
15.24: For the discerning the path of life leads upward, so that he may avoid going down to Sheol.
15.25: The LORD destroys the house of the proud, but He protects the widow’s territory.
15.26: The LORD detests the plans of an evil man, but pleasant words are pure.
15.27: The one who profits dishonestly troubles his household, but the one who hates bribes will live.
15.28: The mind of the righteous person thinks before answering, but the mouth of the wicked blurts out evil things.
15.29: The LORD is far from the wicked, but He hears the prayer of the righteous.
15.30: Bright eyes cheer the heart; good news strengthens the bones.
15.31: One who listens to life-giving rebukes will be at home among the wise.
15.32: Anyone who ignores discipline despises himself, but whoever listens to correction acquires good sense.
15.33: The fear of the LORD is what wisdom teaches, and humility comes before honor.

16.1: The reflections of the heart belong to man, but the answer of the tongue is from the LORD.
16.2: All a man’s ways seem right to him, but the LORD evaluates the motives.
16.3: Commit your activities to the LORD, and your plans will be achieved.
16.4: The LORD has prepared everything for His purpose— even the wicked for the day of disaster.
16.5: Everyone with a proud heart is detestable to the LORD; be assured, he will not go unpunished.
16.6: Wickedness is atoned for by loyalty and faithfulness, and one turns from evil by the fear of the LORD.
16.7: When a man’s ways please the LORD, He makes even his enemies to be at peace with him.
16.8: Better a little with righteousness than great income with injustice.
16.9: A man’s heart plans his way, but the LORD determines his steps.
16.10: God’s verdict is on the lips of a king; his mouth should not give an unfair judgment.
16.11: Honest balances and scales are the LORD’s; all the weights in the bag are His concern.
16.12: Wicked behavior is detestable to kings, since a throne is established through righteousness.
16.13: Righteous lips are a king’s delight, and he loves one who speaks honestly.
16.14: A king’s fury is a messenger of death, but a wise man appeases it.
16.15: When a king’s face lights up, there is life; his favor is like a cloud with spring rain.
16.16: Get wisdom— how much better it is than gold! And get understanding— it is preferable to silver.
16.17: The highway of the upright avoids evil; the one who guards his way protects his life.
16.18: Pride comes before destruction, and an arrogant spirit before a fall.
16.19: Better to be lowly of spirit with the humble than to divide plunder with the proud.
16.20: The one who understands a matter finds success, and the one who trusts in the LORD will be happy.
16.21: Anyone with a wise heart is called discerning, and pleasant speech increases learning.
16.22: Insight is a fountain of life for its possessor, but the discipline of fools is folly.
16.23: A wise heart instructs its mouth and increases learning with its speech.
16.24: Pleasant words are a honeycomb: sweet to the taste and health to the body.
16.25: There is a way that seems right to a man, but its end is the way to death.
16.26: A worker’s appetite works for him because his hunger urges him on.
16.27: A worthless man digs up evil, and his speech is like a scorching fire.
16.28: A contrary man spreads conflict, and a gossip separates close friends.
16.29: A violent man lures his neighbor, leading him in a way that is not good.
16.30: The one who narrows his eyes is planning deceptions; the one who compresses his lips brings about evil.
16.31: Gray hair is a glorious crown; it is found in the way of righteousness.
16.32: Patience is better than power, and controlling one’s temper, than capturing a city.
16.33: The lot is cast into the lap, but its every decision is from the LORD.

17.1: Better a dry crust with peace than a house full of feasting with strife.
17.2: A wise servant will rule over a disgraceful son and share an inheritance among brothers.
17.3: A crucible for silver, and a smelter for gold, and the LORD is the tester of hearts.
17.4: A wicked person listens to malicious talk; a liar pays attention to a destructive tongue.
17.5: The one who mocks the poor insults his Maker, and one who rejoices over calamity will not go unpunished.
17.6: Grandchildren are the crown of the elderly, and the pride of sons is their fathers.
17.7: Eloquent words are not appropriate on a fool’s lips; how much worse are lies for a ruler.
17.8: A bribe seems like a magic stone to its owner; wherever he turns, he succeeds.
17.9: Whoever conceals an offense promotes love, but whoever gossips about it separates friends.
17.10: A rebuke cuts into a perceptive person more than a hundred lashes into a fool.
17.11: An evil man seeks only rebellion; a cruel messenger will be sent against him.
17.12: Better for a man to meet a bear robbed of her cubs than a fool in his foolishness.
17.13: If anyone returns evil for good, evil will never depart from his house.
17.14: To start a conflict is to release a flood; stop the dispute before it breaks out.
17.15: Acquitting the guilty and condemning the just— both are detestable to the LORD.
17.16: Why does a fool have money in his hand with no intention of buying wisdom?
17.17: A friend loves at all times, and a brother is born for a difficult time.
17.18: One without sense enters an agreement and puts up security for his friend.
17.19: One who loves to offend loves strife; one who builds a high threshold invites injury.
17.20: One with a twisted mind will not succeed, and one with deceitful speech will fall into ruin.
17.21: A man fathers a fool to his own sorrow; the father of a fool has no joy.
17.22: A joyful heart is good medicine, but a broken spirit dries up the bones.
17.23: A wicked man secretly takes a bribe to subvert the course of justice.
17.24: Wisdom is the focus of the perceptive, but a fool’s eyes roam to the ends of the earth.
17.25: A foolish son is grief to his father and bitterness to the one who bore him.
17.26: It is certainly not good to fine an innocent person or to beat a noble for his honesty.
17.27: The intelligent person restrains his words, and one who keeps a cool head is a man of understanding.
17.28: Even a fool is considered wise when he keeps silent, discerning when he seals his lips.

18.1: One who isolates himself pursues selfish desires; he rebels against all sound judgment.
18.2: A fool does not delight in understanding, but only wants to show off his opinions.
18.3: When a wicked man comes, contempt also does, and along with dishonor, disgrace.
18.4: The words of a man’s mouth are deep waters, a flowing river, a fountain of wisdom.
18.5: It is not good to show partiality to the guilty by perverting the justice due the innocent.
18.6: A fool’s lips lead to strife, and his mouth provokes a beating.
18.7: A fool’s mouth is his devastation, and his lips are a trap for his life.
18.8: A gossip’s words are like choice food that goes down to one’s innermost being.
18.9: The one who is truly lazy in his work is brother to a vandal.
18.10: The name of Yahweh is a strong tower; the righteous run to it and are protected.
18.11: A rich man’s wealth is his fortified city; in his imagination it is like a high wall.
18.12: Before his downfall a man’s heart is proud, but humility comes before honor.
18.13: The one who gives an answer before he listens— this is foolishness and disgrace for him.
18.14: A man’s spirit can endure sickness, but who can survive a broken spirit?
18.15: The mind of the discerning acquires knowledge, and the ear of the wise seeks it.
18.16: A gift opens doors for a man and brings him before the great.
18.17: The first to state his case seems right until another comes and cross-examines him.
18.18: Casting the lot ends quarrels and separates powerful opponents.
18.19: An offended brother is harder to reach than a fortified city, and quarrels are like the bars of a fortress.
18.20: From the fruit of his mouth a man’s stomach is satisfied; he is filled with the product of his lips.
18.21: Life and death are in the power of the tongue, and those who love it will eat its fruit.
18.22: A man who finds a wife finds a good thing and obtains favor from the LORD.
18.23: The poor man pleads, but the rich one answers roughly.
18.24: A man with many friends may be harmed, but there is a friend who stays closer than a brother.

19.1: Better a poor man who lives with integrity than someone who has deceitful lips and is a fool.
19.2: Even zeal is not good without knowledge, and the one who acts hastily sins.
19.3: A man’s own foolishness leads him astray, yet his heart rages against the LORD.
19.4: Wealth attracts many friends, but a poor man is separated from his friend.
19.5: A false witness will not go unpunished, and one who utters lies will not escape.
19.6: Many seek a ruler’s favor, and everyone is a friend of one who gives gifts.
19.7: All the brothers of a poor man hate him; how much more do his friends keep their distance from him! He may pursue them with words, but they are not there.
19.8: The one who acquires good sense loves himself; one who safeguards understanding finds success.
19.9: A false witness will not go unpunished, and one who utters lies perishes.
19.10: Luxury is not appropriate for a fool— how much less for a slave to rule over princes!
19.11: A person’s insight gives him patience, and his virtue is to overlook an offense.
19.12: A king’s rage is like the roaring of a lion, but his favor is like dew on the grass.
19.13: A foolish son is his father’s ruin, and a wife’s nagging is an endless dripping.
19.14: A house and wealth are inherited from fathers, but a sensible wife is from the LORD.
19.15: Laziness induces deep sleep, and a lazy person will go hungry.
19.16: The one who keeps commands preserves himself; one who disregards his ways will die.
19.17: Kindness to the poor is a loan to the LORD, and He will give a reward to the lender.
19.18: Discipline your son while there is hope; don’t be intent on killing him.
19.19: A person with great anger bears the penalty; if you rescue him, you’ll have to do it again.
19.20: Listen to counsel and receive instruction so that you may be wise later in life.
19.21: Many plans are in a man’s heart, but the LORD’s decree will prevail.
19.22: What is desirable in a man is his fidelity; better to be a poor man than a liar.
19.23: The fear of the LORD leads to life; one will sleep at night without danger.
19.24: The slacker buries his hand in the bowl; he doesn’t even bring it back to his mouth.
19.25: Strike a mocker, and the inexperienced learn a lesson; rebuke the discerning, and he gains knowledge.
19.26: The one who assaults his father and evicts his mother is a disgraceful and shameful son.
19.27: If you stop listening to correction, my son, you will stray from the words of knowledge.
19.28: A worthless witness mocks justice, and a wicked mouth swallows iniquity.
19.29: Judgments are prepared for mockers, and beatings for the backs of fools.

20.1: Wine is a mocker, beer is a brawler, and whoever staggers because of them is not wise.
20.2: A king’s terrible wrath is like the roaring of a lion; anyone who provokes him endangers himself.
20.3: It is honorable for a man to resolve a dispute, but any fool can get himself into a quarrel.
20.4: The slacker does not plow during planting season; at harvest time he looks, and there is nothing.
20.5: Counsel in a man’s heart is deep water; but a man of understanding draws it out.
20.6: Many a man proclaims his own loyalty, but who can find a trustworthy man?
20.7: The one who lives with integrity is righteous; his children who come after him will be happy.
20.8: A king sitting on a throne to judge sifts out all evil with his eyes.
20.9: Who can say, “I have kept my heart pure; I am cleansed from my sin"?
20.10: Differing weights and varying measures— both are detestable to the LORD.
20.11: Even a young man is known by his actions— if his behavior is pure and upright.
20.12: The hearing ear and the seeing eye— the LORD made them both.
20.13: Don’t love sleep, or you will become poor; open your eyes, and you’ll have enough to eat.”
20.14: It’s worthless, it’s worthless!” the buyer says, but after he is on his way, he gloats.
20.15: There is gold and a multitude of jewels, but knowledgeable lips are a rare treasure.
20.16: Take his garment, for he has put up security for a stranger; get collateral if it is for foreigners.
20.17: Food gained by fraud is sweet to a man, but afterward his mouth is full of gravel.
20.18: Finalize plans with counsel, and wage war with sound guidance.
20.19: The one who reveals secrets is a constant gossip; avoid someone with a big mouth.
20.20: Whoever curses his father or mother— his lamp will go out in deep darkness.
20.21: An inheritance gained prematurely will not be blessed ultimately.
20.22: Don’t say, “I will avenge this evil!” Wait on the LORD, and He will rescue you.
20.23: Differing weights are detestable to the LORD, and dishonest scales are unfair.
20.24: A man’s steps are determined by the LORD, so how can anyone understand his own way?
20.25: It is a trap for anyone to dedicate something rashly and later to reconsider his vows.
20.26: A wise king separates out the wicked and drives the threshing wheel over them.
20.27: The LORD’s lamp sheds light on a person’s life, searching the innermost parts.
20.28: Loyalty and faithfulness deliver a king; through loyalty he maintains his throne.
20.29: The glory of young men is their strength, and the splendor of old men is gray hair.
20.30: Lashes and wounds purge away evil, and beatings cleanse the innermost parts.

21.1: A king’s heart is like streams of water in the LORD’s hand: He directs it wherever He chooses.
21.2: All a man’s ways seem right to him, but the LORD evaluates the motives.
21.3: Doing what is righteous and just is more acceptable to the LORD than sacrifice.
21.4: The lamp that guides the wicked— haughty eyes and an arrogant heart—is sin.
21.5: The plans of the diligent certainly lead to profit, but anyone who is reckless certainly becomes poor.
21.6: Making a fortune through a lying tongue is a vanishing mist, a pursuit of death.
21.7: The violence of the wicked sweeps them away because they refuse to act justly.
21.8: A guilty man’s conduct is crooked, but the behavior of the innocent is upright.
21.9: Better to live on the corner of a roof than to share a house with a nagging wife.
21.10: A wicked person desires evil; he has no consideration for his neighbor.
21.11: When a mocker is punished, the inexperienced become wiser; when one teaches a wise man, he acquires knowledge.
21.12: The Righteous One considers the house of the wicked; He brings the wicked to ruin.
21.13: The one who shuts his ears to the cry of the poor will himself also call out and not be answered.
21.14: A secret gift soothes anger, and a covert bribe, fierce rage.
21.15: Justice executed is a joy to the righteous but a terror to those who practice iniquity.
21.16: The man who strays from the way of wisdom will come to rest in the assembly of the departed spirits.
21.17: The one who loves pleasure will become a poor man; whoever loves wine and oil will not get rich.
21.18: The wicked are a ransom for the righteous, and the treacherous, for the upright.
21.19: Better to live in a wilderness than with a nagging and hot-tempered wife.
21.20: Precious treasure and oil are in the dwelling of a wise person, but a foolish man consumes them.
21.21: The one who pursues righteousness and faithful love will find life, righteousness, and honor.
21.22: A wise person went up against a city of warriors and brought down its secure fortress.
21.23: The one who guards his mouth and tongue keeps himself out of trouble.
21.24: The proud and arrogant person, named “Mocker,” acts with excessive pride.
21.25: A slacker’s craving will kill him because his hands refuse to work.
21.26: He is filled with craving all day long, but the righteous give and don’t hold back.
21.27: The sacrifice of a wicked person is detestable— how much more so when he brings it with ulterior motives!
21.28: A lying witness will perish, but the one who listens will speak successfully.
21.29: A wicked man puts on a bold face, but the upright man considers his way.
21.30: No wisdom, no understanding, and no counsel will prevail against the LORD.
21.31: A horse is prepared for the day of battle, but victory comes from the LORD.

22.1: A good name is to be chosen over great wealth; favor is better than silver and gold.
22.2: The rich and the poor have this in common: the LORD made them both.
22.3: A sensible person sees danger and takes cover, but the inexperienced keep going and are punished.
22.4: The result of humility is fear of the LORD, along with wealth, honor, and life.
22.5: There are thorns and snares on the path of the crooked; the one who guards himself stays far from them.
22.6: Teach a youth about the way he should go; even when he is old he will not depart from it.
22.7: The rich rule over the poor, and the borrower is a slave to the lender.
22.8: The one who sows injustice will reap disaster, and the rod of his fury will be destroyed.
22.9: A generous person will be blessed, for he shares his food with the poor.
22.10: Drive out a mocker, and conflict goes too; then quarreling and dishonor will cease.
22.11: The one who loves a pure heart and gracious lips—the king is his friend.
22.12: The LORD’s eyes keep watch over knowledge, but He overthrows the words of the treacherous.
22.13: The slacker says, “There’s a lion outside! I’ll be killed in the public square!”
22.14: The mouth of the forbidden woman is a deep pit; a man cursed by the LORD will fall into it.
22.15: Foolishness is tangled up in the heart of a youth; the rod of discipline will drive it away from him.
22.16: Oppressing the poor to enrich oneself, and giving to the rich—both lead only to poverty.
22.17: Listen closely, pay attention to the words of the wise, and apply your mind to my knowledge.
22.18: For it is pleasing if you keep them within you and if they are constantly on your lips.
22.19: I have instructed you today—even you— so that your confidence may be in the LORD.
22.20: Haven’t I written for you thirty sayings about counsel and knowledge,
22.21: in order to teach you true and reliable words, so that you may give a dependable report to those who sent you?
22.22: Don’t rob a poor man because he is poor, and don’t crush the oppressed at the gate,
22.23: for the LORD will take up their case and will plunder those who plunder them.
22.24: Don’t make friends with an angry man, and don’t be a companion of a hot-tempered man,
22.25: or you will learn his ways and entangle yourself in a snare.
22.26: Don’t be one of those who enter agreements, who put up security for loans.
22.27: If you have no money to pay, even your bed will be taken from under you.
22.28: Don’t move an ancient boundary marker that your fathers set up.
22.29: Do you see a man skilled in his work? He will stand in the presence of kings. He will not stand in the presence of unknown men.

23.1: When you sit down to dine with a ruler, consider carefully what is before you,
23.2: and put a knife to your throat if you have a big appetite;
23.3: don’t desire his choice food, for that food is deceptive.
23.4: Don’t wear yourself out to get rich; stop giving your attention to it.
23.5: As soon as your eyes fly to it, it disappears, for it makes wings for itself and flies like an eagle to the sky.
23.6: Don’t eat a stingy person’s bread, and don’t desire his choice food,
23.7: for it’s like someone calculating inwardly.” Eat and drink,” he says to you, but his heart is not with you.
23.8: You will vomit the little you’ve eaten and waste your pleasant words.
23.9: Don’t speak to a fool, for he will despise the insight of your words.
23.10: Don’t move an ancient boundary marker, and don’t encroach on the fields of the fatherless,
23.11: for their Redeemer is strong, and He will take up their case against you.
23.12: Apply yourself to discipline and listen to words of knowledge.
23.13: Don’t withhold discipline from a youth; if you beat him with a rod, he will not die.
23.14: Strike him with a rod, and you will rescue his life from Sheol.
23.15: My son, if your heart is wise, my heart will indeed rejoice.
23.16: My innermost being will cheer when your lips say what is right.
23.17: Don’t let your heart envy sinners; instead, always fear the LORD.
23.18: For then you will have a future, and your hope will never fade.
23.19: Listen, my son, and be wise; keep your mind on the right course.
23.20: Don’t associate with those who drink too much wine or with those who gorge themselves on meat.
23.21: For the drunkard and the glutton will become poor, and grogginess will clothe them in rags.
23.22: Listen to your father who gave you life, and don’t despise your mother when she is old.
23.23: Buy—and do not sell—truth, wisdom, instruction, and understanding.
23.24: The father of a righteous son will rejoice greatly, and one who fathers a wise son will delight in him.
23.25: Let your father and mother have joy, and let her who gave birth to you rejoice.
23.26: My son, give me your heart, and let your eyes observe my ways.
23.27: For a prostitute is a deep pit, and a stranger is a narrow well;
23.28: indeed, she sets an ambush like a robber and increases those among men who are unfaithful.
23.29: Who has woe? Who has sorrow? Who has conflicts? Who has complaints? Who has wounds for no reason? Who has red eyes?
23.30: Those who linger over wine, those who go looking for mixed wine.
23.31: Don’t gaze at wine because it is red, when it gleams in the cup and goes down smoothly.
23.32: In the end it bites like a snake and stings like a viper.
23.33: Your eyes will see strange things, and you will say absurd things.
23.34: You’ll be like someone sleeping out at sea or lying down on the top of a ship’s mast.”
23.35: They struck me, but I feel no pain! They beat me, but I didn’t know it! When will I wake up? I’ll look for another drink.”

24.1: Don’t envy evil men or desire to be with them,
24.2: for their hearts plan violence, and their words stir up trouble.
24.3: A house is built by wisdom, and it is established by understanding;
24.4: by knowledge the rooms are filled with every precious and beautiful treasure.
24.5: A wise warrior is better than a strong one, and a man of knowledge than one of strength;
24.6: for you should wage war with sound guidance— victory comes with many counselors.
24.7: Wisdom is inaccessible to a fool; he does not open his mouth at the gate.
24.8: The one who plots evil will be called a schemer.
24.9: A foolish scheme is sin, and a mocker is detestable to people.
24.10: If you do nothing in a difficult time, your strength is limited.
24.11: Rescue those being taken off to death, and save those stumbling toward slaughter.
24.12: If you say, “But we didn’t know about this,” won’t He who weighs hearts consider it? Won’t He who protects your life know? Won’t He repay a person according to his work?
24.13: Eat honey, my son, for it is good, and the honeycomb is sweet to your palate;
24.14: realize that wisdom is the same for you. If you find it, you will have a future, and your hope will never fade.
24.15: Wicked man, don’t set an ambush, at the camp of the righteous man; don’t destroy his dwelling.
24.16: Though a righteous man falls seven times, he will get up, but the wicked will stumble into ruin.
24.17: Don’t gloat when your enemy falls, and don’t let your heart rejoice when he stumbles,
24.18: or the LORD will see, be displeased, and turn His wrath away from him.
24.19: Don’t be agitated by evildoers, and don’t envy the wicked.
24.20: For the evil have no future; the lamp of the wicked will be put out.
24.21: My son, fear the LORD, as well as the king, and don’t associate with rebels,
24.22: for destruction from them will come suddenly; who knows what distress these two can bring?
24.23: These sayings also belong to the wise: It is not good to show partiality in judgment.
24.24: Whoever says to the guilty, “You are innocent"— people will curse him, and tribes will denounce him;
24.25: but it will go well with those who convict the guilty, and a generous blessing will come to them.
24.26: He who gives an honest answer gives a kiss on the lips.
24.27: Complete your outdoor work, and prepare your field; afterward, build your house.
24.28: Don’t testify against your neighbor without cause. Don’t deceive with your lips.
24.29: Don’t say, “I’ll do to him what he did to me; I’ll repay the man for what he has done.”
24.30: I went by the field of a slacker and by the vineyard of a man lacking sense.
24.31: Thistles had come up everywhere, weeds covered the ground, and the stone wall was ruined.
24.32: I saw, and took it to heart; I looked, and received instruction:
24.33: a little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the arms to rest,
24.34: and your poverty will come like a robber, your need, like a bandit.

25.1: These too are proverbs of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah, king of Judah, copied.
25.2: It is the glory of God to conceal a matter and the glory of kings to investigate a matter.
25.3: As the heaven is high and the earth is deep, so the hearts of kings cannot be investigated.
25.4: Remove impurities from silver, and a vessel will be produced for a silversmith.
